story:
This campaign will ensure that Guest House Theatre can successfully establish itself among the ranks of Madison’s professional theatres. This will increase the number of opportunities for local professional artists while adding to the quality of Madison’s growing performing arts community. 

Your contribution ensures that all artists involved in our first season will be compensated for their work. You also assure high production values for our first season. 

Our goal: $8,000.

These funds will cover: 

  • Compensation for actors, designers and directors 
  • Costumes, properties, and set costs for our two main stage productions in our inaugural 2020-2021 season 
  • 2020-2021 season marketing and advertising 

Who is Guest House Theatre?

Guest House Theatre is a professional theatre company based in Madison, WI. We are an ensemble of Madison-area theatre artists. Our name comes from the poem The Guest House, but 13th century Iranian poet Jalaluddin Rumi, the first line of which is "This being human is a guest house."

Our goal as artists and a company are to tell stories that matter. We want to bring stories and characters to the stage that reach outside ourselves and reach into our community. We want our audiences to be our guests, to know that when they enter our house, they will be able to connect with experiences that not only resonate with them, but exposes them to the experience of others in their community and beyond. 

Why support Guest House Theatre? 

Guest House Theatre will add a needed small professional theatre company to Madison’s evolving arts community. Small professional--sometimes called "store front"--theatres are a vital part of a thriving performing arts culture. And while Madison has a significant community theatre community, and respected larger companies like Forward Theatre Company and Children's Theatre of Madison, we saw a need for a "store front" sized company. A company like Guest House provides more opportunities for locally based professional artists while also creating an outlet for new and lesser seen playwrights.

Why is this necessary now? Because Madison is a growing, evolving city. Census estimates show the city's population has grown to over 250,000...almost a 20% increase since 2000. This growth is transforming the city. Already, Madison has the eyes of the region and nation turned towards it because of its growing bio and medical technology industries,  its thriving culinary culture, and it's lifestyle amenities. We want to be a part of turning those eyes toward Madison’s arts community, helping to solidy Madison’s status as a thriving, growing city. 

One way to do that is by giving talented artists more reasons to plant roots here, the same way the core ensemble members of Guest House Theatre have. We live here because we choose here, and we believe great art can come from here. 

Why can we succeed? Because all members of this company have extensive arts backgrounds. They have managed and founded theatre companies, acted and directed on stages large and small, taught aspiring performers, written plays that have a national profile, and worked for and attained high level degrees in theatre arts and management. We bring decades of experience and training to the table, combined with an intimate knowledge of the Madison area.

Are there risks? Of course. There are few new ventures that begin without risk. One of ours is that Madison is growing fast, but it’s still a small city. Will it support a growing number of professional theatre companies? Will the city increasing embrace the performing arts the way that embraces other cultural options, like music and restaurant culture.

Also, it will be critical for us to connect with existing major arts funders in the region. As finding and cultivating new funders. Ticket sales and the generousity of our initial supporters will not be enough. We will need to build relationships with the larger cultural funding and business institutions in Madison and the surrounding area. 

Finally, we have to be successful at differentiating ourselves successfully and ensure that audiences identify our work in the professional sector. 

We are confident we can meet these challenges. We have already begun the process of relationship building. Our core company is filled with artists who have high level credentials and experience. That includes multiple masters of fine arts and a master of arts administration. All have worked with professional companies on stage and/or in administration. Two of our founders have started multiple small, successful theatre companies in Madison. We have deep connections to our local arts, business and academic, and communities. We know people. We are have an intense ambition to not only be working theatre artists, but to be thriving and successful theatre artists. Maybe most importantly, we love this city and area. We are committed to the Madison region, with most of us owning homes here and raising our children here. And we want our work to help it be a place where all its citizens can thrive and be proud to call themselves Madisonians. 

How will we specifically address these challenges? Several ways: 

·       Continue to implement our comprehensive marketing and PR plan

·       Grow relationships with members of the Madison arts community through face to face meetings with leaders and other participants

·       Raise funds on Indiegogo and through our fiscal receiver, Arts Wisconsin, to provide donors with proof that we are not only talented artists, but able to build a stable organization from scratch. We will prove we are a “good bet” for their support

·       Manage our first season costs carefully, to make sure as much ticket revenue as possible can go to providing a stable basis for our future seasons. How have we already done this? By negotiating relationships with Edgewood College and UW-Madison to produce our first two mainstage productions at their facilities for no cost while providing their students with career building opportunities. 

·       Strategically select our first mainstage shows to appeal to a diverse range of audiences about topics that resonate with those audiences.

We appreciate every contribution! Here is how we plan to thank each donor.

$25     A personalized shout-out on GHT Facebook page

$50    Facebook shout-out and a GHT fridge magnet! 

$100 Cast and ensemble signed GHT show poster

$250 VIP seating at GHT 1st season shows, a handmade treat from the GHT core       

                     member of your choice

$500* VIP seating at GHT 1st season shows plus name recognition from the stage 

$1000* (Show sponsor) Name recognition from stage. 

                      Photo or logo recognition in show programs. 

                      Name recognition at our future GHT space (Business sponsors also get logo on     

                      posters and 6 show tickets)

$2500+*        (Season sponsor) Name recognition from stage

                      Photo or logo recognition in show programs. 

                      Premium name recognition in GHT future space. 

                      VIP opportunities with GHT artists and core ensemble members. 

                      (Business sponsors get logo on all posters and 8 tickets to all mainstage shows).

 *$500 and above get a special invite to a season-ending cocktail party in the home of GHT cofounders Dave and Karen, attended by the entire core ensemble and other GHT artists who participated in the season. Sit on the red couch where it all began!

 

“How will funds be used if you don’t reach your goal?”

Artist compensation will take priority. Remaining funds will go to production costs and materials

 

What can you do besides contribute? 

Help us spread the word. If you can only give a small amount, then also share this campaign with friends and family. Tell them why you think it's important. The more people who know, the more impact this campaign will have. 

Also, meet with us. Let us buy you coffee. Let us tell you why we believe Guest House Theatre is an important addition to our city and our artistic community. Then tell others about us.

story:
Who We Are

 

Hi there! We're Company of Fools. Allow us to introduce ourselves.

ARTISTIC STATEMENT:
Company of Fools is an independent, Latino-founded and run contemporary theatre company committed to community, social engagement, and innovation. We strive to constantly challenge the limits of our own ability, study, understanding, and advocacy. To this end, our mantra for our art is: Dare to fail gloriously. Our brand, our methodologies, and our spirit does not shy away from challenge or change. We are always willing to push the absolute edge of our capabilities as artists, teachers, and creators. Our willingness to push past the fear of failure can and must lead to unheard-of success.

MISSION STATEMENT: 
Company of Fools is a contemporary theatre company with a threefold mission: 

  1. to present powerful, thoughtful, redemptive, and invigorating productions of 20th- and 21st-century texts;
  2. to commission, create, develop, and produce new, original works; and
  3. to empower new voices, new artists, new communities, and new perspectives throughout our various artistic pursuits.

Inspired by the Shakespearean Fool, we strive to maintain a humorous but worldly outlook on our work. Our community is our lifeblood, and our artists and collaborators are our family. Please feel free to reach out anytime by emailing info@companyoffoolstheatre.com. 

What We're Doing

At the beginning of quarantine, Company of Fools was the first independent theatre company to sponsor and produce virtual staged readings. We've spent the last few months building community, connecting with other artists, and gearing up for the reopening. And we're anxious and eager to get back onstage! So we're producing one of our favorite plays: Rajiv Joseph's brilliant Gruesome Playground Injuries. Never heard of it? Well, it’s not your typical love story. Doug and Kayleen meet in the nurse’s office in their elementary school; she’s got a painful stomach ache, and he’s all banged up from a running dive off the roof of the school. Over the next thirty years, these scar-crossed lovers meet again and again, brought together by injury, heartbreak, and their own self-destructive tendencies. With great compassion and humor, Rajiv Joseph (Broadway’s Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo) crafts a compelling and unconventional love story about the intimacy between two people when they allow their defenses to drop and their wounds to show.

And there are a few things different about our show, too!

First, this is a multi-disciplinary presentation: a piece of immersive theatre paired with an independent painting exhibition by New York artist Brittany Miller. We invite you to join us back at the theatre with a powerful and redemptive return to Company of Fools’ unique brand of work. We'll be staging a production that moves all around our audience in partnership with Culture Lab LIC at Long Island City's beautiful Plaxall Gallery.

Second, we have an excellent space to use for the production! The space is flexible, conveniently located, and beautiful. Not only that, the multiple gallery spaces make for a brilliantly immersive experience, an exciting method of demonstrating multiple disciplines, and a coming together of artists that aren’t possible elsewhere. Our production hopes to partner with Plaxall and Culture Lab in order to reach out to the local community as well as the NYC artistic community at large. The local LIC community has been hit hard by the global pandemic, and the artistic community in NYC has as well. We would like this production to be an opportunity for multidisciplinary artists and the community at large to come together in recognition of how far we've come.

Third, we're excited to be bringing together those multiple disciplines into one cohesive production for a low production cost. We're not a billion-dollar Broadway enterprise (and we're proud of it...), but we're committed to bringing you excellent, high-quality off-Broadway work in person or at home.

Not ready to be in a theatre yet? No problem -- we'll also be streaming this production online on all of our production dates! So you can tune in from the comfort of your own home as well and join us as we come back to the theatre.

More Show Details

PERFORMANCE DATES:
Sat., May 15 @ 8:00 pm
Sun., May 16 @ 8:00 pm
Mon., May 17 @ 8:00 pm

Sat., May 22 @ 8:00 pm
Sun., May 23 @ 8:00 pm
Mon., May 24 @ 8:00 pm

All performances at Culture Lab LIC @ The Plaxall Gallery,
5-25 46th Avenue, Queens

CREATIVE & PRODUCTION TEAM:
Directed for the Stage by Tyler Riley
Conceptual Direction by Cameron Cueva Clarke
Produced by Company of Fools
Stage Manager: Natalie Jones

Intimacy Director: Brooke M. Haney
Video Production & Streaming: Kevin Tully
Makeup Design: Charlotte Bravin Lee
Visual Art Exhibition by Brittany Miller

FEATURING:
Cameron Cueva Clarke & Logan Alexis Troyer

What We Need & What You Get

Alright, here's the fun part. We need your help!

  • We need to raise $5,000 to fully fund our production, pay our fees, and get butts in the seats! As you may know, ticket costs can never fully cover the cost of producing a show iN New York City. That's why we need your help. The funds raised here will pay for artist and production team salaries, rental fees, rights & royalties, painting materials, props & scenic elements, and miscellaneous transportation costs. It's very important to us that we pay all members of our team a fair salary for their time and effort, particularly as the COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing and some folks are still out of work.
  • We have a variety of awesome perks, from online shout-outs to songs to drawings to producer credits and free tickets! Check them all out in detail down below.
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we'll be bummed, but in that case, all funds raised will go towards artists' salaries. 

Why Are We Doing This?

Gruesome Playground Injuries as a play charts the intersection of two lives using scars, wounds, and calamity as the mile markers to explore why people hurt themselves to gain another’s love. The wounds and scars that stay the longest are the invisible ones and are often inflicted on the ones we love most, as well as ourselves.

SOME CONCEPTUAL NOTES:

  • Gruesome Playground Injuries is the perfect show as we come out of the Pandemic Times. It speaks to prolonged absences and how they impact relationships. It also speaks to the common bond that connects all of us in these times: trauma and our recovery. But it does it with humor and kindness.
  • This production will lean into the minimalist elements of the play, and showcase the art of “play" that lives inside all of us. 
  • In between scenes, actors will move about the Plaxall Gallery space, showcasing the more intimate moments of their relationship in an almost “dreamlike” sense; the feelings that remain even in the times they are apart, much as many of us are experiencing right now.

Risks & Challenges

There are definitely some challenges we're all facing. And here are some of ours.

  • Money. Obviously, we all know that things are tight right now. And good art costs money. CoF is of the opinion that good art doesn't have to cost millions of dollars, which is why we're raising such a modest amount. That being said: we can't do it on our own! And that's where you come in.
  • COVID-19 Stuff. As New York City's arts sector slowly starts to reopen, there are a lot of hurdles to navigate as far as keeping everyone safe and healthy. We're uniquely equipped as a company to handle this, having worked independently in small spaces throughout the city and run our own front of house for all of our past productions. We'll keep you safe and healthy, and make sure everyone has a great time doing it!
  • Equity. Company of Fools wants all artists to be treated fairly and paid equitably. We're a Latino founded and run company with a passion for employing folks from all backgrounds. Our board is gender and ethnically diverse and so is our production team, from playwright to management to cast.

Other Ways You Can Help

Listen, we understand that things are crazy right now. Don't think you can spare some change for our project? That's okay! There are other great ways you can help:

  • Make some noise! Tell your friends about our campaign and encourage them to help us however they can. And tag us (@foolsco) and use our hashtags on social media: #fiveyearsoffools #CoF #CoFgruesome #gruesomefools
  • Volunteer! Reach out to the members of the team to help out. We're looking for assistance with front-of-house, ushering, and other complications we need to navigate as a result of COVID-19 protocols.
  • Share! Use the Indiegogo share tools to blast all your friends about the campaign. :)

 

That's all we have for you right now. If you have any questions before you donate, don't hesitate to reach out. And don't forget to read all about our great perks. Thanks in advance, and stay safe!

story:
About Us

The World Voice Ensemble Inc. is a nonprofit organization, formed for the educational and charitable purposes of giving international students of the arts and professional international artists the opportunity to perform, with Americans, in professional quality theater in New York City. The corporation's purpose will be achieved by producing known and original plays and musicals that will include roles open in casting to Americans, as well as Asian, Spanish, Black, and White international artists.

私たちThe World Voice Ensemble は、アメリカに留学している、またはアメリカで活躍したいと思っているインターナショナルの俳優、作家、学生が、アメリカ人と共に舞台を作っていく経験、機会をもっと身近なものにし、インターナショナルのアーティストとしてニューヨークで活躍出来る場をより多く増やす事を目的に作られた、NYCを中心に活動する、NPO法人のシアターカンパニーです。私たちはアメリカ人、アジア人、スペイン人、黒人、白人等、人種関係なく出演出来るミュージカル、演劇をプロデュースしていきます。


Our Partners Are Our Audiences,

Your Support is Vital to Our Production.

The World Voice Ensemble Inc. is a nonprofit organization, and ticket revenue covers only about 50% of our operating costs.We need $2,500 to cover the theater cost for our production of the "BORDERLINE Preview Concert". Our performance is scheduled to play from Thursday April 24 through Sunday April 26, 2015 at The Secret Theatre in Queens, NY.

私たちはサポートを必要としています。

The World Voice Ensemble は非営利団体であり、各公演のチケット収入は興業にかかるすべての費用のうち、約50％しかカバーすることができません。そのため、私たちは皆様からの寄付を必要としています。このたび、私たちの新しいミュージカル「BORDERLINE（ボーダーライン）」のプレビューコンサート公演にともない、劇場レンタル費用の 2,500ドル について、寄付を募っています。このミュージカルは、4月24日（金）から4月26日（日）までクイーンズのシークレットシアターにて上演されます。


The Story of "BORDERLINE"

BORDERLINE is a new original musical comedy that explores the modern day immigrant's experiences. It follows the lives of 7 immigrants who attend the same ESL class, showing their past struggles and the present obstacles they face now living in New York City. It explores each of their American dreams and includes heavy themes of racial prejudice, inequality, and sexual discrimination. It is a musical theater comedy and a parody of the famous broadway musical, A Chorus Line.

ミュージカル「BORDERLINE（ボーダーライン）」とは
同じ英会話教室に通う7人の外国人が、移民としてニューヨークで暮らすうちに経験した数々の苦難、また今、まさに直面している移民ならではの問題をコミカルに描く、現代の新しいミュージカル・コメディです。物語はそれぞれの持つアメリカンドリーム、そしてときに人種的偏見、性的差別、不平等など、彼らが抱える深刻なテーマを探っていきます。
往年のブロードウェイミュージカル、「コーラスライン」をパロディーにした作品です。

※本公演は、ミュージカル「BORDERLINE」に挿入されている楽曲を演奏するプレビューコンサートです。


Various Perks We Offer

  • Special Seating! -- Get seats with in the 1st or 2nd row!
  • The World Voice Ensemble Original Reusable Eco Tote
  • Invitation to The Closing Cast Party!
  • Your Name Published in Our Program!
  • DVD recorded this show BORDERLINE Preview Concert

皆様のご支援に感謝の気持ちを込め、さまざまな特典を用意しています。
     ・特別席へご案内！（最前列または2列目にてご鑑賞いただけます。）
     ・The World Voice Ensemble特製ECOトートバッグプレゼント！
　  ・当公演を収録したスペシャルDVDをプレゼント！    
　  ・キャストパーティーへご招待！（公演最終日）
     ・お客様のお名前がプログラムに掲載されます！

About Us
The World Voice Ensemble Inc. is a nonprofit organization, formed for the educational and charitable purposes of giving international students of the arts and professional international artists the opportunity to perform, with Americans, in professional quality theater in New York City. The corporation's purpose will be achieved by producing known and original plays and musicals that will include roles open in casting to Americans, as well as Asian, Spanish, Black, and White international artists. 私たちThe World Voice Ensemble は、アメリカに留学している、またはアメリカで活躍したいと思っているインターナショナルの俳優、作家、学生が、アメリカ人と共に舞台を作っていく経験、機会をもっと身近なものにし、インターナショナルのアーティストとしてニューヨークで活躍出来る場をより多く増やす事を目的に作られた、NYCを中心に活動する、NPO法人のシアターカンパニーです。私たちはアメリカ人、アジア人、スペイン人、黒人、白人等、人種関係なく出演出来るミュージカル、演劇をプロデュースしていきます。Our Partners Are Our Audiences,

story:
Be a part of the biggest musical production New Orleans has ever seen and help people still finding their way home ten years on. With a cast of over 100, Tobias and the Angel is a true community production and YOU can be a part of it, in the process helping people still working to return home following the failure of the federal levees in 2005.

Our aim? To benefit local communities. We want to do this in two ways: firstly by involving people in a huge artistic project and secondly through actual money raised. We have partnered with the St Bernard Project, who work to rehouse people directly affected by flooding in 2005. The work continues. No profits will be taken from this production. 

My name is Paul Oswell, and in 2006, living in London, I was lucky enough to be involved in something magical. Tobias and the Angel is an exceptional musical event that unites communities. People from every walk of life and background are put to work on and off stage, to help bring this amazing story to life. 

About that story.  Our reluctant hero Tobias is forced far from home after a tragedy only to triumph against evil and return home to rediscover his roots. The wonderful music was composed by Jonathan Dove, with equally engaging lyrics by David Lan. I feel like this has a special resonance for the people of New Orleans, which is why I want 'Tobias and the Angel' to happen here. I want to involve the city's local communities and have people perform who might not otherwise get the chance.

The cast will include: 12 professional performers from New Orleans, a 12-piece orchestra of young, local musicians, a 30-strong chorus of adults, a 30-strong chorus of children and a 20-member local choir. 

Tobias is a life-changing production. By helping to stage it, you're supporting local musicians and performers. You're also helping to involve New Orleans communities, from senior citizens to children, in a life-affirming, creative project.

And you don't just have to contribute. You can be part of it.

What We Need

Staging this magical musical is going to cost money, and it's not a production company, it's just me. I already have many people lined up who are giving their time and talents for free, but we want to pay as many people as much as possible. I'm working for free and the show is not going to take a profit - all of the money we raise will go into the show and to help raise money for our charity partner, the St Bernard Project. 

Example costs:

- Licensing and royalties (around $750 per show)

- An orchestra of young local musicians (around $8,000 for rehearsals and shows)

- A professional principal cast - again, locally sourced ($5,000)

- A musical director, choreographer, lighting director and a stage manager ($6,000)

- Audition and rehearsal space ($2,000)

- Set design ($3,000)

- Publicity, so that we can involve as many people as possible ($1,000)

The entire budget will likely come in at around $30,000, some of which will come from ticket sales, but we also need to raise some of this money up front - the good news is we have some amazing rewards!

The Impact

The staging of Tobias and the Angel brings people together. It is a true example of what beloved New Orleans ambassador Wendell Pierce calls "the transformative power of art". And as a bonus, we employ a large number of local musicians and artists, AND best of all, the city gets to see an incredible show. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that some people just can’t contribute financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help at all:

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tool on your social media. 
  • Sign up on the Tobias in NOLA website (www.tobiasinnola.com) to be a part of the production

I'm beyond excited to try and make Tobias and the Angel a reality. Thank you for your time and for your help. 

Paul Oswell

story:
Hey dance fans! Got a minute?

My name is Nathalie Matychak. I am a 26-year old choreographer inspired by the unbearable lightness of being, mixed media collaborations, random acts of kindness and changing the way we see the world one dance at a time. I also happen to be the founder, artistic director and dancemaker behind MATYCHAK.

MATYCHAK is a project-based contemporary modern dance company in NYC that aims to fuse the uptown and downtown modern dance worlds. Since beginning in 2011, we have shown work at some incredible venues such as Joe's Pub, Symphony Space, and The 92nd Street Y. We've participated in choreographic mentorships with esteemed choreographers Stephen Petronio and Doug Varone, and we joined ELSCO Dance in co-founding the pilot program for Breaking Glass: The Emerging Female Choreographers Project in 2013.

As a choreographer being asked to perform work that is generally on the shorter side, our performance at Dixon Place on April 14, 2015 will be the premiere of our FIRST EVER full-length work. That means 23 minutes of MATYCHAK goodness. This is a lot of stage time. This is awesome. This is a really big deal.

My collaborators and I have been hard at work since the summer of 2014 to make this work into a reality. We all love dancing so much, we would probably do it for free; however, that's just not the way the world works! We need your help  to fund this endeavor.


What We Need & What You Get

  • We are aiming to raise $2,000 in 2 months (#2in2)
  • This money will go directly to our dedicated team -- dancer rehearsal and performance pay, costume design, rehearsal space, transportation, marketing, etc. Any additional funds raised will go towards future project collaborators and festival applications.
  • Wondering what's in it for you? Besides us thinking you are the greatest thing since sliced bread, our backers will receive a variety of perks like social media shout-outs, a limited edition crochet heart from costume designer London Kaye's 1000 Hearts Project, an invitation to sit in on a MATYCHAK rehearsal, 2 tickets to our show, and even a producer credit!


So why donate to MATYCHAK's #2in2 Campaign?

Let's be real -- it is hard to make it as an artist anywhere, let alone in New York City. But we are fearless! This opportunity came on the heels of being one of 16 choreographers selected to participate in DEVICES: Choreographic Intensive (CHIN), a mentoring program of Doug Varone and Dancers, made possible with generous funding support from the New York Community Trust.  The program is supported, in part, by public funds from the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs, in partnership with the City Council and presented in partnership with the 92nd Street Y. WIthout CHIN, Lacuna would have never been.

We also have some amazing things in the works other than our show at Dixon Place. We have been invited to show excerpts of Lacuna at the pushing progress 2015 Showcase at The Salvatore Capezio Theater at Peridance on February 22, 2015 and the WestFest Top Floor Festival at Westbeth's Martha Graham Studio Theater between April 30, 2015 - May 3, 2015. An intensive process collaboration with Robert Wuss from The Wooster Group and sound designer Izzi Ramkissoon will extend MATYCHAK's creative repertoire by diving into mixed media collaborations with Imogen Heap's burgeoning sound glove technology and alpha particle projections. Pretty cool, huh?


With Risk comes Reward . . .

This is not our first time at the rodeo. In 2011, MATYCHAK [formerly known as BANGdance]  exceeded it's goal of raising $1,000 on  Indiegogo towards production costs for our first professional performance as part of DanceNOW NYC's Joe's Pub 2011 Festival at The Public.

We will also be holding an open rehearsal to help raise additional funds for Lacuna on Saturday, March 28, 2015 from 6pm-8pm at Gibney Downtown (280 Broadway, entrance on Chambers Street). Come and have some tasty snacks and a speciality cocktail inspired by Lacuna designed by Norwood Club mixologist Taylor Nathe (who just so happens to be the love of my life, so don't forget to tip!)


Low on green, but still want to help?

Times are tough -- don't we know it! But there are other ways you can help besides donating money. You can get the word out about our campaign via social media websites such as Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr and Instagram. Just use the hashtags #MATYCHAK #2in2 and the Indiegogo share tools found on this page.

Come and have some tasty snacks and a speciality cocktail inspired by Lacuna designed by Norwood Club mixologist Taylor Nathe (who just so happens to be the love of my life, so don't forget to tip!)

Just use the hashtags #MATYCHAK #2in2 and the Indiegogo share tools found on this page.

story:
Who I am

Hello! My name is Theo Lowrey and I'm a Junior at Bard College studying Music and History with a Concentration in Middle Eastern Studies. I've acted for years and been in a number of productions in the college both on and behind stage.

The Play

The show is centered around the ways we move on from the past. It follows a character who simulates memory through the stories captured in inanimate objects. I have worked with a number of storytellers, including Aleah Black, Evan Crommett, Sophia Shwab, Aurora Case, and Cindy Ji, using their stories as the structure and mold of this play. It centers around themes of love, memory, identity, sexuality, and family.

Why we need your help

The Collector centers around the memories captured in objects. Because of this, we need a lot of props, materials for set pieces, and costumes and this costs money. We also plan on commissioning some artists from New York to create shadow puppets that will be incorporated  into the production. The school is not subsidizing the play, so we really rely on your contributions!

Any support is greatly appreciated, whether it be financial or by sharing this on any and all forms of social media to get the word out! The funds will go directly to creating this world!

Thank you all so much!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Rhiannon Stanuch and I am the Slammaster for the Rockford Certified Slam. We are a not for profit community arts group in Rockford IL. We are very excited to be the selected city for this years Rustbelt Midwest Regional Poetry Slam. The Rustbelt Midwest Regional Poetry Slam is the biggest slam poetry competition in the Midwest. It attracts 100 of the nation's best spoken word artist competing for word dominance! It does not have funding and so each years host city is in charge of raising their own funds. This is a once in a lifetime event for the City of Rockford! These amazing poets will be pulling all the stops to show this town just how incredible spoken word can be. In return, we want to show the rest of the Midwest just how awesome Rockford can be. This is a 2 day event, June 19th and 20th. It will be held at several of Rockford's best local businesses. This is a free event but a suggested donation of $5.00 going to all local charities is advised. Rockford Certified Slam wants to use this as a chance to help our local businesses, charities, art community, and the city as a whole. Your contribution will make this entire event happen. Every penny counts and we would love to show the world how important this art form is. We are bringing people together for the love of words. Won't you join us?

What We Need & What You Get

We need to gather $2000.00 to hold the event. This will go to pay for insurance, advertising, licensing, location hosts, PA rentals, and welcome programs for the teams involved. In return the local businesses will be donating there event spaces and the library will be donating the final stage.

We will have some amazing perks for those that are caring and donate to our cause. We will have 5 tiers of perks and every single one of them will be completed by our local poets.

If we do not receive all the funds in this campaign we will use what we do receive towards the above listed things and work on other inventive ways to make up the difference. Even if we have to do a bake sale/ car wash every weekend until the event. No matter what we will make this amazing event happen. Any extra funds that may remain will go toward sending a local team to another regional poetry event. Giving back to the arts community in other cities that are now supporting ours.  

The Impact

This will impact many factors for Rockford. First of all the spoken word art form is an amazing way for people to discuss and express very complex emotions. It is a great art form to get the youth involved in because it helps them deal with issues that are hard to discuss in regular conversation. It teaches stage presence and confidence as well as writing and memorizing skills. This event will be filmed and will be posted so anyone worldwide will be able to watch and enjoy the performances for years to come.

The event has been held for many years at different cities throughout the midwest. It has always made a positive imprint on the community. It has successfully been held in cities like Madison, Detroit, Minneapolis, and more.

In the end it is about sharing the power of poetry with everyone. That is why we strive to always make it a free event. 

Risks & Challenges

Our challenges are few but not always easy to overcome. Our biggest challenge is having the event known throughout town. The second is having the insurance and volunteers in place to make the event go. As a small business owner, Slam Master, Art Program Creator and volunteer coordinator I feel my background will make this an easy event to make go as long as we have the support of the community we need. We do already have people asking to volunteer and as long as this amazing group of people keeps helping I think this will be an extraordinary event. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Can't help financially? Thats okay. We do need volunteers to help at the event and would love anyone that would like to help. Also, if you could like Rustbelt Rockford 2015 on facebook and help us spread the word about the event and the campaign for funds we would be so thankful!
story_txt:
Short Summary My name is Rhiannon Stanuch and I am the Slammaster for the Rockford Certified Slam. We are a not for profit community arts group in Rockford IL. We are very excited to be the selected city for this years Rustbelt Midwest Regional Poetry Slam. The Rustbelt Midwest Regional Poetry Slam is the biggest slam poetry competition in the Midwest. It attracts 100 of the nation's best spoken word artist competing for word dominance! It does not have funding and so each years host city is in charge of raising their own funds. This is a once in a lifetime event for the City of Rockford! These amazing poets will be pulling all the stops to show this town  just how incredible spoken word can be. In return, we want to show the rest of the Midwest just how awesome Rockford can be. This is a 2 day event, June 19th and 20th. It will be held at several of Rockford's best local businesses. This is a free event but a suggested donation of $5.00 going to all local charities is advised. Rockford Certified Slam wants to use this as a chance to help our local businesses, charities, art community, and the city as a whole. Your contribution will make this entire event happen. Every penny counts and we would love to show the world how important this art form is. We are bringing people together for the love of words. Won't you join us?   What We Need & What You Get We need to gather $2000.00 to hold the event. This will go to pay for insurance, advertising, licensing, location hosts, PA rentals, and welcome programs for the teams involved. In return the local businesses will be donating there event spaces and the library will be donating the final stage. 
We will have some amazing perks for those that are caring and donate to our cause. We will have 5 tiers of perks and every single one of them will be completed by our local poets.
If we do not receive all the funds in this campaign we will use what we do receive towards the above listed things and work on other inventive ways to make up the difference. Even if we have to do a bake sale/ car wash every weekend until the event. No matter what we will make this amazing event happen. Any extra funds that may remain will go toward sending a local team to another regional poetry event. Giving back to the arts community in other cities that are now supporting ours.   
  The Impact This will impact many factors for Rockford. First of all the spoken word art form is an amazing way for people to discuss and express very complex emotions. It is a great art form to get the youth involved in because it helps them deal with issues that are hard to discuss in regular conversation. It teaches stage presence and confidence as well as writing and memorizing skills. This event will be filmed and will be posted so anyone worldwide will be able to watch and enjoy the performances for years to come.The event has been held for many years at different cities throughout the midwest. It has always made a positive imprint on the community. It has successfully been held in cities like Madison, Detroit, Minneapolis, and more.In the end it is about sharing the power of poetry with everyone. That is why we strive to always make it a free event.    Risks & Challenges  Our challenges are few but not always easy to overcome. Our biggest challenge is having the event known throughout town. The second is having the insurance and volunteers in place to make the event go. As a small business owner, Slam Master, Art Program Creator and volunteer coordinator I feel my background will make this an easy event to make go as long as we have the support of the community we need. We do already have people asking to volunteer and as long as this amazing group of people keeps helping I think this will be an extraordinary event.     Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:Can't help financially? Thats okay. We do need volunteers to help at the event and would love anyone that would like to help. Also, if you could like Rustbelt Rockford 2015 on facebook and help us spread the word about the event and the campaign for funds we would be so thankful!

story: My name is Nona Cuthbertson, working mother of five (24,22,20 and twins 17) and grandmother of one. the latter four are still attending school. My son Jomo (20) is enrolled in the professional Theater Program at John Abbott College in Montreal , Quebec, Canada. Jomo has obtained a role in a theatrical group to present a piece on anti violence at this years 2015 Fringe Festival in Edinburgh Scotland,with the condition that each cast member come up with 2000$ to cover the airfare and lodging's for two weeks.  Due to Jomo's heavy study load he lives near campus in order to meet the demands of his schedule. He works part time to pay for school fees and living accommodations.  I would love to say to him "oh no problem son, here is the money plus some extra for all the hard work you have been putting into your education". with five children I can not say that. Jomo is full of life and adventure I do not want this door of opportunity  to be closed. The Fringe Festival is a great experience.  2$ from 1000 people is a light burden but 1$ from 2000 people is even lighter. share this with as many people as possible.

story:
Our Story 

From the creators of Refugee Nation, Pop-Up TeAda!, TEADAWORKS, and more, TeAda Productions is proud to bring you the Los Angeles premiere of GLOBAL TAXI DRIVER. 

We are so excited to present our production. This is an exciting play that takes the entire audience on a truly exciting ride through the lives and untold stories of taxi drivers from all over the world. 

In association with East West Players, this is our biggest production yet. We have 50% of the production cost covered through grants. However, we still need individual donations to help cover the increased production costs including actor wages, set design, and providing discounted and free tickets to low-income families and youth in Los Angeles.

Our Plan & Perks 

Help pay for the ride! We need to raise a least $10,000 to make this happen. 

That covers:

  • Cast and crew wages (Let's pay actors for rehearsals!)
  • Set & Prop Design (This show will have a SET!)
  • Rehearsal space rental (Big theater means we need a big space to rehearse in.)
  • Publicity and Marketing (Gotta sell 1500 seats somehow!)
  • Discounted tickets for low-income families (including taxi drivers) and students (Because why are we doing this work anyway if the people we are inspired by can't see what we create?!)
  • Youth Program including: High School Matinee, Study Guide, TeAda Workshop & Post-Show Discussion
  • Free childcare for performances and much more!
We want everyone to know that we appreciate your donations. So we have some sweet perks. Such as wine tasting, Dear White People DVDs signed by cast members, TeAda swag, home cooked Lao meals, and lots more!  Special perks include discounted & free tickets, VIP seating and Special events during the  GLOBAL TAXI DRIVER run.

Why Global Taxi Driver Matters

Taxi Drivers are part of our communities. TeAda's production of GLOBAL TAXI DRIVER is serving as a platform for Los Angeles taxi workers to organize for fair wages and benefits with the National Taxi Workers Alliance and the UCLA Labor Center.  Art has the power to plant seeds of empathy, and foster social change-- we are excited to see the fruits of action develop.  Through supporting this work, you are supporting taxi workers-- an important and often overlooked sector of immigrant workers in Los Angeles.

This is such an important story for us and our community. There has never been a play about taxi drivers and their stories. Global Taxi Driver is inspired by the real life experiences of taxi drivers from L.A. to Minneapolis, Bangkok to Gualajara,  GLOBAL TAXI DRIVER uncovers a unique view of the planet - from behind the wheel of a cab. Throughout the world, taxi driving is a gateway profession for immigrants, often taken on by people who were once farmers, soldiers, doctors, or lawyers. With the growth of ride-sharing services threatening this occupation, these stories become even more urgent to tell.

Our L.A. production is our opportunity to tell these important stories. Help us bring this story to life. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Thank you! We appreciate your donation. If you are unable to donate, please share our cause on FaceBook, Twitter, Instagram, Tumblr, Imgur, Reddit, etc. Also, please purchase a ticket to the show! Thanks so much!

story:
Short Summary

We are Tap the Table Productions, a theatre company that began life in 2011 formed by graduate actors from the School of the Arts: The University of Northampton. We create comedic shows that incorporate ridiculous characters, physical comedy and witty dialogue. However it’s not all about trying to make people laugh; we use the comedy within our shows to help make serious social messages all the more poignant. We want our audiences to be laughing one minute and crying the next!

Back in 2013 we toured a comedic adaptation of Shakespeare's classic tragedy 'Macbeth'. We looked to not only entertain but also challenge the stigma and increase understanding of mental health. The production has SO much more potential for social impact and so we need YOUR help to bring it back but this time bigger, better and bolder than before.

The Impact

There are big problems with society’s tolerance and attitudes towards those with mental health issues and we need your help to tackle this! Our project will reduce stigma and fuel understanding of mental health through theatre. Having experienced and known people who have had mental health issues we feel incredibly passionate about the subject and truly feel through our skills as performers that we can make a difference. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are already putting £5,000 into this project by way of support from the University of Northampton but we need to raise at least a further £5,000 to take things to the next level and make this show the best it can be. Our initial tour will consist of 6 performances around Northamptonshire. 
However putting on a tour isn’t cheap so we need your help to increase production values, hire venues, hire rehearsal space, pay actors and not forgetting marketing. Any money we then make from ticket sales will be ploughed back into the show so that further performances can take place. We have many brilliant perks available to you including tickets to the show, sponsor a sword (we really need good swords) and even attending a rehearsal.

Risks & Challenges
The good news is, the show will definitely be going ahead! So you may be thinking "Why do you need another £5000?" It's simple; to increase quality, outreach and impact! Now in order to do this we need a bigger budget, which is where this crowd-funding campaign comes in.  The bigger the budget, the better the show. The better the show, the greater the reach. The greater the reach, the bigger the impact. We are able to produce the show to the same level that we did before with the original tour.  But in order to for us to take things to that next level and have as great an impact as possible, your support is going to be crucial.


Other Ways You Can Help

No matter how big or small your contribution is its going towards an exciting project that can have such a positive impact on the world. If you can’t contribute then please share online (Indiegogo have some nice sharing tools that you can use) and tell your friends to help us make this show as good as we know it can be. So one last time, please help us make this happen.

story:
From the creator of the hit TV series True Blood, Six Feet under and Oscar Award winning feature film American Beauty, comes a play written by Alan Ball, "5 Women Wearing The Same Dress". 

Join us at one of Toronto's newest venues "The Aztec" (formerly Big Picture Cinema) in bringing Alan Ball's hilarious comedy to life. Directed by Adam Bailey, this award winning cast have graced web, film, TV and theatre sets across the country and Australia.

They all came together by true coincidence - a chance meeting in a dog park, a babysitting interview, comedy fundraiser, "you gotta meet this guy", an ex co-worker's wife from Whitby and the most obscure of all - an acting class. The chemistry this cast has is palpable and funny. This is one show not to be missed! 

Thank you for supporting our production, and yes, every little bit helps. A portion of all ticket sales will be going to the Canadian Cancer Society and Kensington Hospice. We want to honour a true artist and director, he inspired us to continue producing this play even though he would not be here to see the final product. Just because someone is gone, doesn't mean their story is.
In loving memory of Dori Elhachem.

story:
Blurb for the Burbs:

The Empty Room Collective has been producing theatre in Toronto since 2010, we are excited to be back again this November with an original Canadian play by Michal Grzejszczak.

Boys From The Burbs is a comedic coming-of-age story that follows a group of friends growing up in the suburbs. We see their adolescent hopes and dreams awaken, as they begin to discover, and long for the world outside of their neighbourhood.

We are mounting a full production of BFTB in Toronto, opening on November 19th. With your help we will lift this bright and hopeful piece of theatre up  from the page and onto the stage, giving it the production it deserves.


Lunch Money...

Theatre is hard. Putting on a play is a lot like back to school shopping for a 7th grader. First you have to clothe them, and we know how picky they can be (costumes: $600), then you have to buy them all their knapsacks and school supplies (props $400), send them off with lunch money (concessions: $250), and then when they get home you need somewhere to put them (rehearsal space: $1600), their own room with a desk lamp for homework (lighting: $700), and somewhere to practice their bassoon – or whatever – (sound: $400), and that's all assuming he or she actually behaves (insurance: $500). Oh yeah, then you've got to pay taxes to make sure there's a school to send them off to in the first place (venue rental: $3300).
Parents, we sympathize.
We're asking for $3000, about a third of our budgeted costs, and in return we have tons of perks to tempt you with, from tickets to the show and opening night party, to personalized videos of the producing team playing our your outrageous truth or dare challenges!

Extra Curricular

We know it's sometimes difficult to help out as much as you'd like, that's why we need people to help out by spreading the word too – the more shares we get on Facebook and Twitter, the better chance we have to meet our goals and water the seeds of a new generation of Canadian theatre!


Video filmed and edited by our friend Nicholas Porteous. Check out more of his excellent work here!

story:
The Reverse Is Also True. 

Novus theatre bring you The Reverse Is Also True. After a successful R & D at the Bed Pop Arts Centre in August 2014, the next stage of this exciting new work.

Written by Stephen May and Mark Illis, and directed by Sam Turton, the piece will be embarking on a national tour in November 2015. 

The Reverse Is Also True has been developed by Novus with funding from Arts Council England and support from Cambridge Junction. However, we still need help funding the final stages of the project. 


What We Need...

We are looking for £1000 to cover rehearsal space and technical elements of the project. 

£450: Rehearsal space - In order to create the show, we need to hire rehearsal space. We have had some space generously donated, however, we still need to fund the rest of the rehearsal process. 

£550: Technical support - The show has several specific technical elements which are used throughout the performance. We will be using projection throughout which can be a very expensive process. We also have to provide our own technician to man the equipment. 

What You Get...

For £5 you will get shout outs and thank yous on social media and our website. 
For £10 you will get shout outs and thank yous on social media and our website. You will also receive a limited edition of the script for The Reverse Is Also True containing information about the show, rehearsal photos and a copy of the script. 
For £25 you will get shout outs and thank yous on social media and our website, a limited edition of the script for The Reverse Is Also True and a A3 poster for the show as well as a thank you pack with information, interviews and photos from the rehearsal process.
For £40 you will receive 2 free tickets for the show at a venue of your choice, plus all other incentives. 
For £100+ you will receive all incentives listed about AND you will receive a production credit for the show, meaning you are officially part of the process. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute thats fine, you can still help us reach our goal! You can share and tell other people about the work we are doing with the show, buy tickets or publicise the show! 

Thank you for reading.

story:
SNA Educa es una corporación sin fines de lucro que administra 20 establecimientos educacionales técnico profesional a lo largo de Chile, desde Iquique hasta Coyhaique. Atiende a 10. 000 niños y niñas de sectores rurales manera gratuita, con altos estándares de calidad y dignidad. Estos niños provienes de sectores con elevados índices de vulnerabilidad social pero de gran diversidad étnica y riqueza cultural.

Con el objeto de preservar las raíces culturales y ancestrales de nuestra comunidad escolar, ofrecer a los alumnos un espacio de difusión del arte e identidad nacional, así como un espacio de encuentro entre jóvenes de orígenes geográficos y culturales diversos, desde hace dos años, la corporación organiza una muestra folclórica, en la cual participan los grupos de baile de los establecimientos educacionales de la Red SNA Educa. Este evento logra congregar a 120 estudiantes provenientes de todo Chile en representación de sus establecimiento, al rededor de 30 colaboradores educacionales, padres, apoderados, autoridades locales, miembros de la comunidad local e invitados especiales.

En la tercera versión de este evento, programada para el mes de noviembre 2015, hemos logrado, con mucho esfuerzo comprometer un teatro excepcional, con capacidad para 1000 asistentes,  equipos de iluminaria y sonido del más alto nivel, sin embargo nuestros esfuerzos para financiar el arriendo del teatro, equipamiento, vestuario, difusión, traslado de alumnos desde regiones, alimentación, servicios de alojamiento, no han sido suficientes.

Necesitamos dinero para pagar por los servicios antes mencionados y dar el impulso de profesionalismo y excelencia  que este evento y estos jóvenes ameritan. El monto que se ha establecido como meta solo representa los costos asociados a pagos por servicios a terceros, ya que las horas de trabajo durante ensayos, diseño y creatividad de las puestas en escena  y organización forma parte de los esfuerzos colaborativos de los alumnos y trabajadores de la Red SNA Educa.

Nuestros colaboradores y benefactores  podrán tener la satisfacción de ser motores que impulsan experiencias de vida en niños y niñas tremendamente talentosos, que buscan mirar al mundo y sus oportunidades con esperanza y optimismo y que a su vez, el mundo reconozca y valore sus talentos y sus orígenes. Aquellos que lo deseen podran además disfrutar del espectaculo junto a un acompañante en la ciudad de Santiago. 

Todos lo recaudado será respaldado por boletas y facturas de servcios a terceros en el marco de esta actividad. 

  El impacto

En un mundo globalizado y tecnologizado, crear valor en las persona, sus habilidades artísticas y orígenes culturales permiten a estos jóvenes  de origen rural  plantearse hacia el mundo con auto respeto, dignidad y visión de emprendimiento, todo esto colabora enormemente a su desarrollo educacional y psicosocial, lo cual promueve su crecimiento y a romper circulos de pobreza y vulnerabilidad.

Este evento esta destinado a cambiar la visión de vida de los que participan en cualquiera de sus ámbitos, ya sea como artista, colaborador, asistente  o benefactor,  ya que en él se conjugarán la educación, la cultura, el patrimonio étnico, la solidadridad y la mágia de la puesta en escena.

Riesgos y desafíos

Ningún evento de este nivel esta exento de riesgos, ya que involucra a un gran equipo humano y depende de  algunos servicios de terceros  que sin duda se pueden escapar en parte del control de la organización, sin embargo tenemos la experiencia organizacional exitosa, aunque en menor escala, de dos eventos anteriores de muestra folclórica, y una institución con colaboradores tremendamente comprometido y dispuesto a solucionar cada obstaculo que se presente, con mucho profesionalismo y dedicación. 

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Sabemos que hay personas que aún cuando lo desearían, no pueden colaborar con recursos económicos, sin embargo agradeceremos enormemente difundir este proyecto de recaudación utilizando las herramientas dispuestas por Indiegogo.
story_txt:
SNA Educa es una corporación sin fines de lucro que administra 20 establecimientos educacionales técnico profesional a lo largo de Chile, desde Iquique hasta Coyhaique. Atiende a 10. 000 niños y niñas de sectores rurales manera gratuita, con altos estándares de calidad y dignidad. Estos niños provienes de sectores con elevados índices de vulnerabilidad social pero de gran diversidad étnica y riqueza cultural. 
Con el objeto de preservar las raíces culturales y ancestrales de nuestra comunidad escolar, ofrecer a los alumnos un espacio de difusión del arte e identidad nacional, así como un espacio de encuentro entre jóvenes de orígenes geográficos y culturales diversos, desde hace dos años, la corporación organiza una muestra folclórica, en la cual participan los grupos de baile de los establecimientos educacionales de la Red SNA Educa. Este evento logra congregar a 120 estudiantes provenientes de todo Chile en representación de sus establecimiento, al rededor de 30 colaboradores educacionales, padres, apoderados, autoridades locales, miembros de la comunidad local e invitados especiales.
En la tercera versión de este evento, programada para el mes de noviembre 2015, hemos logrado, con mucho esfuerzo comprometer un teatro excepcional, con capacidad para 1000 asistentes,  equipos de iluminaria y sonido del más alto nivel, sin embargo nuestros esfuerzos para financiar el arriendo del teatro, equipamiento, vestuario, difusión, traslado de alumnos desde regiones, alimentación, servicios de alojamiento, no han sido suficientes.
Necesitamos dinero para pagar por los servicios antes mencionados y dar el impulso de profesionalismo y excelencia  que este evento y estos jóvenes ameritan. El monto que se ha establecido como meta solo representa los costos asociados a pagos por servicios a terceros, ya que las horas de trabajo durante ensayos, diseño y creatividad de las puestas en escena  y organización forma parte de los esfuerzos colaborativos de los alumnos y trabajadores de la Red SNA Educa.
Nuestros colaboradores y benefactores  podrán tener la satisfacción de ser motores que impulsan experiencias de vida en niños y niñas tremendamente talentosos, que buscan mirar al mundo y sus oportunidades con esperanza y optimismo y que a su vez, el mundo reconozca y valore sus talentos y sus orígenes. Aquellos que lo deseen podran además disfrutar del espectaculo junto a un acompañante en la ciudad de Santiago.  
Todos lo recaudado será respaldado por boletas y facturas de servcios a terceros en el marco de esta actividad. 
  El impacto En un mundo globalizado y tecnologizado, crear valor en las persona, sus habilidades artísticas y orígenes culturales permiten a estos jóvenes  de origen rural  plantearse hacia el mundo con auto respeto, dignidad y visión de emprendimiento, todo esto colabora enormemente a su desarrollo educacional y psicosocial, lo cual promueve su crecimiento y a romper circulos de pobreza y vulnerabilidad.
Este evento esta destinado a cambiar la visión de vida de los que participan en cualquiera de sus ámbitos, ya sea como artista, colaborador, asistente  o benefactor,  ya que en él se conjugarán la educación, la cultura, el patrimonio étnico, la solidadridad y la mágia de la puesta en escena.
Riesgos y desafíos
  Ningún evento de este nivel esta exento de riesgos, ya que involucra a un gran equipo humano y depende de  algunos servicios de terceros  que sin duda se pueden escapar en parte del control de la organización, sin embargo tenemos la experiencia organizacional exitosa, aunque en menor escala, de dos eventos anteriores de muestra folclórica, y una institución con colaboradores tremendamente comprometido y dispuesto a solucionar cada obstaculo que se presente, con mucho profesionalismo y dedicación. 
Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar 
 Sabemos que hay personas que aún cuando lo desearían, no pueden colaborar con recursos económicos, sin embargo agradeceremos enormemente difundir este proyecto de recaudación utilizando las herramientas dispuestas por Indiegogo.

story:
italytime, a ‘daughter’ of Teatromania, is an international not-for-profit platform conceived by Vittorio Capotorto and Francesco Pagano, and launched in December 2013, with the endorsement of world-known writers Dacia Maraini and Roberto Saviano. 

Teatromania, the ‘mother’ not-for-profit organization of italytime – 501(c)(3) – was created in 1999 and is registered in the New York State.


www.facebook.com/italytime


Our MISSION: share with the world the irresistible beauty of NEW Italian cultural experiences.


More specifically, these are our OBJECTIVES:

·  To give new artists the chance to create and re-invent Italian arts, design & culture

·  To allow kids and teens to nurture their imagination & social engagement

·  To include everyone from the most diverse background to exchange contemporary Italian experiences


Because of the above mentioned goals, we want to create the first permanent Italian Cultural Center in NYC, where the best of Italian Theater and the power of live performances will help especially the young to nurture their dreams, discover their identity and build a better world.


In 2015 we have finally found a location. The italytime Theater is located in Manhattan: 25B Carmine Street - NEW YORK, NY 10014. It is in need of some renovation work. Help us bring this great NYC Theater to its new life!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2W19k4qRip0


What will we do with your help?

1. The absolute priority is the renovation of our new italytime Theater.

We will give back to NYC and the global community not only a physical Theater, but an open space, where people can meet & talk about the Arts, Theater, Italy and much more. It is going to be a true ‘Cultural Center’ at the service of people of all ages, backgrounds and budgets. A stage, a shelter, a springboard for new dreams, this is the most precious gift to a community that usually forgets the value of collective experiences.

This is the power of a Theater!


2. We will set up an organization.

We need structure, without losing the original spirit. Team Members are and will always be artists, who share italytime’s mission & values. This core Team will be a driving force of joy within the local community and within the broader global, virtual community. Italytime will create a unit of ambassadors of the Arts, ready to educate and at the same time to learn with audiences and with the kids, to create a more imaginative community. 

This is the power of people of faith & passion!


3. We will give voice to new artists & spread the love of the Arts among the young.

This movement will showcase new work and transform both performers and audiences via the power of live experiences, across multiple artistic disciplines. We will show true life & dramas, in new ways, unseen in NYC and anywhere else.

We will offer workshops that educate, build social identities and stimulate creativity, without the need to align to one single standard of individual development.

This is the tremendous power of slices of true life, tasted on stage!


How can you help?


1. Donate to this campaign

2. Spread the word within your network on Facebook, Twitter, Linkedin, etc...

3. Follow us on www.facebook.com/italytime and www.italytime.org

4. Join us if you want to do some pro-bono work in NYC! Help us help the young and the arts!

5. Come see our shows in 2015 and 2016! We publish all our upcoming shows on www.facebook.com/italytime 

6. And, just love! Love the arts! Love Theater! And, love Italy!


Your friends at italytime, NYC

story:
A Dream Dance Center with Dream Dance Floors

Downtown Dance & Movement (DDM) is the hottest new 7800 square foot dance center in LA.  Opening October 5th, 2015 near Staples Center and LA Live, it features the widest variety of dance and dance fitness classes available.  In addition, we have a 2700 square foot performance space for shows/dance events and all types of artistic and creative performances. DDM is founded by longtime dance teacher and organizer Linda Valentino, along with her creative business partner Alle Ghadban.  Master dance floor builder David Sukonick is building us the best "sprung" dance floors of any dance studio in Los Angeles--every dancer's dream!   Sprung floors mean real comfort for any kind of dance.  These floors prevent leg and foot pain, protect against injury and give you hours and hours of comfortable dance time. Whether you're dancing ballet or modern on our sprung Marley floor or doing tap, social dance or dance fitness on our sprung maple floors, you'll feel like you're dancing on a cloud!

What We Need & What You Get

First - EVERY LITTLE BIT HELPS.  We are spending $80,000 on our dream dance floors. We bought the best. We would love your help. Whatever your level of contribution, we have a gift to thank you for your generosity.
  • $25--1 free dance or yoga class
  • $50--2 free dance or yoga classes
  • $100--3 free dance or yoga classes
  • $250--one 10-class dance or yoga pass
  • $500--two 10-class dance or yoga passes
  • $1,000--three 10-class dance or yoga passes
  • $2,000--five 10-class dance or yoga passes
  • $5,000-- a One Year VIP Pass to all classes and dance events at Downtown Dance & Movement!
  • $10,000--a Lifetime VIP Pass to all classes and dance events at Downtown Dance & Movement!
  • You can gift some or all of your free classes to a friend or family member!
  • Everything we raise will go to pay for our dance floors, even if we don't raise our target amount.

How Your Contribution Will Help

Have you ever come home from a few hours of dancing  with your entire body aching? The quality of a dance floor affects all types of dance. When a floor is too hard, dancers get very tired, very fast. The primary reason injuries occur, is fatigue.  Dancers' technique can suffer too, because they start to move in ways that "protect" themselves from pain but in the long-run do great damage to their bodies. Even worse, serious injuries can be caused by bad dance flooring. With our top quality dance floors by master builder David Sukonick, you'll be able to dance for hours, without the suffering.  Injuries will be drastically reduced.  Bad falls will be absorbed over a large area and long term injuries, such as those to joints sustained from years of dancing and teaching on hard surfaces, will be all but eliminated. Dancers with slight injuries can work through them on these floors and those with more severe injuries can rehabilitate much faster. These floors will increase the ability to safely dance, teach and rehearse for longer periods of time without fatigue.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Even if you can't contribute, you can still help:

    • Forward the link to this Indiegogo campaign to all your dance friends!
    • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share this campaign on Facebook and other social media!

    Thank you!

story:
Knock-Knock. Who's there? Opportunity.

Hey! our names are Emily (Seymour and Cupples).  We are two dedicated theatre students who met in our first year of college and found a mutual love for comedy.  We both have training in improvisation and stand-up comedy and are looking to further our experience in the industry.  We believe that Second City in Chicago would be the best because of its one month intensive that focuses on improvisation and sketch writing. 

Emily Seymour has been improvising at The Loose Moose Theatre Company in Calgary, Alberta for 3 years.  She has also been performing stand-up comedy around Calgary in several venues.  She was accepted to Humber College in Toronto for Stand-up Comedy Writing and Performance, but chose to return to Red Deer College to complete her diploma and to create the college’s improvisation team, Moose Chuckles.  

Emily Cupples has five years of improvisation under her belt.  She has worked with many teams, including Moose Chuckles and Red Deer's sketch comedy troupe Against the Wall Theatre.  She has been writing sketches for the past two years and has had many of them performed.

Comedy is important to both of us because it is an effective way to bring the audience and performers together.  We hope to increase our level of knowledge so that we can create new work that will excite our audiences.  If you’re not laughing, you should be about to!  

With the support of our contributors we will be able to cover tuition, travel and living expenses during the month long intensive.  However, if we do not reach our complete goal we will put any money we do make towards cost of flights and will continue fundraising to support the remaining.

Going to Second City will allow us to learn new techniques in writing and improvisation.  We are both graduating from the Theatre Performance and Creation program this coming May and have the opportunity to develop our skills internationally.  We hope in doing so we will be able to apply the knowledge we learn to our own company in Alberta, Canada. 

With our shared experience in improv comedy we have been able to develop a strong connection both with each other and our teams. The challenges that come from our pursuit will be faced with confidence and passion for our careers.

Thank you so much for your support this far in our journey.  We hope that you will be so kind as to share our campaign and spread the word.  Please remember: Laughter is the best medicine:)

story:
IF YOU WOULD LIKE TO CONTRIBUTE AFTER THIS CAMPAIGN IS CLOSED PLEASE GIVE DIRECTLY TO FRACTURED ATLAS:

https://www.fracturedatlas.org/site/fiscal/profile?id=12439

THANK YOU!

JESSE

__________


Meta-Phys Ed. is a multi-disiplinary performance collaborative that explores the inseparable relationship between art and spirituality.

This July their new work, Karaoke Bacchae, written and directed by Jesse Freedman, will premier at the New Ohio Ice Factory festival in New York City.

Karaoke Bacchae is a dance theater adaptation of the Euripides’ tragedy, The Bacchae, imagined in a sports bar on karaoke night during the Stanley Cup. Karaoke is canceled to watch the game. The god Dionysus takes the human form of Iggy Pop and leads a horde of drunken sorority girls and cocktail waitress’ into a battle of submission for control of the karaoke machine, against the bars sado-masochistic management. Sung and shouted under the ultimate karaoke playlist, driven by dance and features text from Drunk J. Crew, deranged sorority girl email, and a sexually frustrated drunken high school english teacher.

July 22-25 2015

For More information on the the ICE FACTORY 2015, or to purchase tickets: <a href="http://www.icefactory.org/#!karaoke-bacchae/c1v9t" target="_blank">http://www.icefactory.org/#!karaoke-bacchae/c1v...>

ICE FACTORY is an OBIE Award-winning summer festival of new work.

Every summer The New Ohio Theater invites the most exciting downtown companies to present their latest projects in an environment of generosity, dialogue, and inspiration. Ice Factory is a place where artists can take risks, try out new ideas, and bring their projects to a new level.

Plays introduced in Ice Factory have gone on to garner Drama Desk nominations, OBIE Awards, Audience First Awards in Edinburgh, Off-Broadway productions, commercial runs, and national and international tours.

Funding for this project will go towards:

-Artist fees!!!!

-Set and costume pieces.

-Renting a really nice projector

PROJECT HISTORY:

Karaoke Bacchae's development began at Sarah Lawrence College in the MFA Theater Practicum.

In October 2014 a concert reading of the complete script was presented at La Mama Club, produced by Eugene Lange Colleges "Alumnight," curated by Zishan Urgulu.
