story:
Little Did Productions...


...is dedicated to creating innovative and exemplary puppet-based theater for audiences of all ages.

Since 2007, Little Did has been utilizing puppetry and music to express complex and imaginative themes through tales that are timeless and accessible to any audience. From our New York City debut A Silly Silverstein Show at FringeJR 2009 to 2014's Ramayana in Madison Square Park, LDP has been making their mark on the city's puppet community with performances at the Bushwick Starr, St. Ann's Warehouse, and Standard ToyKraft. Reviewers have called the work "clever," "snappy" and "visually scintillating," accompanied by original music that is "haunting and beautiful."

These experiments in puppetry, music and theater have led us here, to SOLINA.

SOLINA is a full-length, all-original show told through diverse styles of puppetry and music. Premiering at the New York International Fringe Festival in August 2015, SOLINA is the story of young girl who awakens to Rooster’s call and discovers Sun is missing and everyone she loves is trapped in a deep sleep, peacefully unaware. She ventures into the darkness to speak to the creatures of the night, encountering false trails, riddles, and dangerous characters on a quest to find Sun and save the world from darkness. This original hybrid multimedia puppet opera draws from myths, techniques, and musics from a variety of cultures to resonate as something rooted in the familiar, yet never before seen.

Puppetry is an expensive art form, and SOLINA is our most ambitious show to date. Our vision is expansive, including moving set pieces, glowing puppet eyes and live electronic music. Generosity from art lovers like you is simply the only thing that will make it possible. In the sidebar you can see the rewards that we're offering to our donors, including physical, handmade goods and exclusive digital content. We hope that you'll consider becoming part of the Little Did family and help us Little Do It.

A Well-Defined Fiscal Plan...


...is essential to any serious art project.

We are proud and honored to be partially supported by public funds from the Manhattan Community Arts Fund, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and administered by Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. We've also been awarded the 2015 Hot Time in the Old City residency for projects in development by our friends over at Standard ToyKraft!

We're also forever thankful to an anonymous donor who has generously offered to match any funds raised up to $3,000!

This is why our goal for this campaign is $3,000. If we can raise this much from a dedicated and caring team of fans, it will be matched and added to the funds that we can/have raised through grants. This puts us very close to our budget goal, but not quite there. Any additional funds raised will still go directly into the show, most notably to provide stipends for our tireless and talented cast and crew.

Here are our budget broad strokes:

Expenses:

Rehearsal Space Rental: $800

Puppet Materials: $2,507 
Set Materials: $1,450
Costumes: $350 
Makeup: $150 
Travel/Transportation: $698 
Technical Expenses: $700
Printing/Publicity: $950
Fringe/Fractured Atlas Fees: $975
Total without stipends: $8,580


Modest Stipends for all Designers and Performers:  $4,670
Total: $13,250


Income:

"Drinking with Puppets" Fundraiser 2014: $410
MCAF Grant: $2,690
Total secured income: $3,100

Indiegogo Campaign at Goal: $3,000
Matching Donation: $3,000
Total income with Indiegogo goal met: $9,100

Indiegogo Campaign at Reach Goal: $5,150
Matching Donation: $3,000
Total with Indiegogo campaign Reach goal met: $11,250

Projected Ticket Sales: $2,000
Total income with Indiegogo campaign Reach goal and projected ticket sales: $13,250 (BALANCED BUDGET!)

We are happy to discuss the details of our budget with any potential donors if you want to reach out to us at littledidproductions@gmail.com. The basic formula is this:

By helping us to get to our Goal of $3,000, you maximize our potential income from private donors

By helping us to get to our Reach Goal of $5,150, you maximize our potential to balance our budget after ticket sales

Anything raised beyond our Reach Goal will go to further performances of SOLINA

Your Donation...


...would make you a member of the Little Did team, a Giving Tree, and a dear friend.

Our agreement with our fiscal sponsor, Fractured Atlas, makes it so that the donations that go through this campaign will be tax-deductible (above the cost of your rewards) because they will go directly to this project, SOLINA. We will not use any part of it on administrative costs or anything not directly related to the creation of this show, a journey story that will empower children, inspire audiences, and invigorate theater, puppetry and music communities in New York and beyond.

Let's be Friends...

If you cannot donate (or even if you can), please consider sharing on your social media outlets! Our Instagram and Twitter handles are @littledidprod and you can find us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/LittleDidProductions. Please "Like" and "Follow" us for updates that include sneak peeks of the digital content being offered as rewards, short films and #eyebombs that we've been leaving around the city, slowly turning our community into a giant puppet!

Both musically, and visually, SOLINA takes our greatest skills and pushes them to the limit. Although kid-friendly, it is a twisted and unconventional fantasy intended for all audiences. The story’s main theme challenges the antiquated concepts of “good” and “evil” too often oversimplified in children’s theatre. In SOLINA, like in life, all characters possess both good qualities and evil qualities, and our strong, female protagonist learns this as she ventures out on her own for the first time. It’s a lesson essential to children, but as Little Did goes on this journey to write, build and fund our first fully original full-length show in New York City, we are learning just how vital and ageless it is.
story_txt:
Little Did Productions...

...is dedicated to creating innovative and exemplary puppet-based theater for audiences of all ages.

Since 2007, Little Did has been utilizing puppetry and music to express complex and imaginative themes through tales that are timeless and accessible to any audience. From our New York City debut A Silly Silverstein Show at FringeJR 2009 to 2014's Ramayana in Madison Square Park, LDP has been making their mark on the city's puppet community with performances at the Bushwick Starr, St. Ann's Warehouse, and Standard ToyKraft. Reviewers have called the work "clever," "snappy" and "visually scintillating," accompanied by original music that is "haunting and beautiful."


These experiments in puppetry, music and theater have led us here, to SOLINA.


SOLINA is a full-length, all-original show told through diverse styles of puppetry and music. Premiering at the New York International Fringe Festival in August 2015, SOLINA is the story of young girl who awakens to Rooster’s call and discovers Sun is missing and everyone she loves is trapped in a deep sleep, peacefully unaware. She ventures into the darkness to speak to the creatures of the night, encountering false trails, riddles, and dangerous characters on a quest to find Sun and save the world from darkness. This original hybrid multimedia puppet opera draws from myths, techniques, and musics from a variety of cultures to resonate as something rooted in the familiar, yet never before seen.


Puppetry is an expensive art form, and SOLINA is our most ambitious show to date. Our vision is expansive, including moving set pieces, glowing puppet eyes and live electronic music. Generosity from art lovers like you is simply the only thing that will make it possible. In the sidebar you can see the rewards that we're offering to our donors, including physical, handmade goods and exclusive digital content. We hope that you'll consider becoming part of the Little Did family and help us Little Do It.
   A Well-Defined Fiscal Plan...

...is essential to any serious art project.

We are proud and honored to be partially supported by public funds from the Manhattan Community Arts Fund, supported by the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs in partnership with the City Council and administered by Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. We've also been awarded the 2015 Hot Time in the Old City residency for projects in development by our friends over at Standard ToyKraft!


We're also forever thankful to an anonymous donor who has generously offered to match any funds raised up to $3,000!


This is why our goal for this campaign is $3,000. If we can raise this much from a dedicated and caring team of fans, it will be matched and added to the funds that we can/have raised through grants. This puts us very close to our budget goal, but not quite there. Any additional funds raised will still go directly into the show, most notably to provide stipends for our tireless and talented cast and crew.

story:
Join the $11 for 11 Campaign!

Commonwealth Classic Theatre Company is celebrating its PRIME (11 being a prime..and pretty magical number....) This summer is our 11th season of bringing great theatre to the Greater Philadelphia region.  

We're especially excited this season, to be bringing you William Shakespeare's THE TEMPEST (featuring former RSC actor, David Howey as Prospero) and the World Premiere of RAGE OF ACHILLES by Paul Parente, local playwright and company member.  It's a season of revenge and redemption...not to be missed!

Where do you come in?

We're asking for just a little bit of support - one dollar for every season we've shared with you.  $11 for 11!

(We've listed some suggested amounts, but indiegogo will let you donate any amount you'd like...so clean the change out of those couch cushions!)

What will we do with $11?

Obviously we're hoping for more than one donor... Combined, each of your $11 donations will go toward production costs for our Free Theatre in the Parks production of THE TEMPEST and for the World Premiere of RAGE OF ACHILLES. Have you the seen the cost of magical staffs and demi-god shields lately?  (Have we mentioned how excited we are about this season?)

    Don't forget to come out and see us!!!

    In July, come see THE TEMPEST as it storms through 14 area parks.  Click here for a full schedule of performances.

    August brings the World Premiere of RAGE OF ACHILLES at the Black Box Theatre at Drexel University's URBN Annex.  Click here for show times and tickets.

    Please come see us so we can thank you in person!

story:
Short Summary

There is not enough theatre in Toronto to satisfy the needs of the performers who live there and many of the opportunities that do present themselves aren't paying  performers for their time. My name is Naomi, and I am a Toronto based actor who has experienced the theatre draught first hand.

I have made it my goal to start a company that helps passionate theatre creators mount their shows while making it possible to pay everyone for their work. There are so many people who want to create theatre, so let's tap into that resource and get more works, and more jobs happening!

What We Need & What You Get


As I stated before, there are not enough performance opportunities to fulfill the demand that actors present, but it is impossible to create your own work because everything is so expensive. I made a basic breakdown of production costs, which includes getting the rights, theatre rental, technician, director, stage manager payment, rehearsal space, costumes, advertisement, and a base fee for the actors, and discovered that to run a show for two weeks costs approximately 6000. My goal with this campaign is to raise that 6000 (or more, of course,) so that through Stop the Bull people who have the drive to put on a show will finally have the means!

I ask each of you to consider: have you ever seen a show that you loved and would like to see remounted? Have you ever dreamed of putting on a show? Do you think being paid for your work is a good thing? Do you know any struggling artists? Do you have 20 dollars that you could donate  in order to help the Canadian theatre scene to become a more vibrant one? Any little bit is a huge help to my cause. If you really can't even afford 20 dollars, I understand, I've been there, and passing on the word about this campaign can be a big help too. And don't forget our fun incentives! You can get a season pass to Stop the Bull's first season, a Shakespearean sonnet or a song performed either live or on film (location depending) by one of our talented board members, a shout out for your cause or campaign, and, of course, your name broadcasted all over the place as one of our generous supporters. 
Thanks for your support in my mission to create! I want Stop the Bull's inaugural show to take place in late September, so I need the funds around the beginning of the month to get everything booked down. The first show of the season will be my own play, It's Kind of a Love Story, which premiered in the 2014 Toronto Fringe. It has been reworked, and I have found a stellar cast and crew who are willing to come on board... Now we just need the dollar billz! Let's make it rain folks, and make theatre creation an accessible option without breaking the bank!

The Impact

The arts are always a smart thing to invest in. They really bring the community together, and make it a thriving, happy one. By investing in my artistic project, you are supporting young artists who will shape the future art scene in Toronto. By helping us out now, you are helping to develop a business-smart, driven population of artists who will continue to grow and  change their community in ways that couldn't be achieved if we don't explore that business sense now. There is so much drive and innovation among young performers, and we can use that to make the future of Canadian theatre a bright one. I have successfully produced my show, It's Kind of a Love Story, in the past, and during that process I learned a lot of the skills  it takes going into a show. This time will only go more smoothly than the last, and hopefully as Stop the Bull continues to grow as the community's mutual production fund, it will become increasingly lucrative, and a more successful endeavour.

Risks & Challenges

Never fear- your investment in the arts is not going to just disappear after one production. I will be asking each show that I help produce to run at least one fundraiser before opening, to recoup some of the costs prior to ticket sales. There will be time invested in marketing to make sure the show has targeted its market audience, and ticket sales should be able to at least make up the difference and ideally also pull in a profit, which will be divided up among the performers as a profit split. I will ask that the profits be split one extra way, and that the production fund receives that cut of the proceeds, so our company can continue to grow and eventually pay their performers per hour, as they rightfully should be.

I will be accepting show proposals from each interested party and meeting with them one on one to discuss their plans for success. The last thing I want is for my efforts to go to waste before they have even begun, and I want to ensure that I am supporting people who are willing to put in the effort to create a wonderful show that will break even.

Other Ways You Can Help

Obviously financial help is a big part of this campaign, but there are so many ways that you can help Stop the Bull become a thriving business. Pass on the word to your wealthier friends, share our campaign on your Facebook page, Twitter account, etc., come out and see our shows once the company has launched, or donate your time as an usher or box office person! We appreciate any and every contribution you are willing to make, and I hope that you will take the time to support the young innovative community,

story:
Who we are:

LightBox Theatre Company is a non-profit theatre company committed to providing quality, professional live entertainment, for Turlock’s children and youth. Through public and school based performances we seek to provide opportunities for all of our community’s youth to be entertained, enlightened, and inspired. We strive to be one of the first steps in instilling a life long love of the arts for the members of our community. 

We currently produce two shows, one in the fall and one in the spring. Our first production in October 2015 will be  a stage adaptation of the well-known children's book Bunnicula.  By producing stage adaptations of popular children’s literature we are able to integrate our programming with the curriculum of K-12 educators. By partnering with local civic organizations, such as the Carnegie Arts Center, we provide affordable opportunities for educators to introduce their students to the stories they have been reading in class in a new way -- through live performance. When moving beyond published stories, we seek collaboration with local cultural groups to develop new works that highlight and celebrate the favorite stories or legends from our community’s diverse population.

LightBox Theatre Company is excited about its role in the lives and imaginations of Turlock’s youth. As we grow, we envision becoming a larger fixture in our community, participating in civic events, and forming lasting partnerships with educators and local businesses. We are a small company with big dreams, not just for ourselves but for our community as well. Come grow with us!

What Your Donation Provides:

The budget for the two-play season is a modest one of $16,000. We anticipate that future budgets will increase with the support of corporate sponsors and private donations. We are budgeting for 14 performances of each play; 8 public weekend performances and 6 school performances (offered at no charge to  participating classes).

The budget includes:
  • stipends for actors and technical personnel 
  • royalties for two productions
  • printed materials
  • sets and costumes
  • venue costs

Proceeds from ticket sales of the public performances will be used to cover any additional expenses and to ensure a fund for the next year's schedule.

How Your Donation is Recognized:

As a donor, your name will appear in the programs for both plays this season and will be acknowledged on our website. Additionally, every donor will receive a special letter from a student from a local school expressing their appreciation.

Depending on the amount of your contribution, you will also join the LightBox Circle as a member. Please see our Donation page on our website for information on the giving levels and benefits.

Or, you can also choose to Select A Perk to support our campaign:

  • Donors who contribute $25 will receive a LightBox Theatre Company decal
  • Donors who contribute $100 will also receive a LightBox Theatre Company T-Shirt, signed by the Co-Founders
  • Donors who contribute $250 will receive a limited edition, promotional poster of our inaugural production of Bunnicula, signed by the entire cast
  • Donors who contribute $500 will receive a special edition wall plaque showing our appreciation

While we await the receipt of our own 501(c)3 status, all donations are being channeled through our not-for-profit partner, The Carnegie Arts Center.  All donations are tax deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Feel Good About Contributing:

LightBox Theatre Co. was born out of a desire to create a professional non-profit resident theater company for young audiences that would benefit Turlock and its surrounding communities. Opportunities for family-friendly performances are few in the Central Valley, but they are a must for instilling in young people the value of the arts.

School performances  allow us to serve audiences that may never have had the chance to see live theatre. Low-income students and their families will attend our shows at no cost, opening up a world of imagination and experience.

More than just a local community theatre, we are a professional company that provides paid opportunities for designers, directors, actors, and technicians to produce high-quality entertainment. In the future, we hope to create an internship program for emerging artists that are pursuing a professional career in theatre or theatre education to ensure that our company is continually integrating new ideas and perspectives as well as contributing to our field at large.

Share:

Help us get this new initiative off the ground and onto the stage!

  • Share this campaign with your family and friends.
  • Join us in October for Bunnicula and share in the fun.

story:
Welcome to our page and thank you for taking the time to find out more about our project!

We are NMT Automatics and we are seeking support for our new show Dido and Aeneas; an adaptation of Virgil’s ‘Book Four’ of The Aeneid.  It will fuse dance, theatre, and a soundtrack that combines Purcell’s original music with a new electric, industrial soundscape. 

The first stage of which is a two week Research and Development period, taking place in September, which will include active engagement and participation with Redbridge and Deptford community youth, culminating in a public and industry showcase.

Via a contemporary retelling of this ancient story, we aim to explore cultural intolerance in the 21st century: the conflict between old morals and current attitudes. 

Ultimately, we wish to produce a piece that not only is artistically great but also benefits the communities that we are working in.

You can be a part of this!

Research & Development:

Set within a period of industrial change, we will experiment with object manipulation, using raw materials to create a visually dynamic performance space and an arresting soundscape. This will be the first time Purcell’s opera has been juxtaposed with a modern metallic score specifically to create a theatrical soundtrack. 

We will be working with four actors and two youth groups - Redbridge Youth theatre (South Woodford) and Uncover Youth (Deptford) - who by participating in three workshops and performing with us in the showcase will directly impact on the artistic quality, diversity of ideas and accessibility of the piece, and also provide the opportunity for personal development on their behalf. We aim to find a home for a January production that would not only be informed by the communities within which we have worked, but also have them performing within it. 

“Aeneas, the Trojan hero, is shipwrecked on the enemy shore of Carthage. Brought to the widowed Queen Dido, he woos her with stories of war and hardship. On a dark and stormy night an evil spirit sends a message of intolerance and hatred to Aeneas, persuading him to leave Dido and continue his journey. When she hears of Aeneas’ plans, Dido is distraught and builds a great fire, secretly planning her own death.”

A Bit More About The Company:

NoMansTime Automatics updates classical texts giving them relevance to a modern audience, fusing dance and drama and taking music as a primary source of inspiration. Stylistically, the company uses corporeal, poetic and surrealist imagery through physical theatre and text-based storytelling. 

This will be the second full production that we have created following the the reformation of the company by Artistic Director Jonathan Young in 2014.

The first wasThe Orpheus Project: new writing inspired by the Orpheus myth and Kafka’s The Trial, using two performers, an original soundscape, and a unique physical style in a dystopian setting. 

Development began in January 2014, with a sharing critiqued by “Remotegoat:” ‘the sort of storytelling that should be encouraged in the arts’. With feedback, the show was re-worked for a month long Edinburgh run at C Too, achieving five stars from Broadway Baby: ‘A kill shot… bold and exciting’ and four stars from both The Stage ‘A visual statement’ and The Skinny  ‘The visuals and the story are brilliantly done’. Finally, it was selected and further refined for the So and So Arts Club Festival (London) in November. 

The Story So Far...

We have since begun work on this, our next project: Dido & Aeneas.

On consultation with an industry figure, we decided to begin the project with Research and Development which would not only benefit the quality of the production but would also put us in a better position when seeking funding from the Arts Council. 

As such a couple of months ago, we did a walking tour of appropriate theatres and community spaces around London, in order to seek space-in-kind and support for this R & D. We set up a number of meetings which brilliantly resulted in being offered space at three venues - The Redbridge Drama Centre, Greenwich Theatre and The Deptford Lounge. 

Once we had the venues with us we were then in a stronger position with our Arts Council bid which we immediately set about working on. Suffice to say the application took a lot of time and refinement to get it to where we were happy with! 

Unfortunately, the Arts Council in fact turned our initial bid down. However the feedback was that it was a strong application, it just needed more specifics in terms of the engagement with the youth companies. We have since amended the application and are very much hoping that with that, it will get accepted (we find out mid August). This of course, is a big if. 

So we have to look into other sponsorship, which is where this crowd funding site comes in.

The Budget...

We have asked the Arts Council for £7,680, this total includes payment of all creatives at equity level, including 4 actors, ourselves, the producer and dramaturg as well as £750 for the remainder of The Deptford Lounge who gave us a discount of 40% on their space (we're there for a week and they wanted the showcase as well). 

This project goes ahead with or without the Arts Council funding since we already have the space and generous support of the venues and people involved.

However if the bid is turned down again, we would lower the budget significantly and use whatever we manage to raise to pay for the Deptford Lounge and at least a small amount to the creatives and actors involved.

So we're looking at raising £2750, which would allow us to do this. 

On the other hand… If We Get Arts Council Funding:

Your support will go towards the funding of the full January production (3 weeks rehearsal, 3 weeks run), and all of its costs including: building hire, creatives, set, and costume. As you can imagine the cost of a full production is significantly more than two weeks of R & D so any help we can get, the better! 

The Dido & Aeneas Team:

Director: Jonathan Young

Jonathan is co-founder and artistic director of NMTA. Under the stage name, Noah Young, he has performed at places including The Barbican, London o2, The Trycicle, and Riverside Studios, and played parts ranging from Oberon and Sir John Falstaff to Munta, the Ugly Sister. Also a director, writer and musician, he has collaborated with artists such as Rion Willard, Adam Waldmann, Michiko Nitta and Michael Burton. 

Producer: Holly Aston

Holly is a theatre producer with experience working for a diverse range of theatre organisations and is currently a fellow under the CLORE leadership programme. Production Co-ordinator for Matilda, RSC. Previously: General Manager, The King’s Head Theatre and Leader of Emerging Artists Projects for AFTEC in Hong Kong. 

Choreographer: Jennie May Dunne

Jennie’s Lecoq training inspired NMT Automatic’s use of object manipulation in TOP and her acrobatic-dance background enabled a development of adagio-style movement. Acclaim includes: The Cambridge Fool’s When In Rome (‘outstanding choreography’ “WhatsOnStage”) and recently Where’s Your Mama Gone (Hen and Chickens) and Matchstick Girls (Redbridge Youth Workshop). 

Composer: David Hermann

David is another co-founder of NMTA. He has composed for TV in Germany and Switzerland as well as collaborating extensively with Dog Eared Films (London). His company, Windhouse Compositions, is currently creating a classical soundtrack for a documentary about Angela Merkel. 

Designer: Rion Willard

Rion has exhibited internationally and featured in various publications. A previous NMT collaboration saw the creation of an interactive architectural installation, which investigated human communication, within a rhythmical performance piece – parts of which were featured in the Pask Present Exhibition, Vienna. 

Dramaturg: Bernie C.Byrnes

Bernie’s writing commissions include: RSC (When There Were Ships) and New Theatre Royal, Portsmouth. Dramaturg credits include the award winning Muse of Fire (Shakespeare’s Globe), Little Soldiers (Theatre Re), Solas Fae (D Project) and NMT’s TOP. 

So - that's us and Dido. Thank you for staying with us to the bottom (ish) of the page. 

If you'd like to support, help or invest in us and join the team, we'd be really thrilled to have you. 

But that's not the only way you can help!  Spreading the word about the project and the crowdfund through Twitter, Facebook or by any other means available is invaluable - we'd be delighted to have another voice! You can tweet the link to this campaign or add it to your FB page.

Thanks again,

Jonathan, Jennie, Holly and David 

NMT Automatics

www.nmtautomatics.com

Want to follow our progress? Join us on Facebook and Twitter!
story_txt:
Welcome to our page and thank you for taking the time to find out more about our project!
We are NMT Automatics and we are seeking support for our new show Dido and Aeneas; an adaptation of Virgil’s ‘Book Four’ of The Aeneid.  It will fuse dance, theatre, and a soundtrack that combines Purcell’s original music with a new electric, industrial soundscape. 
The first stage of which is a two week Research and Development period, taking place in September, which will include active engagement and participation with Redbridge and Deptford community youth, culminating in a public and industry showcase.
Via a contemporary retelling of this ancient story, we aim to explore cultural intolerance in the 21st century: the conflict between old morals and current attitudes. 
Ultimately, we wish to produce a piece that not only is artistically great but also benefits the communities that we are working in.
You can be a part of this!
Research & Development:
Set within a period of industrial change, we will experiment with object manipulation, using raw materials to create a visually dynamic performance space and an arresting soundscape. This will be the first time Purcell’s opera has been juxtaposed with a modern metallic score specifically to create a theatrical soundtrack. 
We will be working with four actors and two youth groups - Redbridge Youth theatre (South Woodford) and Uncover Youth (Deptford) - who by participating in three workshops and performing with us in the showcase will directly impact on the artistic quality, diversity of ideas and accessibility of the piece, and also provide the opportunity for personal development on their behalf. We aim to find a home for a January production that would not only be informed by the communities within which we have worked, but also have them performing within it. 
“Aeneas, the Trojan hero, is shipwrecked on the enemy shore of Carthage. Brought to the widowed Queen Dido, he woos her with stories of war and hardship. story:
This Is Our Story.

Last year, the City of Surprise voted against continuing the Dysart District Override. thereby cutting the the Dysart Unified School District’s budget by $18 million. Programs that were funded by the override are now underfunded or have been entirely eliminated in order to keep up with increased expenses . The Override funded the following programs:

In elementary schools:

  • Art, Music, Band and PE classes
  • Full day kindergarten
  • Maintaining current class sizes
  • Additional math and reading support
  • 7th and 8th grade athletic programs 

In high schools:

  • Athletic programs
  • Fine Arts elective classes
  • Additional math and reading support 
  • Maintaining current class sizes

Our organization, Blank Paper Theatrical Initiative, is a non-profit community theatre based in Surprise, Arizona. Knowing that the DD-Override did not pass, we wanted to work with the school district directly, offering more after school fine arts opportunities! We have decided to offer two no-cut district-wide theatrical productions during this upcoming school year. It's an amazing opportunity to provide a creative outlet and after-school program for a school district desperately in need of art.

This Is How Dreams Comes True

We need to raise $5,000 to get our community education program off the ground. These funds will go towards the foundation of this initiative:

  1. Purchasing required insurance(s)
  2. The performance rights for two shows
  3. Design elements: sets, costumes, and props

Any amount exceeding this goal allows us to provide participants with an increased amount of opportunities to experience and educate! We want all participants to have the best experience possible.

This is a "flexible funding," "InDemand" campaign. If we do not reach our goal, all donations will still go toward our theatrical enrichment programs! This is our first fundraise as a non-profit organization. Our "bigger picture" hope is that by meeting and exceeding our financial goal, we'll be able to jump start similar enrichment programs through BPTI.

Just Make A Move

There are other ways to help us fundraise and be able to start something amazing for Surprise, Arizona! Our Board of Directors is diverse and experienced. We have educators, theatre house managers, directors and designers and performers. The foundation of BPTI is that it functions as a learning environment! Similar to having an array of directors, there are multiple outlets to help BPTI reach its goal!

  1. Spread the word!!! Send the URL above to friends, family, colleagues, institutions to whomever and whenever you can.
  2. Social Media is the new cool: tweet us, instagram a picture of our logos and tag us, send us a Facebook message or even tag us on there!
  3. Email us about opportunities for us to take the reigns!
  4. Be an advertiser in our program and throughout the season's two shows!

story:
Who are we?

In 2014, Mercury Glass Theatre Company broke into the New York theatre scene with presentist productions of William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet and Measure for Measure and Christopher Marlowe's Edward II. Now in 2015 we're shifting our focus to living writers and seeking to workshop a number of new plays that will be put up at competitions and festivals all over New York City and potentially beyond!


We are looking for new works that speak to a broad range of audiences about pertinent social issues. We hope to use our platform to raise voices that may not always be heard, to raise issues that are important to young people today, and to hold our particular mirror up to nature. 


What's the plan?


Over the course of the Spring / early Summer of 2015, we will be receiving submissions from playwrights, workshopping those plays, and submitting them to festivals. We will run separate Indiegogo campaigns for the individual works, but we need something to get us started. We need to pay for printing costs, rehearsal space, and submission fees, and we need your help to do it.



How can you help?


The easiest way to help us is by giving us a tax deductible donation. We have a number of perks that we hope interest you. Any amount of money you can give us is greatly appreciated, but of course more is always better!


If you have access to rehearsal space you would like to give/rent us, let us know. If you run a Festival and are interested in working with us, let us know. If you have a script you would like us to look at, please let us know.


Beyond that, talk about our Indiegogo campaign on all your social media platforms, through your email, or in person . Check out our website at MercuryGlassTheatre.org Follow us on Facebook. And help spread the word about our company!

story:
DARK HOUSE THEATER

We're a new theater company dedicated to producing work that explores themes of terror, suspense, and the supernatural. I'm Brian Williams, one of the Founding members, and Artistic Director. My Co-Founder and partner in this endeavor, Scot Gianelli, is the Managing Director of the group. We met while working at a theater festival in New York state and we bonded over a shared love of scary movies and good theater. With our friend Jack O'Brien as Producer, we founded Dark House Theater this past winter.  

Our first show goes up this September. It's a horrifying comedy called SLASHER. Written by Allison Moore, the dark comedy explores the making of a Slasher film. SLASHER has it all: thrills, chills, laughter, pretty girls, a terrifying villain with a juicy back story, and a bathtub full of blood. But bathtubs full of blood don't come cheap; hell in New York City, nothing does, so we're asking for your help.

We want to keep you on the edge of your seat, scare you, and thoroughly entertain you. You're the main reason we do what we do. Dark House Theater will make "populist art." We want people to WANT to come to our shows, so we are going to bust our butts to please our audiences.

What We Need & What You Get

As I said earlier, producing theater in NYC takes a lot of money. We're trying to raise $35,000 for our first show. Here's why we need it. 

Theater rental - $4,000 per week x 3 weeks: $12,000.

Playwright Royalties: $1,175.

Scenery: $3,000.

Props: $1,500.

Lighting: $500. 

GOOD Fake Blood (Not Red Water): $1,000.

Costumes: $2,000.

Press & Marketing: $3,000.

Actors: $3,000.

We also have to pay the Director, Fight Director, Fight Captain, Set Designer, Lighting Designer, Stage Manager, Sound Designer, Costume Designer, Composer. and the House Manager. The list goes on.

Additional payroll: $5,000.

On top of this is all the stuff that people forget about, like liability insurance, or even masking tape (you'd be amazed at how much tape gets used in one play!), and a ticketing service. And don't forget all of the great stuff we have lined up for our wonderful donors (we certainly haven't!). That gets us to our total of $35,000 very quickly. 

We also are hoping to be able to reserve a theater for our summer show in 2016 and to have the funding to begin work on our second production.

Additional Expenses: $2,825. 

Total: $35,000. 

If we don't raise all of this money, we will attempt to do the show in a scaled-back way, or save the money for even more extravagant future productions.

We are thrilled about some of the amazing perks for those of you who contribute.

Stylish thank you notes are forthcoming, and Facebook shout-outs, and tons of good energy and gratitude, but that's just the beginning!

We're also offering individual, quirky surprises that will accompany your thank you notes.

We are offering t-shirts and coffee mugs with our logo.

We will write and illustrate a poem in the style of Edward Gorey detailing your unique and one-of-a-kind demise.

Some of you will get home-baked confections.

Tickets to SLASHER, of course!

A chance to attend a dress rehearsal and sit with the director and give personal feedback to the creative team.

There will be an opportunity for you to be part of the show via SCREAM-OVER!

A private performance for you and your friends, with a special party with the cast, and your drinks are on us at the after-party!

Take home an arm and a leg (or some other ghoulish prop used in our show.)

We will make you up and photograph you onstage in a scene from a slasher style murder! 


What We Want to Do & What We've Done

We feel that theater should be fun, entertaining, and gripping. That's what we're trying to do here.

We want to attract new audiences to the theater, and expose them to the magic of live performance.

We also want to create an educational outreach program for NYC youth. That's down the road, but it's really important to me, as a former theater teacher. Theater changed my life when I was a teenager, and we want to share that with people who otherwise might not be exposed to it.

Scot and I have focused on bringing experienced, talented artists into Dark House, but also people who have a track record of excellence and innovation. 

I got my BA in Theater at Auburn University.  I studied Acting in the MFA program at the University of Florida. I've directed at the Yale Cabaret, The Florida Players, Monday Night Productions in NYC, The Hippodrome Theater in Gainesville, Florida, Twin Tiers Theater Festival in Olean, NY, and the SEACT in Dothan, AL. I'm also a commissioned playwright, and I'm currently writing a screenplay for a supernatural thriller entitled Widow's Walk.

Scot earned his BFA at the University of Arizona school of Theatre Design & Technology, with an emphasis in Lighting Design. Some of his favorite projects include The Grand Guignol Series and The Fest at the Flea with Scenic Designer Andrew Diaz. Scot's the founder and creative director of event and installation design firm New 70 Design Studio, Inc.

We've worked on shows and projects that were very successful, but we've also been involved with some that weren't. We believe in learning from our successes and failures, and moving forward with wisdom gained from experience. We will earn every dollar you pledge, work as hard as we  possibly can, and pay you back not only with gratitude and awesome gifts, but by making a production and a company that you can be proud to support.


    Risks & Challenges

    New York is a tricky town. People know what's good, and they're picky. We are committed to excellence. We want to be here for a long time to come and be a group that people think of as an excellent theater organization. 

    For us, it's not enough to simply get an audience in the door.  New Yorkers know what's good and what isn't, and we simply won't settle for anything less than giving everyone who comes through our doors an incredible and memorable experience.

    We have a great script, a great creative team, and we will produce an incredible show.


    If You Can't Donate... You Can Still Help

    If you love scary movies, and want to see more scary stuff onstage, but you can't contribute, you can help us by

    Sharing our campaign on Facebook and Twitter.
    Letting your friends know about our campaign.
    Coming to our show in September.

We also have to pay the Director, Fight Director, Fight Captain, Set Designer, Lighting Designer, Stage Manager, Sound Designer, Costume Designer, Composer. and the House Manager. The list goes on.
Additional payroll: $5,000.
On top of this is all the stuff that people forget about, like liability insurance, or even masking tape (you'd be amazed at how much tape gets used in one play!), and a ticketing service. And don't forget all of the great stuff we have lined up for our wonderful donors (we certainly haven't!). That gets us to our total of $35,000 very quickly. 
We also are hoping to be able to reserve a theater for our summer show in 2016 and to have the funding to begin work on our second production. 
Additional Expenses: $2,825. 
Total: $35,000. 
If we don't raise all of this money, we will attempt to do the show in a scaled-back way, or save the money for even more extravagant future productions.
We are thrilled about some of the amazing perks for those of you who contribute.
Stylish thank you notes are forthcoming, and Facebook shout-outs, and tons of good energy and gratitude, but that's just the beginning!
We're also offering individual, quirky surprises that will accompany your thank you notes. 
We are offering t-shirts and coffee mugs with our logo.
We will write and illustrate a poem in the style of Edward Gorey detailing your unique and one-of-a-kind demise.
Some of you will get home-baked confections. 
Tickets to SLASHER, of course!
A chance to attend a dress rehearsal and sit with the director and give personal feedback to the creative team.
There will be an opportunity for you to be part of the show via SCREAM-OVER!
A private performance for you and your friends, with a special party with the cast, and your drinks are on us at the after-party!
Take home an arm and a leg (or some other ghoulish prop used in our show.)
We will make you up and photograph you onstage in a scene from a slasher style murder! 

  What We Want to Do & What We've Done
We feel that theater should be fun, entertaining, and gripping. That's what we're trying to do here.
We want to attract new audiences to the theater, and expose them to the magic of live performance.
We also want to create an educational outreach program for NYC youth. That's down the road, but it's really important to me, as a former theater teacher. Theater changed my life when I was a teenager, and we want to share that with people who otherwise might not be exposed to it.
Scot and I have focused on bringing experienced, talented artists into Dark House, but also people who have a track record of excellence and innovation. 
I got my BA in Theater at Auburn University.  I studied Acting in the MFA program at the University of Florida. I've directed at the Yale Cabaret, The Florida Players, Monday Night Productions in NYC, The Hippodrome Theater in Gainesville, Florida, Twin Tiers Theater Festival in Olean, NY, and the SEACT in Dothan, AL. I'm also a commissioned playwright, and I'm currently writing a screenplay for a supernatural thriller entitled Widow's Walk.Scot earned his BFA at the University of Arizona school of Theatre Design & Technology, with an emphasis in Lighting Design. Some of his favorite projects include The Grand Guignol Series and The Fest at the Flea with Scenic Designer Andrew Diaz. Scot's the founder and creative director of event and installation design firm New 70 Design Studio, Inc.We've worked on shows and projects that were very successful, but we've also been involved with some that weren't. We believe in learning from our successes and failures, and moving forward with wisdom gained from experience. We will earn every dollar you pledge, work as hard as we  possibly can, and pay you back not only with gratitude and awesome gifts, but by making a production and a company that you can be proud to support.    
Risks & Challenges

New York is a tricky town. People know what's good, and they're picky. We are committed to excellence. We want to be here for a long time to come and be a group that people think of as an excellent theater organization. 
For us, it's not enough to simply get an audience in the door.  New Yorkers know what's good and what isn't, and we simply won't settle for anything less than giving everyone who comes through our doors an incredible and memorable experience.We have a great script, a great creative team, and we will produce an incredible show.
  
If You Can't Donate... You Can Still Help
If you love scary movies, and want to see more scary stuff onstage, but you can't contribute, you can help us bySharing our campaign on Facebook and Twitter.Letting your friends know about our campaign.Coming to our show in September.

story:
as a soldier

In 2006 I was deployed to Iraq with my partner, Specialized Search Dog Diego. Our mission was simple: assist coalition forces in the search for weapons, ammunition and explosives.  

It soon became very clear that the only "simple" thing for me in this war was my bond with Diego. In the midst of tremendous violence and upheaval I had an animal who was entirely dependent on me for his survival and, more importantly, loved me unconditionally.

During our deployment Diego and I were credited with the discovery of over 200,000 lbs of weapons, ammunition, and explosives, including the discovery of four roadside bombs. His nose saved countless lives--including mine on more then one occasion--but it was his never ending supply of licks, tail wagging, and wet-nosed nudges that kept me emotionally whole.

our mission

Through this performance piece we hope to illustrate the experiences of combat veterans in Operation Iraqi Freedom and incite discussion about the repercussions of prolonged combat in the lives of these soldiers.

In order to do this we need to provide for:

  • Costume pieces to supplement my personal combat gear.
  • Props and equipment rental
  • Designer and crew fees to support my team of Kansas City theatre professionals.
  • Location rental
  • Promotional material to spread the word and ensure that as many people as possible are able to hear this inspirational and thought-provoking story.

as a performer

Logan was a member of the Utah National Guard while he attended the acting conservatory at the University of Utah. During his senior year he was called to active duty and suspended his training. Five years later, after meeting Diego and serving in Iraq, Logan returned to undergrad and completed his Bachelors in Fine Arts. He spent two years acting in Chicago and regional theaters before attending the University of Missouri at Kansas City to earn his Masters in Fine Acting in Acting & Directing. He is a proud member of the Actor Equity Association, the union of professional actors and stage managers.

"what else can i do?" 

The issue of continued veteran care is one that needs the support and encouragement of people like you. You can help by being involved in your communities, becoming engaged in current veteran affairs, and donating to organizations that support veterans and their canine partners.

  • www.woundedwarriorproject.org
  • www.mwdtsa.org Military Working Dog Team Support Association
  • www.save-a-vet.org Military & Law Enforcement Working Dog Rescue & Support


"K-9 Guardians of the Night"

story:
Hello, everyone!

My name is Tatiana, I am a performing artist specialising in dance, but with a broad artistic interest. You can find more of my work on youtube and my website:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCjZ-gE8wCyZBRUzUqXqNCvg

http://tatirooney.wix.com/tati-rooney

Although born in Iceland, for me home was a small town on the banks of the Rhine in Germany. Amongst the vineyards and quaint cottages, my brother and I were allowed to explore and grow our burgeoning creative talent. We spent many happy hours planning, filming and editing our own short movies. For my friends, I wrote detailed scripts, brimming with enthusiasm and overflowing with dialogue. Looking back, perhaps they more closely resembled short, disorganised novels! But everyone starts somewhere, right?

I also attended ballet classes twice a week and I LOVED to perform. Even though, as a child I was more timid and calm by nature, performing gave me a great deal of confidence and equipped me with an intoxicating new way to express the feelings I had hidden. As well as benefiting me, my dream became the crafting of a highly relatable performance, facilitating a shared experience of catharsis in the audience, an outlet for all the joys and sufferings we experience as humans.

Deep down, I always knew I wanted to live an interesting and adventurous life, I felt such joy performing and inspiring people. I have found my gift and have devoted myself to its development as far as monetary constraints have allowed me. I love to lift people, to help them transcend the troubles of their lives, even if only for a short while, through the universal language of dance.

After graduating from high school I was faced with a tough decision, I had to admit to myself that I SHOULD dance, as a CAREER. It was quite hard to admit, since I knew it would be a road paved with financial uncertainty.

Nevertheless, I was determined as I enthusiastically set about auditioning for several prestigious dance and musical theatre colleges in London. My hard work was rewarded by an acceptance from Laine Theatre Arts, one of the top colleges in the country! This was such a giant leap for me, coming from a small German town and suddenly being thrust amongst some of the top talent that the world has to offer, but I thrived on the challenge and really felt myself grow as a person and as a dancer, gaining a solid foundation for my professional ambitions. Yet all the while, the money that the college demanded was a sword of Damocles that hung over my head as I danced. After completing two terms I had to face the reality that I simply did not have enough money to continue.

It was a valuable experience, with professional training that made me feel alive and that has certainly enabled me to begin, to leave amateurism in the rear view mirror.

It just saddens me that the arts, an industry that we all depend on to enhance our lives, risks excluding new talent for no better reason than a lack of funds.

However, I have NOT been discouraged, only made more determined to succeed and make my contribution to society. I realised for myself how much I want it, and recent experience has taught me to FIGHT for what I want. I am taking risks and I am not afraid anymore. I am more disciplined than ever.

Currently, I have thrown myself back into the maelstrom of auditions for various performing arts colleges around London and Europe, trying to gain scholarships. I have even auditioned for performance positions on cruise ships, along with many people who have already had a few years of professional training. It has given me a lot of confidence.

So far I have been accepted by Millennium Performing Arts and the Barcelona Institute of Dance and Bird College. They want me. I have what it takes. But I need the money.

No matter what happens, whether I have to work for a few years to save up enough to fund myself, I know I will be successful in the end. Success, does not depend on other peoples perception of what I have achieved, it’s more about staying true to myself and my own goals. I know my life will give me joy and satisfaction, because I will FIGHT for it. I refuse to settle for less ;)

I believe every person is SO special and has greatness inside. I feel like I am on the verge of discovering my speciality and what greatness God has placed in my destiny.

If you want to help a dancer in financial need, you are very welcome to help me.

THANK YOU!!! :)


A video explaining my situation:


If you want to get to know me better as a person:

Contact me

Feel free to ask me ANYTHING! I'd be glad to answer any questions of yours.

YouTube Channel:

 https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCjZ-gE8wCyZBRUzUqXqNCvg

My Website: 

http://tatirooney.wix.com/tati-rooney

My Facebook:

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Tatiana-Rooney/1416856208623696?ref=hl

My Instagram:

http://instagram.com/tati_rooney

- Tatiana Rooney

story:
Why a Lighting Grid?

For over 20 years, the 4th floor Mason Hall was just used for storage.  But in its earlier lifetime, practically since the Peoples Church building was built in the 1920s, this beautiful space was used as a theater.  And now it can be again, with your help.

The Peoples Church of Chicago is proud of our beautiful building, the Preston Bradley Center, and all the varied activities going on here, from soup kitchen to arts center.  And now we can have plays, dance performances, cabarets, as we refurbish Mason Hall.  We’re repainting the room and repairing the ceiling, and most importantly for performance groups, we’re replacing the lighting grid with state of the art equipment.

We have a number of theater and dance groups already lined up to use Mason Hall – and they need the grid to do their productions!  We love having theater and art here in our building, because we believe that art nourishes the soul.  And we need these groups to be here, so we can keep this historic building open and thriving as a center for arts and culture, spirituality and community.

Help install this very essential piece of infrastructure in Mason Hall to bring local, independent theater and performances back into the Preston Bradley Center!

What We Need & What You Get

Refurbishing Mason Hall includes the new grid, $9,450;  repairing the sconces, $400; and painting the walls and trim, $770, for a total of $10,620.  We'll put up a chunk of it, because this is so important.  We're asking you to help support live, independent theater on the North side of Chicago to the tune of $6,500.

In return for your donation, we're offering fabulous (!) prizes:  supporter buttons, cds of Dr. Bradley's inspiring short sermons, tix to future shows, secret tours, photo sessions, milestone ceremonies and more!

The Impact

Reviving this theater/dance space will bring a new mid-size performance venue to the North side of Chicago.  We value the arts, and with this space available, we will make this part of town culturally richer for those who live here, and for those who love Uptown's diverse community. 

This new lighting grid helps address the need for affordable performance space for small dance and theater companies in Chicago.  It allows us to offer a "blank slate" space, yet with all the infrastructure needed for theatrical and dance performances to be professionally lit, while remaining affordable.

The space offers not only a clean, uncluttered performance area, box office window, separate dressing rooms, and bathroom and shower for performers, but also lets independent artists and small companies bring only the equipment they need for their performances.

This versatility will help performing artists of all budget levels present their work at a higher production value than they have been able to afford up till now.

Even if you can't contribute yourself, tell your friends about the Preston Bradley Center and our efforts to get the theater refurbished.  You can use the share tools on Indiegogo to get the word out,

And thanks for contributing!

story:
Company of Friends does Beckett!

Since our creation in 2008, Company of Friends has been a leading theatre group in the Liverpool area, creating a thriving community of adult actors with learning disabilities.

We've been invited to the high-profile International Beckett Festival, Happy Days 2015. This is a unique opportunity for our highly talented group of people with learning disabilities to  perform on the international stage. The festival, and our play, take inspiration from the timeless talent of Samuel Beckett, one of the most influential writers of the 20th Century. Our performance is called "Nothing To Be Done", a Beckettian slant on living life with learning disabilities. 

We've performed the show before to great applause, at the YAI International Conference in Intellectual and Developmental Disabilities in New York in 2014 and in our home-venue, the Black-E Arts centre in Liverpool. We can't wait to perform it again. 

Your donation will go toward the accommodation for the cast, we're all putting our hands in our pockets, but any extra amount you can give will help our actors focus less on their funding and more on their lines!

What We Need & What You Get

We need some help funding our hotels for the 5 nights we'll be there. Any money that you give will be split between all the members and reduced from their overall costs. 
We estimate that an overall fundraising of £1000 would take a significant chunk of cost off the cost of each of our actors. 
For donating we have a number of gifts and perks to say thank you!
  • For £5 you will receive our undying love and gratitude. 
  • For £10 you will receive a thank you note from the whole cast, along with our undying love and gratitude. 
  • For £20 you will receive your name in the programme, a copy of the programme as well as everything else in the lower donation categories.
  • For £50 you will receive a Company of Friends T-Shirt, in the colour and size of your choice, along with everything in the lower donation categories. 
  • For £100, you will receive two Company of Friends T-Shirts, a mention in the programme, a Thank You note from the whole cast and everything else in the lower donation categories.
  • For £200, A bottle of bubbly along with two front row tickets to the show! (Only available to those who can be in Enniskillen during the festival.

story:
Who are we?

We are Project X Collective. A small group of young creatives who want to make a difference and expose their community to new forms of art. This time we come to you in collaboration with Le Cercle Molière in St-Boniface, Manitoba to give you our very first full scale production. A show putting a spotlight on the mariage between circus arts and projections.

What you're investing into ...
We're very excited to share our show with you. We've got some great ideas brewing, the only thing missing is a great space to showcase it in. That's where Cercle Molière's collaboration comes in. We'll be showing January 2016 in their main space - and this is where you come in ! Your generous donations will go towards :


  • Rental fees for the space, projector and other projection equipment
  • Ticket printing
  • Marketing ( posters, flyers, etc.)

    With your support we can get even closer to producing a fully realized production and compensate the collaborating artists who are making it happen. 


The Impact

We are proud to announce that our show will feature local artists mainly from Monica's Danz Gym. With their artistic support we will be able to offer you a once in a life time show. This is also a great experience for the artists to be part of a show of larger scale and technical proportions than before. We look forward to working with them and teaching them all about what goes into a show from creation to closing !

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, don't worry - there are plenty of other ways you can help. Share our link on social media and spread the word about our campaign. 


We can't wait to see your beautiful faces in our audience and hope you enjoy the show! Thank you in advance for your contributions.

story:
WHO ARE WE AND WHAT HAVE WE DONE TILL NOW?

The Annual “Bollywood and Multicultural Dance Festival” (BMDF) in Athens is being organized for the 6th consecutive year, and in the summer of 2018 it will materialize as a 3-day event, between June 29th and July 1st, at the iconic Dora Stratou Theater.

Bollywood and Multicultural Dance Festival was organized for the first time, by the 1st Bollywood Dance Academy Greece and Artistic Studio Oriental Expression, in Athens, Greece in June 2013.The festival is still Greece's biggest Multicultural festival and one of Europe’s biggest since 2013.

Over the last few years, the absence of Government funding, organizational issues within the art communities themselves, but – most of all – the severe and ongoing Financial Crisis in Greece, have made Greece a difficult terrain for hosting artistic events. 

The professional team of the Academy at the opening show for the 5th BMDF, 2017.

The BMDF emphasizes on cultural exchange as key component in International Relations.  From India and Middle East to North Africa and the Mediterranean Basin, every year different nations come in close contact in the heart of this beautiful city of the Athens. Over 15 countries have participated in the festival in the last 5 years.

VENUE & AUDIENCE : The Festival takes place at a landmark location, the Dora Stratou Dance Theater, that has been running since 1953. It is easily accessible by means of public and private transportation; it is situated in the Historical Center of Athens, opposite the Acropolis, on the far side of Filopappou Hill. The Festival welcomes people of all ages and cultural backgrounds to join this celebration. Due to the very contemporary and youthful nature of the spectacle itself, the Festival draws an audience of young people in the majority, aged 15-40,from all over Greece who are artistically inclined, especially familiarized with social media and who also bear a strong interest for alternative arts, cultures and lifestyles.

Capacity crowd at the historical Dora-Stratou Theatre, Athens, at the 4th BMDF,2016.

 

WORKSHOPS & MASTERCLASSES

Every year BMDF invites renowned dance faculties from all over the world to teach Workshops and Masterclasses at the festival. The workshops are open for all age groups and levels, and offers a wide variety of dance forms to choose from and thus attracts hundreds of students every year to participate and learn various dance forms.

Posters of the 12 different dance workshops organized in the 5th BMDF, Greece, 2017

 

 

A glimpse of the different dance workshops held  at BMDF over the years

 

INTERNATIONAL BOLLYWOOD DANCE COMPETITION

BMDF was the first to organize an International Bollywood dance competition in Greece in 2014, and back then it was one of the few Interntational Bollywood Competitions in all over the world . The competition includes Solo and Group categories and will be held for the 5th consecutive time this year.

A glimpse of the International Bollywood competition over the last 4 years in BMDF

Left : Ms. Anna Dimitratou, along with the Ambassadress of India to Greece, Ms. Manimekkala, awarding the prizes to the winners . Right : Panel of Judges at the 3rd & 4th International Bollywood dance Competition

SHOW : One of the main attractions of BMDF is the Mega show closing the festival. Ranging from Indian and Greek traditional dance forms to Oriental and Middle-Eastern dances, African and Latin dance among others, the BMDF showcases a list of the most diverse dance forms in the world by inviting artists from all over Greece and abroad in this spectacular Multicultural show every year at the Historical Dora – Stratou Theatre in Athens.

Pontian Union of Piraeus-Keratsini-Dragetsona & Pontian Union of Peristeri presenting  Greek dance at the 4th BMDF show

The professional team of 1st Bollywood Dance Academy Greece performing Indian Dance at the 4th BMDF  Show

The Professional team of Artistic Studio Oriental Expression performing Oriental Dance with swords at the 4th BMDF show

 

TELEVISION

   1st Bollywood Dance Academy competing at Greece Got Talent 2017 on SKAI TV.

Ms. Anna Dimitratou with Ms. Eleni Menegaki in popular TV show “Eleni” on Greek TV channel ALPHA.

The Academy has been invited on every popular TV channel in Greece. The BMDF has been promoted on various shows with popular celebrities like Eleni Mengaki, Mr. Krateros Katsoulis and Ms. Katerina Karavatou and Mr. Markos Seferlis featuring on Channels such as ALPHA, MEGA, ERT, EPSILON TV  and SKAI TV.

The Academy performing on the famous Tv show "Sta Kala Kathoumena" hosted by Krateros Katsoulis and  Katerina Karavatou on Epsilon TV

The 1st Bollywood Dance Academy Greece with Mr. Markos Sefarlis in popular show “Mega Me Mia” on  Greek TV channel MEGA.

The 1st Bollywood Dance Academy Greece in popular show “Menoume Ellada” on Greek TV channel ERT

NEWSPAPERS & MAGAZINES

Ms. Anna Dimitratou featuring in popular Indian Newspaper Hindustan Times on her Dance tour in India in 2015.

Ms. Anna Dimitratou and the team of 1st Bollywood Dance Academy featuring in the famous People Magazine, Greece.

A coverage of Bollywood and Multicultural Dance Festival in Shape Magazine, Greece.

The Bollywood Academy featuring in various Indian  regional and National Newspapers for their achievements so far, including TV shows like So You Think You Can Dance, Greece and Greece Got Talent.

 

LIST OF COUNTRIES

In the past 5 years of its existence , the BMDF has received participation from all over the world. Some of the countries who were a part of the previous editions of the festival include:

  1. INDIA                        
  2. SPAIN
  3. FRANCE
  4. FINLAND
  5. AUSTRIA
  6. EGYPT
  7. HAWAII
  8. SRI LANKA
  9.  BANGLADESH
  10.  PAKISTAN​
  11. U.K
  12. ITALY
  13. PORTUGAL
  14. BULGARIA

PRICES

 

Show ticket (Saturday Show) : $15 

Show tickets (Sat & Sun Show) : $20 

Participation fee (for Competition) : $30 

1 Day Pass ( Workshops + Show ) : $40 

2 Days Pass (Workshops + Show) : $65

3 Days Pass (Workshops+ Masterclasses+Show) : $125 

FULL PASS (Workshops+Masterclass+Competition+Shows) : $150 

We want to maintain low prices for the passes so that more people can participate in this festival. We could save a lot of money by only working with local artists, but then we would not be fulfilling our mission of bridging different cultures, dance communities in different Countries and supporting collaborations. 

OVERALL COST ESTIMATE

 

1) Cost of Space (theater "Dora Stratou” )                                                                        $2500 

2) Total Prize money for Solo and Group Categories                                                     $1,900 

3) Travel and accommodation  for guest dancers and teachers  and                      $5600 

4) Costumes(25-30)                                                                                                                  $3,700 

5) Advertising/promotion(flyers, brochures , posters, forms, programs,

   ticket issuance)                                                                                                                         $1,200 

6) Videography and Photography for the Opening party, Workshops,

Competition and Shows:                                                                                                           $1,100 

 

TOTAL                                                                                                                           $16000 

*The above budget still excludes some of production costs in the festival, like studio rents for rehearsals, graphic designer and various other little expenditures.

*You can choose to cover one or some of the major estimated costs and get a SPONSOR title or just become a SUPPORTER of the Festival by offering any amount you wish.

*Alternatively, you could offer as a gift of your Company's products to the participants and winners in the Bollywood Dance International Contest.

 

Will the dancers get paid?

Yes, that’s one of the main purposes of this campaign. So that we can cover the production costs and every participating artist gets remunerated well for their work. Generally the artists, invited by the festival, are paid even if the festival suffers a loss, but the dancers/choreographers of the Academy get paid only if there is a profit after covering all the expenses. 

For more details about the Festival check out our website : www.bollywoodfestival.gr or the YouTube Channel mentioned in the profile.

story:
"I see you stand like greyhounds in the slips, straining upon the start. The game’s afoot. Follow your spirit, and upon this charge cry “God for Harry, England, and Saint George!”

Your Courage, Your Cheerfulness, Your Resolution Will Bring Us Victory

Greyhounds is the first play by new young writer Laura Crow. It first premiered at The Greater Manchester Fringe Festival in July 2017 where it sold out leading to a second run in September 2017. This year Time & Again Theatre Company (formed by Laura last July to help bring the play to life) will be travelling up to Edinburgh to perform Greyhounds at the most famous Fringe festival in the world.

The company is;
Tim Cooper - Edward Holmes
Catherine Cowdrey - Ruby Winters
Laura Crow - Katherine Winters (and Writer/Producer)
Fiona Primrose - Nancy Wilde
Jacob Taylor - Will Croft
Jacqueline Wheble - Director/Front of House
Paul Wilson - Light/Sound

We have also been lucky enough to collaborate with Tom Barker, who took our wonderful promotional images, the Yorkshire Air Museum, who allowed us access to their stunning collecting of vintage aircraft for the day, and the Seamstress of Bloomsbury, who have provided us with utterly gorgeous outfits for both our photos and the full run in Edinburgh!


This Was Our Finest Hour 

Ruby, the village's would-be Bohemian, is directing a performance of Henry V to raise money for the local Spitfire fund. Never mind that it has fifty-two characters (most of them men) and that she's never read a word of Shakespeare in her life. Her younger sister Katherine is highly logical, highly mathematical, and completely inept at interacting with the world around her. Luckily, Will seems to know just what to say to her (though playing King Henry is quite another matter). Edward is a former RAF pilot recovering from a bad injury, and along with Nancy, an aspiring actress forced to work at her aunty's grocery shop while the bombs fall on London, he plays a range of characters under Ruby's far from expert guidance.

Greyhounds takes something huge - the Battle of Agicourt, the Second World War, Shakespeare's Henry V itself - and confines it (every scene is set in the village hall), bringing to the surface all the simmering tension, subtext, and raw emotion that the English so desperatley try to hide. 


We Can Do It!

Here is a very basic breakdown of what it will cost us to bring our show to the Fringe;
Venue - £2,400
Accommodation - £2,800
Marketing - £600
Travel - £200
Fringe Registration - £300
Insurance - £200
Total - £6,500
This is without paying our actors, director/FOH, light/sound a single penny.

Seeing this story come to life is an incredible experience and every single person involved has given up huge amounts of time and effort to create something we're really proud of. The Edinburgh Fringe Festival is such a famous and exciting platform. It is a chance for our work to be seen by industry professionals and to reach a much wider audience. Your contributions will directly help us to achieve this and perform at the biggest Fringe festival in the world!

 

Never Was So Much Owed By So Many To So Few

Your donations will make all the difference. We have some spiffing treats to tempt you with! Vintage postcards sent from Edinburgh, Shakespearean enamel pins, feminist propaganda posters, replica gas mask boxes and more! Take a look to the right to see what we have to offer and dig (deep into your pockets) for victory!

 

Let Us Go Forward Together 

We understand that not everyone is able to contribute but there are still many ways you can help.

  • Follow us on social media -  Twitter   Instagram   Facebook
  • Like, share and comment on our posts! Interaction is so helpful in gaining momentum.
  • Share this campaign!
  • Tell as many people as you can to check out the play at the Fringe!
  • Spread the word! Careless talk won't cost lives - in this case, in fact, it's encouraged! 


​
