story:
Who We Are

Hello! We are the team from Aphrodite and the Invisible Consumer Gods.

Sam Donvito

Writer, Performer and Producer

Sam is passionate about creating theatre that challenges stereotypes of beauty and gender. Her experience working as a beauty therapist for many years has given her a unique perspective. Sam graduated as an actor from the Adelaide College of the Arts in 2013. She also studied Playback theatre, a socially inclusive and audience interactive theatre from. Sam has studied and regularly peforms West African and Middle Eastern dance styles, she is a vibrant dancer who enjoys incorporating dance in storytelling.

Ellen Graham

Deviser, Performer, Co-Producer

Ellen loves exploring the depths of Greek mythology. She is also passionate about bringing her own perspective to create a totally unique and relatable performance.

Ellen graduated as an actor from the Adelaide College of the Arts in 2016. Since then she has regularly worked in theatre, children’s theatre and film. Her other talents include burlesque and exotic dancing. Ellen is an ongoing singer and dancer with the Australian Motley Crue show.

Why It’s Important

We both have experienced first or second hand comments regarding our appearance, felt objectified, pursued some diet and then done it all over again. Rinse, recycle, repeat. This show has important messages of body positivity and remaining true to yourself. We are passionate to get those messages out there

Our First Steps

“A great show and highly recommended for young women”

★★★★ - The Advertiser

Sam was inspired to write this play after watching a TEDx Talk by Jean Kilbourne called The Dangerous Ways Ads See Women. With the focus on creating this show, Sam then pursued a mentorship with playwright Emily Steel, as well as an intensive training program with Zen Zen Zo Physical Theatre Company. These activities were supported by the Helpmann Academy.

We (Ellen and Sam) then created Aphrodite and the Invisible Consumer Gods. With the help of NIDA graduate Christopher Bond as dramaturg and director, the show debuted at the Adelaide Fringe 2018.

Aphrodite won the 2018 Adelaide Festival Centre inSPACE Development Award - for best new work by a South Australian artist. This means we get three weeks of free rehearsal space, some free equipment hire and the opportunity to present Aphrodite at the curated 2019 Adelaide Festival.

Next On The Agenda For 2018

Since the Indiegogo video recording, we have received an opportunity to further develop Aphrodite in collaboration with Les Arts Scéniques theatre company, in Basel Switzerland. This will be facilitated by renowned movement specialist Cary Rick. Our show will then tour:

  • Edinburgh Fringe Festival: 12- 27th August, at ZOO Charteris, Venue 124.
  • Sydney Fringe Festival: Late September, Dates and Venue TBA.

 

Funds We Have Raised

 

Arts South Australia; Made in Adelaide, top up Grant of $2946 to go towards:

• Accommodation in Edinburgh for 3 weeks.

 

 

Helpmann Academy; Regular Grant of $3029.75 to cover:

  • Sam’s return flights from Adelaide to Zurich
  • The collaboration development with Les Arts Scéniques, in Switzerland
  • Marketing at Edinburgh Fringe

 

                                              

 

 

Total Funds Raised:$5975

 

In-Kind Support! Thanks to our Wonderful Family and Friends we also have:

  • Accommodation in Switzerland
  • Ellen’s Flights from Adelaide to Zurich
  • Accommodation in Sydney
  • Rehearsal space
  • Emotional support!!! 

 

What We Need Your Help With

  • Edinburgh Fringe registration fee- $720
  • Sydney Fringe registration fee- $397
  • Venue fees in Edinburgh (including FOH staff and a sound and light operator)- $3800
  • Venue fees in Sydney- $1000
  • Music licencing rights APRA and PRS- $300
  • Marketing in Sydney- $200
  • Return flights for Sam and Ellen from Adelaide to Sydney- $600
  • Return flights from Basel, Switzerland to Edinburgh- $600
  • Travel insurance- $400
  • Accommodation in Edinburgh not covered by the Arts SA grant (It’s expensive during the festival season!) -$700
  • Food and living expenses for 5 weeks (We won’t be able to keep our day jobs during tour) - $3000
  • Props, Costume and Set updates- $283

Total Funds Needed: $12,000

 

Risks & Challenges.

What fun would there be without some risk? Here are some we are facing:

  • Size/Competition: The Edinburgh Fringe hosts over 3,398 shows in 25 days. We're one (fantastic show) with a team of two. Don’t worry we’re highly creative at attracting attention to ourselves.
  • Finances: The whole reason why we're running this crowdfunder is because it is very expensive to put on a show, let alone travel all ar ound the world and back.
  • Endurance: We will be devising, marketing, producing our show while travelling, and it's a hard enough job without dealing with jet-lag and missing our daily dose of Vegemite!

We’re totally up for the fringe marathon challenge.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are artists ourselves and understand being a little light in the pocket! However if you can't donate there are still many ways that you can support us.

These include: 

  • Come see the show! The most important performer in the show is YOU: the audience. If you are in Edinburgh or Sydney or will be for our season dates then come see what all the fuss is about and if you can't, tell other people to come see the show! Here is a link to Edinburgh Fringe ticket information:

https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/aphrodite...

  • Leave a review! In a busy festival the thing that will make us stick out are your praises. If you see the show/have seen it and you loved it- write a review or leave us a message on our facebook or instagram!
  • Spread the word! It's easy to be forgotten in the tide of social media but if you take a second to post a link to our Indiegogo, or facebook, or instagram then we can keep attracting attention.
  • Use the Hashtag: #aphroditeandtheinvisibleconsumergods and get us trending!

Sam graduated as an actor from the Adelaide College of the Arts in 2013. She also studied Playback theatre, a socially inclusive and audience interactive theatre from. Sam has studied and regularly peforms West African and Middle Eastern dance styles, she is a vibrant dancer who enjoys incorporating dance in storytelling.

Ellen Graham
Deviser, Performer, Co-Producer
Ellen loves exploring the depths of Greek mythology. She is also passionate about bringing her own perspective to create a totally unique and relatable performance.
Ellen graduated as an actor from the Adelaide College of the Arts in 2016. Since then she has regularly worked in theatre, children’s theatre and film. Her other talents include burlesque and exotic dancing. Ellen is an ongoing singer and dancer with the Australian Motley Crue show.
Why It’s Important
We both have experienced first or second hand comments regarding our appearance, felt objectified, pursued some diet and then done it all over again. Rinse, recycle, repeat. This show has important messages of body positivity and remaining true to yourself. We are passionate to get those messages out there
Our First Steps

“A great show and highly recommended for young women”
★★★★ - The Advertiser
Sam was inspired to write this play after watching a TEDx Talk by Jean Kilbourne called The Dangerous Ways Ads See Women. With the focus on creating this show, Sam then pursued a mentorship with playwright Emily Steel, as well as an intensive training program with Zen Zen Zo Physical Theatre Company. These activities were supported by the Helpmann Academy.
We (Ellen and Sam) then created Aphrodite and the Invisible Consumer Gods. With the help of NIDA graduate Christopher Bond as dramaturg and director, the show debuted at the Adelaide Fringe 2018.


Aphrodite won the 2018 Adelaide Festival Centre inSPACE Development Award - for best new work by a South Australian artist. This means we get three weeks of free rehearsal space, some free equipment hire and the opportunity to present Aphrodite at the curated 2019 Adelaide Festival.
Next On The Agenda For 2018

Since the Indiegogo video recording, we have received an opportunity to further develop Aphrodite in collaboration with Les Arts Scéniques theatre company, in Basel Switzerland. This will be facilitated by renowned movement specialist Cary Rick. Our show will then tour:

Edinburgh Fringe Festival: 12- 27th August, at ZOO Charteris, Venue 124.
Sydney Fringe Festival: Late September, Dates and Venue TBA.


 
Funds We Have Raised
 
Arts South Australia; Made in Adelaide, top up Grant of $2946 to go towards:
• Accommodation in Edinburgh for 3 weeks.
 


 
Helpmann Academy; Regular Grant of $3029.75 to cover:

Sam’s return flights from Adelaide to Zurich
The collaboration development with Les Arts Scéniques, in Switzerland
Marketing at Edinburgh Fringe

 
                                              
 
 
Total Funds Raised:$5975
 
In-Kind Support! Thanks to our Wonderful Family and Friends we also have:

Accommodation in Switzerland
Ellen’s Flights from Adelaide to Zurich
Accommodation in Sydney
Rehearsal space
Emotional support!!! 

 
What We Need Your Help With

Edinburgh Fringe registration fee- $720
Sydney Fringe registration fee- $397
Venue fees in Edinburgh (including FOH staff and a sound and light operator)- $3800
Venue fees in Sydney- $1000
Music licencing rights APRA and PRS- $300
Marketing in Sydney- $200
Return flights for Sam and Ellen from Adelaide to Sydney- $600
Return flights from Basel, Switzerland to Edinburgh- $600
Travel insurance- $400
Accommodation in Edinburgh not covered by the Arts SA grant (It’s expensive during the festival season!) -$700
Food and living expenses for 5 weeks (We won’t be able to keep our day jobs during tour) - $3000
Props, Costume and Set updates- $283

Total Funds Needed: $12,000
 
Risks & Challenges.
What fun would there be without some risk? Here are some we are facing:


Size/Competition: The Edinburgh Fringe hosts over 3,398 shows in 25 days. We're one (fantastic show) with a team of two. Don’t worry we’re highly creative at attracting attention to ourselves.

Finances: The whole reason why we're running this crowdfunder is because it is very expensive to put on a show, let alone travel all ar ound the world and back.

Endurance: We will be devising, marketing, producing our show while travelling, and it's a hard enough job without dealing with jet-lag and missing our daily dose of Vegemite!

We’re totally up for the fringe marathon challenge.


Other Ways You Can Help
We are artists ourselves and understand being a little light in the pocket! However if you can't donate there are still many ways that you can support us.
These include: 

Come see the show! The most important performer in the show is YOU: the audience. If you are in Edinburgh or Sydney or will be for our season dates then come see what all the fuss is about and if you can't, tell other people to come see the show! Here is a link to Edinburgh Fringe ticket information:
https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/aphrodite...


Leave a review! In a busy festival the thing that will make us stick out are your praises. If you see the show/have seen it and you loved it- write a review or leave us a message on our facebook or instagram!

Spread the word! It's easy to be forgotten in the tide of social media but if you take a second to post a link to our Indiegogo, or facebook, or instagram then we can keep attracting attention.
Use the Hashtag: #aphroditeandtheinvisibleconsumergods and get us trending!

story:
Groove Juice Swing

Groove Juice Swing, established in 2004, is based in Rochester, NY and specializes in Lindy Hop, the original swing dance from the 1920s and 1930s. We offer dance classes, weekly social dances, live band dance events, performances, and dance workshops throughout the year. Annual events include Stompology, a solo jazz workshop weekend; Slow Dance Soiree; and the Red Hot Holiday Ball, a free social dance and party dedicated to all of the newest swing dancers in the community. 


Our Dream

It has been a long-standing dream of Groove Juice Swing to expand our programmatic offerings and establish a street-level, accessible space in the already vibrant community of the South Wedge, Rochester. 

We made the move to the Historic German House last summer, and have had a glimpse at realizing our dream – we pulled up the carpet to refinish a hardwood dance floor in the ballroom, we have access to a secondary lesson room and office space for the first time in 10 years, and ButaPub is gracious to open up their downstairs pub for our dances, also enabling us to have food & drink at our events. Our new space is handicap accessible and ballroom capacity give us something to aspire to.

 

It’s our dream to bring the joy of swing dancing to Rochestarians near and far, young and young-at-heart, wise and curious. 

In 2016, we want to see more people wandering in to ButaPub, happening upon a room full of delightful dancers. We want to bring you more live music that makes you move. We want to challenge you in new, diverse dance classes. We want to take the Lindy Hop to high schools and the next generation. We want to support the community with world-class talent, like top instructors for workshop weekends and sought-after bands from across the nation. And to do it, we want to invest in a comfortable home to dance in.


Every dollar that is donated goes straight back into the community. Support a joyous, active, growing community so we can share swing dancing with Rochester in 2016!

Fundraising Goals: 

·  $100- Supplies- all the cups, snacks, markers, and mints to keep you refreshed and dancing all night long

·  $250- Bartenders- Sure, you can always trot downstairs for a drink, but wouldn't it be nice to have bartenders upstairs more often at GJ Specials? 

·  $500- Jazz Art- Let's decorate! Help us get frames and artwork up in the private lesson and 63 room, featuring vintage and modern jazz posters and artwork

·  $1000- Sound equipment- Better equipment means clearer classes and more live music, and who doesn't want that? 

·  $1500- Sweetheart Show & Swing Dance- Debuting a jazz-based Valentine's-themed show featuring the Flower City Follies and talented Rochester artists, followed by a swing dance with a Rochester favorite - The Swooners! Save the date for Feb. 13th.

·  $2000- Water fountain- No more waiting for water jug refills, just duck on over to the water fountain to refresh yourself.  

·  $3000- Better thermostats- We love us some hot jazz and cool moves, but we prefer our bodies to be at a comfortable middle ground. 

·  $5000- Gordon Webster- We've missed having this crowd favorite here in Rochester- help us bring him back for some swing in the spring!

·  $7500- Mirrors- We've got plans to add mirrors to the private lesson and 63 rooms, just so you guys can see how good lookin' you are on the dance floor. 

·  $10000- Refinishing the stage- We love our beautiful new floors. There's just one more piece to polish before everything is shiny and smooth- the stage. 

·  > $10000- Awesome-ifying our Events- Out-of-town teachers. Live Music every month. Renting a Rochester van to travel to a nearby dance exchange. Crazy Photobooths. Whatever we get, goes right back into making our dance events awesome for you guys. 


What's the Impact? 

Each of our goal projects is something we feel would really benefit our dance scene and the local South Wedge community. Our mission is to learn, create, have fun, build relationships, and enjoy jazz with a growing community of swing dancers. We strive to create a dance community which is inclusive, friendly, and social. We want to provide the best place  for students, teachers, and community members to learn, create, and grow. We also want to support our local musicians, support the history of the dance, and create a space where everyone can meet their individual goals.  We're happy when we're dancing, and sharing the love of dancing with the community around us, and we thank you for helping us to continue sharing that love.

story:
Thank you to all of our generous donors! If you would like to contribute after the close of this campaign, please visit: www.SISUisintheHeart.com

SISU . . . what's that?  

My name is Park Cofield. I'm a theater director, a community builder, and a third generation Finnish-American! 

SISU is in the Heart  is a multi-year, international, community-based theater project about finding family, what it means to call a place "home", and a strange Finnish word -- SISU, which is hard to translate, but it means something close to perseverance, overcoming insurmountable odds, or inner personal strength.

I'm seeking support to produce an original play in partnership with the Finnish Heritage Museum and the community of Fairport Harbor, Ohio, a small village on Lake Erie with a large Finnish American population. This is also where my great-grandparents immigrated in 1900! The production will be FREE to the public and will take place at the local high school on October 1 - 4, 2015.

The play I have written is inspired by my personal family ancestry and stories shared by the community over the past year. 

I am also collecting personal stories of "SISU" on the backs of little red Finnish houses, in honor of my mother, who passed away in 2014. 

           

The FREE performance will feature:

  • 20-30 community members on stage! 
  • Professional performers and designers from CA, OH, GA, and Finland!
  • Live music by AALLOTAR-- Teija Niku (accordioinist) & Sara Pajunen (violinist)!  Sara is the Finlandia Foundation National Performer of the Year!
  • Puppets inspired by Finnish "pauper statues" or vaivaisukot, a folk art tradition only found in Finland and the paintings of my relative, Antti Ojala!

This is a play about much more than just my family. It is about ALL families. It is about where your family is from and who you are.
We can't do it without your help! 


This project is a HUGE undertaking. The community of Fairport Harbor deserves a great play and I need your help to give it to them. 

I have received two grants from Finlandia Foundation National for the initial research and development, and for travel support, but the rest of the project relies on personal contributions, private foundation support, and in-kind donations (including the use of the theater in the local high school).

We are seeking $15K on IndieGoGo with a stretch goal of $20K. This is only a portion of the total $100K budget. Your contribution will support the production costs below and most importantly will allow me to pay artists and community members for their hard work and time! 

$5,000 - Artist Fees  & Per Diems
$5,000 - Production Costs - Sets, Lights, Costumes, Puppets, etc.
$3,000 - Music and Composition
$2,000 - Community Actor Stipends
$5,000 - Local Housing (only fully covered if we meet our stretch goal of $20K)

Project Team - Jeffrey, Nina, Park, Saara, and more people to be hired soon!
AALLOTAR - Teija Niku, Sara Pajunen

Impact  

  • Fairport Harbor is in a period of revitalization. This large scale artistic project will help inspire and give the community an active voice!
  • The Finnish Heritage Museum has proclaimed 2015 as the "Year of the Young". Focusing on those who are the future of Fairport will help them to grow their membership, attract younger families, and increase their national exposure and connection to other Finnish-American communities!

                

           


Special Perk (Added 7/13) - Limited Quantities!

A set of 4 limited edition postcards featuring the work of Antti Ojala. Subjects include pauper statues, landscapes, abstract images. . . there's even one with a goat!

 

What Happens Next?

  • 2016 - The project will tour to the birthplace of my great-grandfather in partnership with Vanha Paukku, a cultural center in Lapua, Finland!
  • 2017 -  A proposed  U.S. exhibition of vaivaisukot in New York and Los Angeles in partnership with The Society to Save Pauper Statues. This exhibition will coincide with screenings of two documentary films about the project and the 100th Anniversary of Finnish Independence!
  • 2018 - Follow-up visits with Fairport Harbor, Ohio and Lapua, Finland, and a letter writing campaign between seniors and teenagers in both communities!

Press & Other Resources 

LA Playwright returning to Fairport for first draft on Finnish Play - The News-Herald
Playwright hosts Story Circle in Fairport Harbor - The News-Herald
A Trip to Finland – Paupers, Paintings, and Puppets - TCG Circle
Sara Pajunen named Finlandia Foundation Performer of the Year - USA Suomeksi
Transforming Barriers into Frontiers - Emilia Lahti - Ted Talk on "SISU"


Other Ways to Help! 

If you aren't able to contribute financially, please consider:  
  • Spreading the word about the project using the Indiegogo share tools.
  • Sending me your own personal "SISU" story! Click HERE for more info.
  • Visiting the project website: www.SISUisintheHeart.com 

Thank you! 

From the bottom of my heart, and Fairport's -- Kiitos!

Park Cofield
Project Director

Thank you! From the bottom of my heart, and Fairport's -- Kiitos! Park CofieldProject Director

story:
Short Summary

Festival51 is a Rhode Island-based women's playwriting festival designed to create exposure and work for female writers and theater artists. Submissions to the festival are currently being accepted (see our website link below for more details) and the final four candidates will be selected on May 15th. All plays will be fully staged and produced at Mixed Magic Theatre’s performance space in Pawtucket, RI from July 31st through August 15th, 2015.

Festival51 Website

Funding is necessary for Festival51 to meet it's main goal: provide female writers and theater artists paid exposure in their selected craft. Proceeds from this fundraiser will go directly to the artists involved - Festival51 is not a for-profit venture, but a showcase and an opportunity for female artists to see their work staged and produced.

What We Need & What You Get

While we are also seeking alternative funding sources such as grants and direct donations via our website, your contribution here will enable us to meet the goal of providing paying jobs for women writers and directors and give voice to an underrepresented element of Rhode Island and Southern New England Theater.

 
  • With four plays being selected, your contribution will help provide funding for five playwrights and four directors.
  • Be a part of elevating the discussion about equality in the arts.
  • Even if we don't meet our full goal, the money raised will still be divided equally among the artists and provide some level of pay for their artistic efforts.
  • You will be listed as a Donor to the Festival and, depending on your donation level, receive other perks and benefits related to the event itself, including private events and performances.

The Impact

Women's voices in the Arts and Theater, in particular, are still struggling to be heard in a field where male playwrights and directors still have dominance. Festival51 has been designed to help levelset that discrepancy and hopefully become an annual event in Rhode Island.

The organizers of Festival51, in conjunction with Mixed Magic Theatre ( Mixed Magic website ) have a collective wealth of experience and talent making them uniquely qualified to successfully mount such an endeavor. Organizers Leann Heath and Terry Shea have been practicing Theater artists for decades, as actors, directors, designers, producers, organizers, marketers and developmental curators. Mixed Magic's Jonathan Pitts-Wiley and Tammy Brown are also Partnering Artists for Festival51 and will aid in curating and selecting the final script candidates.

The talent is in place, scripts have been submitted from all over New England and finalists selected. Your contribution will ensure that the women who produce these final works will have a chance to succeed in their field and have their voices heard in a crowded, often male-dominated landscape.

Risks & Challenges

We are aware that many Arts organizations are seeking help and donations in order to survive in a crowded field. Festival51 does not have the kind of name exposure that other, established Arts entities in Rhode Island may have, but we believe that with the right outreach, we can overcome that challenge. Our presence in social media (Festival51 Facebook Page) has already garnered substantial attention and we await a potential RISCA grant. That grant will not be enough to meet projected expenses, however, and producing plays creates financial need beyond being able to pay writers and artists. We believe that with your aid, we can meet our production costs and still be able to provide a modest stipend to those women contributing to Festival51's success.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if your contribution is small (or you cannot contribute at all) please help us by passing the word about Festival51 to anyone you know. People can visit us at www.festival51.org or our Facebook page at www.facebook.com/rifestival51.

We can answer any and all questions at rifestival51@gmail.com or (401) 285-0351.

Thank you for your help in making Festival51 a reality and a success!

story: Hi There! my name is Aleah Quiñones, I am a current Sophomore at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. I have been chosen among hundreds of applicants to participate in the Actors Apprenticeship at the Williamstown Theatre Festival. To have this opportunity is nothing short of a blessing from God! The program, however, costs a total of $3,950 to participate with a $1500 deposit by JUNE 1st, an amount my family and I can't come up with as I've been saving funds for my Fall semester of college at The Royal Academy of Dramatic Art in London. I am an extremely passionate artist trying to make my dreams a reality. Everyone that I have met and learned from on my journey has served my life with so much inspiration, invaluable tips, and joy. That is exactly what I'm hoping to gain at Williamstown. Not only will it be an opportunity to work and learn, but to also connect with other artists and become a part of the Williamstown family. Thank you so much for your time to learn a little about me and my goals, your support means more to me than you know!

story:
Lesbian porn! Just kidding -- for once we tell our own narrative. Red and Boiling is a whimsical drag and shadow puppet show created by Noga Yechieli Wind and Joshua Rivas about queer womyn and their lives beyond the act of coming out. Do you know what lies behind the flannels and pick up trucks, when they are full three dimensional beings? Drag duo Hasadick and Rosay Ratcheté do. Together they will take you through a world of striking shadow puppetry using comedy and lip sync. Their journey explores the lives of queer womyn and non-binary individuals from different countries, religions, ethnicities, and ages. We premiere this magical piece at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival this August. Come laugh, celebrate and rediscover your identity with us. Based on hours of real life interviews, every performance changes as new testimonies are shared verbatim. If you share your story with us, it might be in our show the next day. Red and Boiling is like soup, a pot of queer stories, a pinch of drag, a dash of lip sync, a few slices of comedy, some tears, and, most importantly, salt.

But that’s not all. The story is never over, because there are too many stories to tell. As we interview more womyn every week, we’ve turned these testimonies into a podcast.  You can hear the complete stories at: www.redandboiling.com/podcast/ , Stitcher:  http://stitcher.com/s?fid=187037&refid=stpr , or Soundcloud  https://soundcloud.com/user-892795198/red-boiling-ep-1 .

Why We're Doing It

We are excited to take Red and Boiling to the melting pot of the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. It gives us the opportunity reach an audience that is intersectional. Red and Boiling reveals the untold stories of queer womyn from the Middle East to the U.S., and our international testimonies deserve to be seen by an international audience. Out of the dozens of womyn interviewed, most have never seen themselves represented on stage. Hasadick and Rosay are dedicated to amplifying the reality of queer womyn and Red and Boiling provides that space. Not only are we building a queer community, but we are building a bridge to the international queer community. Edinburgh is a truly international space for audiences, artists, and presenters, allowing us to make connections that help us lay the foundation for future international touring. Come into the light with your identity and witness an hour of celebration, heartbreak and magic. 

What We Need

Taking a play to Scotland isn’t easy, nor is it cheap. We are spending $19,000 on travel, lodging, and per diem for seven artists, and $1200 on advertising to make sure that we reach our audience. Additionally Hasadick and Rosay will be in drag EVERY DAY for a MONTH in Edinburgh, and makeup, beards, eyelashes etc can add up to quite an expense. Every penny of the $3500 that we raise here is going to one of the following places: Travel, Artist Fees, Drag, and Advertising. We are investing in our artists, and in our community.

How You Can Help

For every $5 that we raise, we can afford to make five more stickers./ buy another pair of eyelashes for Rosay (if only her real ones were enough...)

For every $15 that we raise, we can print ten buttons. (who doesn’t love a button?!)

For every $30 that we raise, we can cover one person’s meals for one day. (You know us dykes are all about that FISH....and chips)

For every $75 that we raise, we can make five new puppets. (Gimme that X-Acto knife hunnyyy)

For every $100 that we raise, we can afford one new beard for Hasadick. (Drag is expensive, ya’ll)

For every $250 that we raise, we can print 30 more posters. (We want our faces on every corner!)

For every $500 that we raise, we can fly one artist to Scotland! (they’ll have to get back on their own)

 

What you get: Our undying love, affection, and gratitude. And if you REALLY help us out, maybe you get the Red and Boiling #ally award which we've just made up. 

The Team

Noga Yechieli Wind is an actor, writer, theater maker and queer activist from Jerusalem. Her work focuses on merging her activism and her art. She wrote, directed and produced Let’s Talk Sex Work: A Play, which was performed at the CalArts New Works Festival, as well as the Los Angeles LGBT Center in 2017.  Noga is also a drag king, performing as a bearded queer Jewish persona by the name of Hasadick. She lives in Los Angeles and graduated in 2018 with a BFA in Acting from California Institute of the Arts. For more information visit www.nogawind.com  

Joshua Rivas is a Los Angeles based director, actor and theatre maker. Joshua is a co-founder of Familia Elefante Productions; a puppetry company created while studying at California Institute of the Arts. Using shadow puppetry, toy theatre and live projection, Joshua’s work emphasizes a re-examining of the way we see the communities around us. In addition to their puppet work Joshua has developed a Drag Persona named Rosay Ratcheté who is the bougiest lady of them all. Joshua graduated from California Institute of the Arts in 2018 with a BFA in Acting. For more Information visit www.Joshuarivas.com.

 

Creator/Performer: Noga Yechieli Wind

Co-Director/Puppet Designer/Performer: Joshua Rivas

Puppeteer/RED: Alex Mitchell

Scenic Designer: Tanya Orellana

Costume Designer: Cameron Meakin

Lighting Designer: Rose Malone

Sound Designer: Anna Grossman

Stage Manager: Madison "Grey" Miller

Production Manager: Max Weinstein

Edinburgh Producer: Malik Allen 

Producer: Sophie Blumberg

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

Come see the show in Edinburgh. Don’t live in Scotland?

Call your queer friends in Scotland and tell them to buy tickets.

Don’t have queer friends in Scotland? What’s wrong with you?

Okay, then call your straight friends in Scotland.  

Don’t have any friends in Scotland? Call your friends in London and tell them to drive up to Scotland. Don’t have friends in the U.K or Europe? Buy a plane ticket or boat ride across the Atlantic.

Left your credit card in your other flannel? Cat eat your debit card? Spent your cash on the U-haul you just rented?  

 

TELL YOUR FRIENDS. SPREAD THE WORD.

 

Share our campaign with someone you think might want to support us!

Listen to our podcast here: www.redandboiling.com/podcast, Stitcher:  http://stitcher.com/s?fid=187037&refid=stpr , or Soundcloud  https://soundcloud.com/user-892795198/red-boiling-ep-1 .

Follow us on Instagram @redandboiling!

Follow us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/RedandBoiling/

Share your story: email us at redandboiling@gmail.com

 

Come out into the light.

story:
Help us change the world - one audience member, one individual, one mindset at a time. 

We're 'from (a)basement theatre collective', a new independent theatre company based at Royal Holloway University. We believe in exposing what is hidden below to the society above; giving under-represented and undermined voices a place on stage and in conversation. We aim to make social-specific theatre that challenges, inspires and - most importantly - reveals oppressed narratives that deserve to see the light of day.

 

We are:

Director: Rebecca Goh, Drama and Philosophy third year student

Stage Manager: Emily Wilkinson, Drama and Theatre Studies third year

Deputy Stage Manager: Niamh Kennedy, Drama and Theatre Studies third year

Publicity Officer: Cameron Cheung, Drama and Theatre Studies third year

Role A: Aaron Barrow, Drama and German first year

Role B: Kerryn Isobel Frean, Drama and Theatre Studies first year

Role C: Matteo Lewis, Music second year

Role D: Elizabeth Lindsay, Drama and Film Studies first year

 

What is this about?

"If people are going to kill themselves, could they at least do it in the privacy of their own homes and away from public transport? Having my train cancelled because you hate life is selfish as fuck! #selfish"

00:00 (pronounced 'zero hundred hours') is a look at what goes on behind the scenes; the people who clean up, sanitise, disinfect, and come into existence after the world has gone to sleep. 

Following the lives of workers employed with Network Rail as part of the “Specialist Cleaning Team”, this production examines the collateral damage and impact of railway suicides. From train drivers to social media managers, from commuters to the decontamination crew, 00:00 will take the audience on a witty high-speed kaleidoscope journey beneath the façades we wear; mental health, society, masculinity, and messy aftermaths in modern Britain. 

Previously performed at The Old Court Theatre in Windsor to critical acclaim, 00:00 now returns to Egham for a three-day run at The Packhorse, with evening performances on 7th, 8th and 9th December 2018. It aims to raise awareness of social issues such as toxic masculinity, the changing face of human interaction, and perceptions of lesser-known mental health conditions. This production reanimates and restores hidden perspectives to the public consciousness, and to provide a glimpse into environments that remains inaccessible to the majority of society. It reflects the lack of empathy we see still prevalent around us, through found text and devised ensemble movement. This production also aims to highlight pertinent underground social issues, and to give a voice to those unheard and unseen. We hope that the perspectives presented in this performance would resonate with audience members, and generate further constructive debate and discussion. It encourages every individual in the audience to cease taking people for granted, and to re-examine their relationships and reactions to such tragic events. 

 

 

Why us?

This is a COMPLETELY independent, original, full-length professional show, and we need all the help we can get!

  • We have staged this show before, and would now like to make it bigger and better, and more engaging for our audiences.
  • As we are unaffiliated with either the Students' Union or Royal Holloway University's Drama department, we do not have the same funding or support that other productions on campus get. 
  • Thus, we are crowdfunding and trying to cover our costs of buying props and set items. 
  • We are not out to make massive amounts of profit, 10% of all ticket sales will be donated to the charity organisation Samaritans (they feature in the play quite a bit). 
  • All contributions, regardless of it being £1 or £100, will aid us immensely in bringing this show to life, and no amount is too small to go unappreciated! 
  • If 10 people donated £10 each, it would be £100 altogether and that's no small feat.

We feel that this show is especially important in this day and age (and worth any monetary contributions), as we are exploring and presenting relevant and topical issues in a new and exciting way. We won't spoil the show for you, but both the text and set design is going to be unconventional, and the show would be staged outside the Packhorse pub across the road from the university campus which is an interesting change from the usual theatrical spaces. All financial contributions will help us to stage the best possible show we can, and to do justice to issues that still affect people in society to this day. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need the money to purchase/rent:

  • Black cloths to transform the venue into an atmospheric and intimate performance space
  • A projector
  • Lamps for lighting (performing in complete darkness is all well and good but we don't want to be TOO immersive)
  • Set items such as rostrums and gravel 
  • Printing materials such as tickets and programme booklets
  • Any travel costs incurred in transporting gear and equipment to and fro
  • Creating/mailing perks claimed by our lovely Indiegogo contributors 

And most importantly, enough money to:

  • Pay all actors and crew members, who have spent so much time and effort making it all possible.

 

A sneak peek of what's up for grabs as perks for contributing (depending on the amount given):

  • A signed scrapbook that includes an exclusive behind-the-scenes look at the rehearsal process, photos of rehearsals and the show itself, train tickets collated by cast and crew, along with funny and interesting stories/memories attached to the journey on the ticket, amongst other content.
  • Hilarious movie/train posters Photoshopped with cast and crew members' faces, signed.
  • Free tickets, and a chance to talk personally to the cast and crew after the show regarding the play and the performance (post-show discussion and Q&A if you so wish).
  • Signed and annotated copies of the director's script (our director is fond of doodling so you can expect to see an interesting variety).
  • Credit on programme booklets and shoutout on social media.

That's not even half of what we offer, click on the individual tiers on the right to see what else we have (or contribute some money to find out).

 

 

The Impact

By contributing to our project, you will be:

  • Enabling us to ensure that our production is the best that it can be.
  • Supporting an entirely independent theatre company made up of poor students with big dreams.
  • Helping us to compensate everyone involved in this passion project with some financial renumeration for their blood, sweat and tears.
  • Allowing the different voices in the play - all seldom heard or seen - to be brought to the surface, hopefully engendering a more understanding and empathetic community.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, there are other ways to help us! 

  • Please do spread the word about our performances and share our posts/events on Facebook!  https://www.facebook.com/belowthefirstfloor 
  • If you could, please pass our campaign/crowdfunding page on to others you know! 
  • If you would like to help out/sponsor us in other ways, get into contact with us and we'll be more than happy to discuss whatever you have in mind!

 

Thank you for reading, and thank you so so much for all your support! We hope to see you at the show x

story:
Short Summary

The Aspen Fringe Festival & the Aspen Chapel are thrilled to bring  THE CHRISTIANS, by Lucas Hnath, winner OUTSTANDING NEW OFF BROADWAY PLAY, to the ASPEN CHAPEL.  

 “a Terrific New Play about the Mystery of Faith” —NY Times  
 " powerful, riveting” —National Catholic Reporter

The play will be performed in the Sanctuary at the Aspen Chapel, Thursday, July 5th and 8th. Both performances start at 7:30pm.

ABOUT THE PLAY: Ten years ago, Pastor Paul’s church was a modest storefront. Now it houses thousands, with a coffee shop in the lobby and a baptismal font as big as a swimming pool. But Paul is about to preach a sermon that will shake the foundation of his congregation’s beliefs. Backed by a live gospel choir, The Christians is both epic and unexpectedly intimate, an unflinching look at faith in America — and its power to unite or divide.  And YOU THE AUDIENCE PLAY THE CONGREGATION.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5,000 to produce this play. The show will run for two nights, July 5th and July 8th.  Both performances start at 7:30pm.

Every cent raised will be used to pay for performers, musicians, set decoration, advertising and marketing. 

We are offering some amazing perks for your contribution!  Please see the list on the right of all the great things you get by making a tax-deductible contribution.

The Impact

What are people saying about ‘The Christians’? Why is this play so important?

Check out the video excerpts from the original Off B'way show. Although we are not affiliated with the Playwrights Horizon production, we hope to inspire the same excitement! Playwright Lucas Hnath was Featured in the Aspen Tomes and and hosted an evening at the 10th annual Aspen Fringe Festival, June 10th. For more information visit www.AspenFringeFestival.org

Help us present this Once-in-a-Lifetime Event about Faith in America!
In an exciting first time collaboration, The Aspen Fringe Festival and the Aspen Chapel 
seek to present this Award Winning Play called: “…Remarkable !” —Christianity Today 

The Play takes place in a church and THE ASPEN CHAPEL  will be our Stage!
With a LIVE GOSPEL CHOIR and YOU THE AUDIENCE PLAY THE CONGREGATION!

Why We Can Pull This Off

The Aspen Fringe Festival is dedicated to the idea that great art stimulates cultural discussion, inspires  and encourages people to reach for their dreams and give back to their communities and the world. Especially in time of great discord we believe in the power of the arts to heal relationships and communities.

The Aspen Fringe Festival is celebrating its 10th year bringing of high quality performances to the Roaring Fork Valley. Please help us to continue to inspire our residents and visitors alike.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you love this idea, but can't help financially, please share this campaign with your friends.

Thank you for your support!

The Aspen Fringe Festival & the Aspen Chapel are thrilled to bring  THE CHRISTIANS, by Lucas Hnath, winner OUTSTANDING NEW OFF BROADWAY PLAY, to the ASPEN CHAPEL.  
 “a Terrific New Play about the Mystery of Faith” —NY Times   " powerful, riveting” —National Catholic Reporter
The play will be performed in the Sanctuary at the Aspen Chapel, Thursday, July 5th and 8th. Both performances start at 7:30pm.
ABOUT THE PLAY: Ten years ago, Pastor Paul’s church was a modest storefront. Now it houses thousands, with a coffee shop in the lobby and a baptismal font as big as a swimming pool. But Paul is about to preach a sermon that will shake the foundation of his congregation’s beliefs. Backed by a live gospel choir, The Christians is both epic and unexpectedly intimate, an unflinching look at faith in America — and its power to unite or divide.  And YOU THE AUDIENCE PLAY THE CONGREGATION.

What We Need & What You Get
We need to raise $5,000 to produce this play. The show will run for two nights, July 5th and July 8th.  Both performances start at 7:30pm.
Every cent raised will be used to pay for performers, musicians, set decoration, advertising and marketing. 
We are offering some amazing perks for your contribution!  Please see the list on the right of all the great things you get by making a tax-deductible contribution.

The Impact
What are people saying about ‘The Christians’? Why is this play so important?

Check out the video excerpts from the original Off B'way show. Although we are not affiliated with the Playwrights Horizon production, we hope to inspire the same excitement! Playwright Lucas Hnath was Featured in the Aspen Tomes and and hosted an evening at the 10th annual Aspen Fringe Festival, June 10th. For more information visit www.AspenFringeFestival.org
Help us present this Once-in-a-Lifetime Event about Faith in America!In an exciting first time collaboration, The Aspen Fringe Festival and the Aspen Chapel seek to present this Award Winning Play called: “…Remarkable !” —Christianity Today 
The Play takes place in a church and THE ASPEN CHAPEL  will be our Stage!With a LIVE GOSPEL CHOIR and YOU THE AUDIENCE PLAY THE CONGREGATION!

Why We Can Pull This Off
The Aspen Fringe Festival is dedicated to the idea that great art stimulates cultural discussion, inspires  and encourages people to reach for their dreams and give back to their communities and the world. Especially in time of great discord we believe in the power of the arts to heal relationships and communities.
The Aspen Fringe Festival is celebrating its 10th year bringing of high quality performances to the Roaring Fork Valley. Please help us to continue to inspire our residents and visitors alike.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you love this idea, but can't help financially, please share this campaign with your friends.
Thank you for your support!
campaign_city: 77 Meadowood Dr. Aspen, CO 81611, United States

story:
Who

We are a scrappy startup founded by a group of Fredonia Alumni in August of 2016. Our alma mater instilled the idea of making your own theatre and exploring who you are as an artist. Shellscrape Theatre Co. works under the belief that the uniqueness of the individual is at the core of all theatrical expression.

What

Miss Julie is the final production of our inaugural year and is a contemporary interpretation of August Strindberg's original play. This story was adapted by our Artistic Director (Hey Elaine!) in order to be more accessible to our audiences. Our cast is working together to create a new ending for Miss Julie that breaks away from its traditional and unfortunate outcome.

The Impact

Your contribution directly translates to the opportunities we provide our artists. At this stage in the production process, we have a team of 14 young theatre professionals from actors to technicians. We hope to increase this number by including photographers, designers and critics to further the quality of the show and to provide a chance to gain hands on experience. 

What We Need

Our fundraising goal of $2,000 will go toward the following: 

Performance venue - a multipurpose warehouse in Brooklyn

Rehearsal space - we're working with our friends at Union Street Dance

Marketing - we need effective advertising to make some noise

Our artists - receive a stipend for their time and dedication to the project

Props and costumes - sourced from local merchants to support our community

What You Get

If you donate, any amount big or small, you will receive the following: 

Freshly Picked 

  1. Our digital gratitude

Sunny Side Up

  1. Our digital Gratitude
  2. Handwritten thank you card

Over Easy 

  1. Our digital gratitude
  2. Handwritten thank you card
  3. Autographed mini poster

Fried

  1. Our digital gratitude
  2. Handwritten thank you card
  3. Autographed mini poster
  4. Shellscrape Theatre Co. pin 

Scrambled

  1. Our digital gratitude
  2. Handwritten thank you card
  3. Autographed mini poster
  4. Shellscrape Theatre Co. pin 
  5. Recognition in the program
  6. One ticket - reserved seating

Poached 

  1. Our digital gratitude
  2. Handwritten thank you card
  3. Autographed mini poster
  4. Shellscrape Theatre Co. pin 
  5. Recognition in the program
  6. Two tickets - reserved seating
  7. Professional recording of the performance

Soft Boiled

  1. Our digital gratitude
  2. Handwritten thank you card
  3. Autographed mini poster
  4. Shellscrape Theatre Co. pin 
  5. Recognition in the program
  6. Two tickets - reserved seating
  7. Two tickets for a meet and mingle with the actors
  8. Professional recording of the performance

Risks & Challenges

Miss Julie is developing in NYC which is an inherent risk. In the past, we have had to replace props, change the batteries of lights mid-performance and scramble to find alternate venues. Things happen and we try to be as prepared as possible. With our diverse backgrounds, we know we can find a solution to whatever arises.

Other Ways You Can Help

Miss Julie is an amazing piece that we hope a lot of people can see!

Can't attend? No problem, we know you live far away. Can't spare a dollar? Don't worry about it, we understand.

Instead, help us out by sharing this page with your family, friends, neighbors and your social network.

And that's all there is to it. From everyone at Shellscrape Theatre Co., thank you!

story:
What

Cake is a transcontinental, cross Atlantic oceanic cyberworld creation built on google docs, facetime and a seasonally shifting time difference.  

It’s is an attempt to understand how the hell you’re supposed to be comfortable naked.

It’s frosting and fluid and so much hair, just... ahh… really just everywhere. In your mouth and your butt crack. Really, it’s... it’s everywhere.

It’s been hours researching how people can fall in love with bridges.

It’s plastic wrap.

It’s is what it looks like when your sense of self is taught to you solely through rom-coms.

It may be messy.

It will be delicious.

 

Who

Cake is an international collaboration between Australian theatre artist Caitlin George and NYC based Shellscrape Theatre Company. Caitlin and Elaine Rava, Artistic Director of Shellscrape, met during their 9 months training in New York with Anne Bogart’s SITI Conservatory 2016-17. In December 2017 Caitlin returned home having plans to meet Elaine the following year for the first staging of their joint collaboration, Cake. With the assistance of Shellscrape members Brittany Partridge (Producer) and Angela Wheeler (Marketing Director), Cake will soon make its world premiere at the Melbourne Fringe Festival. 

 

The Impact

Your contribution will go towards the necessary costs of staging a show in Melbourne, Australia. This first staging will be the world premiere of Cake but in no way the end of the journey. In 2020 after further development we plan to take Cake back home to New York, whilst simultaneously mapping out it’s European Fringe Festival tour. Your support on this first major step of this project will mean we have the financial support to further the longevity of our cross-cultural collaboration and the life of this strange yet delicious slice of theatre!

 

What We Need

Our fundraising goal of $1,500 will go toward the following. As you can see our costs for this project are greater than the amount we’re asking for. The extra costs will be covered out of pocket. 

ITEM - COST $(AUD)

Festival Administration Fee - 345

Rehearsal Space Hire - 275

Performance Venue Hire - 380

Set Pieces/Construction - 240

Props/Consumables - 150

Marketing/Advertising - 160

Technician Hire - 450

TOTAL BUDGETED EXPENSES - AUD$ 2,000

 

Project expenses not included are Elaine’s international flights, domestic travel expenses and accommodation. These expenses are being paid for out of pocket and your donations will not go towards their reimbursement.

 

Note from the Playwright

Cake began in a tiny diner in Manhattan, which looked as though it hadn’t been touched since 1973. Elaine and I were meeting having searched high and low for any place open and selling doughnuts. 14th Street had failed us so we ended up in said diner. Elaine had some kind of big cookie thing and I chose for myself the biggest piece of marble baked cheesecake I’d ever seen.

Cake and I have a long standing love affair but this slice really took the biscuit. I told Elaine, a close friend and an artist I admire, “We should make a play about a woman who’s in love with a cheesecake. It doesn’t have to do with body image or anything she’s just in love with a cake.”

And dear Elaine replied, “Okay. Let's do it.”

Nearly a full year later, I’ve since moved back to Melbourne while Elaine has directed three other productions with her company, Shellscrape Theatre in New York. During this time, Cake has had many different faces, shifting and writhing about till it reached its current iteration. Throughout all its phases the overarching question has always remained rooted in love. How do we love? How are we taught to love? How do we love another completely and all consumingly yet still keep some love for ourselves? Is that even possible?

I don’t think this play has any of the answers, it’s more all of my incomprehension splattered over 50, hopefully, entertaining minutes. But it’s a very big world, so if I struggle to understand, then surely there are other people out there feeling the same thing.

Love is incomprehensible.

Maybe so is this play.

 

Risks & Challenges

This show is risky. It will definitely be going up, that much is for certain but there's no guarantees on success. No one may come. We may not break even. Elaine could get lost at LAX trying to find her connecting flight and spend the rest of her days living somewhere between Terminal 1 and reality. This is also the first full play I've written AND our first time at Melbourne Fringe. But in spite of it all, we've kept going. And now, we're so close I can almost taste that sweet sweet frosting! I'm confident that we'll be able to manage any catastrophes we face.

I'll just get Elaine a map or something. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Cake is an amazing piece that we hope a lot of people can see!

Can't attend? No problem, we know you live far away. Can't spare a dollar? Don't worry about it, we've been there too. 

Instead, help us out by sharing this page with your family, friends, neighbors and your social network.

And that's about all there is to it!

 

From everyone at Shellscrape Theatre Co.

THANK YOU

Cake is an amazing piece that we hope a lot of people can see!
Can't attend? No problem, we know you live far away. Can't spare a dollar? Don't worry about it, we've been there too.

And that's about all there is to it!
 
From everyone at Shellscrape Theatre Co.
THANK YOU

story:
DPR DANCE- a different kind of dance company

DPR Dance was created out of the passion of its director: Dougie Robbins. With 3 nominations for his work on musical productions in the last three-years, Dougie knew that creating a platform for himself as an emerging artist and storyteller was essential. This year, while dancing at the historic Jacob's Pillow, he came to the realization that his passion for theater dance (the kind of dancing you see in Musicals) was unique within the dance world. He realized that the greater dance community, including audiences who see dance, aren't exposed to  theater dance- and his mission became clear. He set out to create a Theater-Dance driven company to bring theater dance from the musical stage and into festivals, concert stages and educational centers. He quickly found that his idea was in fact NEEDED in the dance community when he was asked to join the Emerging Choreographer Series in NYC alongside 8 choreographers. He was the only, and first, theater-dance choreographer to present work at this primarily modern dance organization. 

     Rooted in the American Jazz tradition of Jack Cole, DPR Dance is the only dance company keeping this heritage alive. Using his ground breaking technique as  foundation, DPR Dance creates dance that tells stories that entertain, uplift, and move the audience. DPR Dance is a firm believer in the power of community, and strives to give back to the community whenever possible, teaching guest and master classes to young and experienced dancers alike.

For more information about DPR Dance, its mission satement, and past and future projects, please visit: https://www.dougierobbins.com/upcoming-performances

 

Your Support Counts!

Still in our first year of development, NOW is when you're support matters most! It is essential that we have the resources to produce quality dance programs.  Our first, fledging, performances will become how we are identified and  defined. YOU'RE donations will help us to achieve the best quality in all aspects of dance creation specifically the THREE D's: DANCERS, DESIGNERS, and DEVELOPMENT.

You are not alone in donating:

DPR Dance has been very lucky, passionate and supportive producers have already donated some wonderful gifts to our cause! The following have been donated to us as payment in-kind:

Performance Space, Costumes,  and Artist Housing.

We are excited to announce that the stage has been donated by the Cortland Repertory Theater! Here is a photo of our space:

http://www.cortlandrep.org

 

What project does this campaign fund?

This project funds an evening length work to take place at Cortland Repertory Theatre in late 2018 or early 2019. The piece is entitled, "Boardwalk", and tells the story of a gang of young teenagers in the 1950's. Using dance and theatrical story telling, we watch as two of the male gang members compete for the attention of one female. Using popular music from the late fifties and early sixties, featuring the music of artists such as Ben E. Goodman and the Supremes, the cast of rowdy and lovable characters serves an uplifting slice of Americana for audiences of all ages to enjoy. This piece explores themes of romance, jealousy and the social expectations of American Women in the 1950's.

 

Where does your donation go?

While having a donated performance space is an incredible gift, most of our expenses occur long before we hit the stage! This campaign helps us to subsidize:

Space Costs: rehearsal space in New York City is our single biggest cost

Casts Costs: hiring quality dancers and designers 

Producing new works and educational programs

Music Licensing: we have to pay to gain permission to use an artist's music

Designer Fees: Lighting design, sound design, stage management

Props and Sets

Travel Expenses

Thank You:

Thank you for reading or story, and for adding to our cause! By donating to DPRdance, you are helping bring the joy of dance to audiences and students alike. If you have any questions about our campaign do not hesitate to reach out to us!

story:
About Innervation Dance Cooperative:

Innervation Dance Cooperative, also known as IDC, was founded in 1998 by Michael Sherman who sought to bring together like-minded artists to collaborate and create works that entertain, engage, and inspire discussion through storytelling.  IDC strives to create original work by collaborating with artists of all backgrounds and has a focus on giving not only veterans, but new creators a platform to show their work.  This has allowed us to continue to grow into the wonderful company you see here today. You can find out more about us here: http://www.innervationdance.org/

About Movies About Animals:

Movies About Animals is a band from Chicago by way of Normal. You may listen to and learn more about them here: https://moviesaboutanimals.bandcamp.com/

Why We Need Your Help:

IDC is a 501(c)(3) non-profit performance organization. This means that we rely on outside sources and show revenue to pay for all the things needed to put on a fantastic show! These things include: rehearsal space, performance venues, educational outreach, costuming, light/sound design, and most importantly paying OUR PERFORMERS! Your contribution will go directly to the local, hardworking artists in the Chicago dance and music communities.

What does this show mean to us and why is that important?

After jumping completely out of our comfort zone last season with our sold out show, It's My Own Invention, IDC wanted to continue to look for new creative avenues to grow. RUMOURS is near and dear to all of our hearts and is something many of the collaborators involved have always wanted to create. Fleetwood Mac is such a prolific part of music and pop culture history and we all want to make sure we are able to pay proper homage to the artistry they have created. By collaborating on this particular album with Movies About Animals, IDC is bridging the gap between the fields of dance and music in an interesting way;  not only are we performing the songs live and dancing to them, we are working together to create a completely new story and sound from something so well established. In the modern arts world, dancers and musicians are often far removed from one another due to all of the fantastic technology available to us all. On this project, we are getting back to the roots of the relationship between music, dance, and the physical human beings involved in the process. We are meeting in person and creating works side by side for a truly unique experience for everyone involved.

How do we make it look so easy?

Answer? We DON'T! Putting on a live performance of any kind takes a lot of work! In this case both IDC and Movies About Animals are running into new challenges that we have otherwise never encountered. Some of these are trying to work with an entire cast and company, as well a full band's crazy schedule, making sure that we do not over step our bounds in regards to the use of or changes made to the original work, finding a balance between artistic fields so that both musicians and dancemakers feel fulfilled with the end result and SO many more.  We love what we do and are passionate about creating a community for artists of all backgrounds. This project has been both educational, and beautiful thus far!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please remember that every single dollar donated is both extremely appreciated and MATTERS! However, if you are unable to make a monetary donation at this time there are plenty of other ways you can help us make this the best season ever such as:

-A donation of goods or services for us to auction or raffle off at live events

-Following us on our social media accounts to help make us more visible. We are currently on Facebook, Twitter (InnervationDC), and Instagram (InnervationDanceCo)!

-Planning to attend or sharing upcoming live events we do throughout the season. We have one coming up in December!

-Simply SHARING this campaign with your network!

 

Thank you so much to all of you that have and continue to support us in our artistry. There are no words that convey the amount of love and gratitude we feel for you all!

Why We Need Your Help:IDC is a 501(c)(3) non-profit performance organization. This means that we rely on outside sources and show revenue to pay for all the things needed to put on a fantastic show! These things include: rehearsal space, performance venues, educational outreach, costuming, light/sound design, and most importantly paying OUR PERFORMERS! Your contribution will go directly to the local, hardworking artists in the Chicago dance and music communities.What does this show mean to us and why is that important?After jumping completely out of our comfort zone last season with our sold out show, It's My Own Invention, IDC wanted to continue to look for new creative avenues to grow. RUMOURS is near and dear to all of our hearts and is something many of the collaborators involved have always wanted to create. Fleetwood Mac is such a prolific part of music and pop culture history and we all want to make sure we are able to pay proper homage to the artistry they have created. By collaborating on this particular album with Movies About Animals, IDC is bridging the gap between the fields of dance and music in an interesting way;  not only are we performing the songs live and dancing to them, we are working together to create a completely new story and sound from something so well established. In the modern arts world, dancers and musicians are often far removed from one another due to all of the fantastic technology available to us all. On this project, we are getting back to the roots of the relationship between music, dance, and the physical human beings involved in the process. We are meeting in person and creating works side by side for a truly unique experience for everyone involved.How do we make it look so easy?Answer? We DON'T! Putting on a live performance of any kind takes a lot of work! In this case both IDC and Movies About Animals are running into new challenges that we have otherwise never encountered. Some of these are trying to work with an entire cast and company, as well a full band's crazy schedule, making sure that we do not over step our bounds in regards to the use of or changes made to the original work, finding a balance between artistic fields so that both musicians and dancemakers feel fulfilled with the end result and SO many more.  We love what we do and are passionate about creating a community for artists of all backgrounds. This project has been both educational, and beautiful thus far!
Other Ways You Can Help
Please remember that every single dollar donated is both extremely appreciated and MATTERS! However, if you are unable to make a monetary donation at this time there are plenty of other ways you can help us make this the best season ever such as:
-A donation of goods or services for us to auction or raffle off at live events
-Following us on our social media accounts to help make us more visible. We are currently on Facebook, Twitter (InnervationDC), and Instagram (InnervationDanceCo)!
-Planning to attend or sharing upcoming live events we do throughout the season. We have one coming up in December!
-Simply SHARING this campaign with your network!
 
Thank you so much to all of you that have and continue to support us in our artistry. There are no words that convey the amount of love and gratitude we feel for you all!

story:
Don’t feel bad. Also conflicted, with this dichotomy of black women popularized in movies and mass media, Shannon Dada decided to do her own research. Shannon traveled to Atlanta from California observing and engaging women from the low “hush-hush” corners of Atlanta’s notorious "West-End" to the highrise celebrity community of note, "Buckhead" for what would be Evoladad Production’s first ever all-female play documenting the complexities of diverse black in·gé·nues and their interactions. Much to Shannon’s amazement (and relief): broad was the canvas every woman shared but very fine to the tip of the brush was the strokes each woman painted of her experience. Shannon titled her findings: No Names in the Strokes of Life. “No Name” for short.

What You Can Do  

We are exactly 15 days away from our debut show, "No Name" coming February 3rd and we are breaking out of the mass-media mold with laughs because social change can be scary but cultural banter is fun!

We are 10 days away from our debut show. Please support us as we reach out to uplift women and black community. 5,000 is our goal and every contribution helps. Nothing is too small as it helps us get the message out to the women who so sorely need it. We are here to uplift, thank you ahead of time.

story:
Short Summary

Dumas Theatre is a new group of theatre professionals ready to take Seattle by storm. We aim to bring new, exciting theatre to the Seattle area. Our focus is on contemporary works that have interesting, fresh themes. We like theatre that makes you think. 

Founded in 2017, Dumas Theatre consists of Jackson Harned, Mike Klinge, and Courtney Wagner. The three of us met while studying theatre at the University of Missouri. 

Our inaugural production, CONSTELLATIONS, was held at The Pocket Theater in Seattle. We are now working to stage Sarah Ruhl’s DEAD MAN’S CELL PHONE. 

What We Need

Why do we need money?

The following are things that require money when producing a show: 

  • Rehearsal Space Rental
  • Performance Space Rental
  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Promotional Materials
  • Lots of Coffee

The Impact

We appreciate every person who supports us, no matter how big or small it may seem. Even $5 helps us pay for an hour at the rehearsal space. Or the gas to get us there. Or the posters we have to print. 

By helping us offset the cost of production, you’re helping create high-quality art. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute on this platform? That’s OK! 

Consider checking us out at facebook.com/dumastheatre OR at our new website (still a work in progress) www.dumastheatre.com

Please come see our show & thank you very much for helping us make our dreams come true. 

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Senior Thesis: I Choose To Be

    For this thesis I will be choreographing an evening-length work, demonstrating how women in our society are socially constructed and are told to live in a particular way. It will explore the social constructs of what it is to be a woman and the characteristics or qualities that are acceptable, such as; emotional, quiet, submissive, pretty, heterosexual, weak, etc. Through a variety of movement phrases constructed by the choreographer in collaboration with the dancers, this study will show a story all to familiar to women. After identifying how women are socially constructed, this piece will then show how we can break down the barriers women face and how we should be accepting of all women and how they present themselves. Ultimately the project will reveal that not one woman is the same, but still an incredible person for the characteristics and qualities that society does not necessarily identify. 

    With the money raised with this fundraiser, I plan to take a portion to pay the wonderful people who have dedicated their time to help make it happen. As of right now all people involved are volunteer. Another portion will be going towards helping produce this thesis in Atlantic City and bring it the public eye. The remainder of the funds will go to various missions located in South Jersey such as: 

  • AC Rescue Mission
  • Covenant House
  • Robins Nest
  • Womens Center (Linwood)
Any contribution is greatly appreciated no matter the amount. More than anything I want to bring awareness to the socially constructive concept of a woman’s image in our society, through the use of choreography and give back to the South Jersey arts community!

story:
What is Memorare?

  • a Roman Catholic prayer to the Blessed Virgin Mary. 
  • a new play by Steven Carl McCasland.
On a hot summer day in 1964, a young Nigerian postulant arrives at a New York City convent for refuge, prayer and a new beginning. Meanwhile, a 14-year-old black boy has been murdered by a white police officer in Harlem. The streets are raging with riots. The questions that arise in the aftermath of in the postulant's arrival will change the Sisters forever. Join acclaimed playwright Steven Carl McCasland as he draws back the curtain on a private and devout group with his bold, original play Memorare.

How can you help?

Producing a play in New York City isn't easy. And it isn't cheap, either.  Here's just a few of the things we'll need to make it happen:

  • Approximately $500 to cover the cost of costumes (eight identical habits).
  • Approximately $600 to cover the cost of scenery and props. We are striving to recreate a New York City convent from the 1960's to our best ability.
  • Rehearsal space isn't easy to come by in this city. And when you find it, it costs you a pretty penny. In order to rehearse Memorare, we'll need to spend around $1,000 on studio space alone.
  • Insurance for the space and for Actor's Equity members (this will be a showcase production) will cost approximately $450. 
  • Renting a theatre for a two-week, 14-performance run will cost approximately $5,000. This includes lighting and sound equipment, along with stock furniture to add to our set and exclusive access to the venue for our two-week booking.
  • Each actor and tech team member will require a stipend for their time and efforts on the production. We estimate needing approximately $1,500 to cover this cost.
  • Every play requires an audience. Finding them can be tricky - especially when it's a brand new play like Memorare. For that reason, we'll need to spend around $300 on publicity items - including posters and postcards. 

Why Memorare? Why now?

  • Steven Carl McCasland's critically acclaimed plays have been called "brilliant", "astonishing", "inventive", "boldly imagined". Little Wars, What Was Lost, Neat & Tidy, Der Kanarienvogel, 28 Marchant Avenue, Shades of Blue and more have been produced at nearly a dozen theatre. 
  • Memorare premiered in a sold-out reading at The Drama Book Shop to standing ovations and high acclaim.
  • There aren't a lot of new plays with roles exclusively for women. Memorare will employ EIGHT women, both union and non-union. 
  • Memorare is an original play that examines a difficult dialogue our country is having about the relationship between our police and young black men & women. We hope that it adds to the conversation and helps us continue to grow from it. 

Can't donate? You can still help! 

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help... Share, tweet, blog and e-mail about our campaign! Tell your friends and family and ask them to contribute. Tell them why you believe in Memorare and why you want to see it happen.
