story:
Creating culture. Honoring heritage.

The Trinacria Theatre Company is a summer exchange program that brings American theatre artists to Sicily for a four-week intensive residency. Our mission is to use theatre as a tool to promote Sicilian history, heritage, and culture at home and abroad. Over the summer, theatre makers study and work in the beautiful landscape of the Southern Messina region, developing an original piece of theatre based on local folklore and mythology. The final performance will be staged outdoors free of charge in various Sicilian villages, as well as for audiences in the United States. 

Who we serve

For years, the Sicilian countryside was marred by a decline in population, high unemployment rates, and economic instability. Recently, a boost in the Sicilian tourism economy has drawn renewed interest to this island of incredible natural and historic beauty. Trinacria Theatre Company hopes to continue this trend by reframing Sicily as a site of pilgrimage for artistic retreat and residency.

Company members from Boston and New York will spend four weeks in the rich landscape of Southern Messina, in the seaside villages between the cities of Messina and Catania in a region commonly referred to as Calonerò (from Greek, meaning "good water"). A group of 8 performers and theatre makers will live and work together as an ensemble to develop a piece of theatre based on local mythologies and folklore. The performance will tour to several local villages for free outdoor performances. The piece will then be performed in the United States at the end of the summer.

We believe that this residency experience will be life-changing for the theatre-makers, dreamers, and creators traveling to Sicily, but we hope that the greatest impact will be on the communities and villages of Southern Messina. The arts are the most important tool for people to share their stories, and we hope that through Trinacria Theatre Company's work, the beauty and history of the Sicilian people can be spread to the global community. Our hope is to create an annual event that draws a renewed interest in Sicilian arts, history, and culture, instills pride in the people of Southern Messina, and draws more artists to this land of extraordinary beauty.

What we need

The costs of running a theater company are high - even more so an international organization! In order to successfully operate in our first year, we are seeking to raise at least $21,000.

If we raise $21,000, we will be able to afford:

  • Housing for 9 people over 4 weeks at the P. Cuppari Institute at San Placido Calonerò, an agricultural high school in the region
  • Food and vittles for 9 people over 4 weeks (at an estimated $5 per person for breakfast, $5 per person for lunch, and $10 per person for dinner)
  • Rehearsal and performance venue space rentals in Sicily and Boston
  • A 9 person passenger van and gas for 4 weeks
  • Marketing materials, such as printed posters and digital advertising
  • Performance costs (including costumes, props, set, lighting, and sound)
  • Legal fees, incorporation, insurance, and other company overhead

If we raise $25,000, we will be able to afford:

  • Hosting a "Sagra," or food festival, for our company's opening, an important part of our mission to connect with the community
  • Materials to hold a 2 week educational theatre summer day camp for young people (ages 8 - 12) in the region
  • Improved performance venues in both the US and Italy

If we raise $36,000, we will be able to afford:

  • Round-trip airfare for all of our participants

If we raise $40,000, we will be able to afford:

  • Beginning conversion of an empty residence in Sicily into a permanent company home for future seasons

The Plan

We are looking to raise $16,000 with our IndieGogo page. We have a number of great rewards, which we hope you’ll enjoy! We are also seeking to raise $5,000 through charitable organizations to reach our $21,000 goal. If you or anyone you know works for a charitable foundation or organization that you believe would be interested in our mission, please get in touch with us at info@trinacriatheatre.com!

Risks & Challenges

We realize that this is a huge undertaking! However, we have assembled a group of determined and headstrong young company members who are prepared to deal with tough conditions and huge obstacles to make this company a reality. 

Our primary goal is to live and work for 4 weeks in Sicily and create a performance piece that will create a positive impact on our host community.  If we are unable to afford rent at our host site, we plan to "rough it" with sleeping bags and air mattresses, rather than living in the comfort of the P. Cuppari Institute.

Without adequate funding, we will be forced to cut such important programs as our educational theatre camp for Sicilian children, hosting a "Sagra" or food festival to connect with our communities, and creating a short documentary film piece about our host site, the Enoteca Provinciale Messina. Nevertheless, as they say in the business, "the show will go on!" Every dollar that you donate to the Trinacria Theatre company will go towards funding this summer's work, and even if we have to scrimp and scrape, we are determined to create impactful and positive art for communities that need it most.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word to anyone you know who might be interested in our work - direct them to our IndieGogo campaign, or simply direct them to our website, www.trinacriatheatre.com. 
Come see our show! Whether you live in Sicily or the States, we hope to provide accessible, affordable performances in both English and Italian. Keep an eye on our website for updates on our future performance dates!
We will also gladly accept any in-kind donations of supplies, materials, equipment, or anything else. Space rentals eat up a huge portion of our budget, and so we are always grateful for anyone who will open their doors to us and allow us to rehearse or perform at a discounted cost. We would also greatly appreciate donations of Italian language learning tools, textbooks, or workbooks. Loans of audio equipment, such as speakers and microphones, are also greatly appreciated.

story:
EYE HIGH THEATRE are currently working on a new experimental show 'No Longer A Secret' based on the 'The Secret Garden' by Frances Hodgson Burnett. The show will take place as part of the 2016 Edinburgh Fringe Festival and will be performed at theSpaceUK from the 22nd - 27th August. 


You are all invited to come and enjoy the show!


ABOUT:

EYE HIGH THEATRE is a new London-based theatre company founded by Grace Lambert & Grace Strickland de Souza. We use an unconventional and experimental style that looks to re-work classic texts; blurring the lines between artistic disciplines and creating aesthetically and atmospherically innovative work.

Through our work we are committed to pushing the boundaries, for example previous shows have included blindfolding actors, spontaneous Charleston dancing, playing in paint and water and performing illusions. 'No Longer A Secret' will be our first ever fringe show and we want the chance to continue surprising and challenging you through our work.


PRODUCTION: 

'No Longer A Secret' investigates identity, mortality and the dehumanisation of the individual. It is inspired by Frances Hodgson Burnett's 'The Secret Garden' and told through the nostalgic eyes of an old man as he waits in his hospital bed. This deconstructed re-telling is woven throughout with lessons, and questions, original music and a transformative garden. 

The show was formed as part of a collaborative project involving MA Performance Design and Practice students from Central Saint Martins and other creative artists. We believe it is important to provide a platform for talented individuals through our work.

Classic British texts have always been an inspiration in our work. We believe it is important to revive these stories and introduce them to new audiences in an innovative way. After months of reflection and development the show is now ready to enter the rehearsal period and ultimately it will debut at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.


BUDGET:

In order to make the show a success, your support is crucial. We are looking for funding to help with: accommodation, transport, marketing and production costs. We would be extremely grateful for any support you can offer us. Your generosity will not only be helping to establish our theatre company, but also showcase other artists, composers, writers and designers with whom we will be collaborating. 
We are looking to raise a total of £7000. BUT by breaking this down into 3 smaller amounts, we meet our targets and deadlines as they arrive. 

Phase 1 - £3000 Venue, Accommodation, Transport
Phase 2 - £2000 Venue, Marketing & Production Costs
Phase 3 - £2000 Venue, Production Costs 


THE TEAM: 

Artistic Director: Grace Lambert 
Grace spent 3 years studying Music and Drama at Bath Spa University graduating with a First Class (Hons) degree. She is now currently completing an MA in Performance Design and Practice at Central Saint Martins, University of the Arts London. Grace has previously worked with Brighton Theatre on 'Vlad the Impaler' and frequently collaborates with music video director Jackson Ducasse filming for a variety of artists: Icarus, Rob Bravery, Alex Maxwell. 


Artistic Director: Grace Strickland de Souza 
After studying Drama for 3 years at Bath Spa University, Grace went on to study screen acting at CAPA in Sheffield and advanced acting at the Merseyside Acadamy of Drama. Alongside directing, she has also acted in various stage and screen productions: 'Macbeth', Harlen Coban's 'The Five' and 'Billy Elliott: The Musical'. Grace is also a fashion blogger and experimental musician. 


Writer: Astara Cambata 
Astara graduated from Bath Spa University with a degree in Creative Writing and Drama Studies. She wrote and produced a play 'The Hive' for the Bath Fringe Festival '14. She now lives and works in London having recently worked alongside Shunt and Coney. 


Technical Director/Lighting Designer: Berta Pibernat
Berta has previously worked in San Francisco on several productions in community theatre such as 'The Learned Ladies', 'Tenderloin' and adaptations of Hemingway. She has also worked with dance companies such as Applegate, Joffrey, Ballet School/ Alonzo King Ballet School. She is now based in London studying an MA in Performance Design and Practice at Central Saint Martins. She is also an experienced programmer who has collaborated with several professionals including Tony Award Winning Lighting Designer Christopher Akerlind. 


Composer: Ruari Metcalfe 
Ruari studied Music at Bath Spa University where he was the inaugural winner of the Bath Spa Graduation Composition competition in 2013. As a composer and arranger Ruari has an adaptable style which lends itself to the world of film and theatre having previously worked on a variety of independent films.  


Set & Costume Designer: Sha Lu  
Sha (Sasha) studied as a Costume Designer and Maker at London College of Fashion graduating with a First Class degree. She has designed for numerous shows: DEJA BLUEZ X Central Saint Martins (Panarmonion Bar and Stage); The Macropulos Case (the Central Saint Martins Studio Theatre); The Horrible Pet Store (China Joy 2014); Not Now, Bernard (Unicorn Theatre);  4.48 Psychosis (To be confirmed). Sha is currently a London based designer and is continuing her studies at Central Saint Martins: MA Performance Design and Practice.

Illustrator: Ella Strickland de Souza 
Ella is a freelance illustrator and artist currently based in London. 
http://cargocollective.com/elladesouza


OTHER WAYS TO HELP: 

Keep spreading the word! Forward the details of our show to your friends and family and share this campaign. For more information follow us on social media. 

Twitter & Intagram: @eyehightheatre or like us on Facebook by searching Eye High Theatre.

Thank you, 

From all of us at EYE HIGH THEATRE

This show means a lot to us and we cannot wait for you to see it!
story_txt:
EYE HIGH THEATRE are currently working on a new experimental show 'No Longer A Secret' based on the 'The Secret Garden' by Frances Hodgson Burnett. The show will take place as part of the 2016 Edinburgh Fringe Festival and will be performed at theSpaceUK from the 22nd - 27th August. You are all invited to come and enjoy the show!ABOUT:
EYE HIGH THEATRE is a new London-based theatre company founded by Grace Lambert & Grace Strickland de Souza. We use an unconventional and experimental style that looks to re-work classic texts; blurring the lines between artistic disciplines and creating aesthetically and atmospherically innovative work.Through our work we are committed to pushing the boundaries, for example previous shows have included blindfolding actors, spontaneous Charleston dancing, playing in paint and water and performing illusions. 'No Longer A Secret' will be our first ever fringe show and we want the chance to continue surprising and challenging you through our work.PRODUCTION: 'No Longer A Secret' investigates identity, mortality and the dehumanisation of the individual. It is inspired by Frances Hodgson Burnett's 'The Secret Garden' and told through the nostalgic eyes of an old man as he waits in his hospital bed. This deconstructed re-telling is woven throughout with lessons, and questions, original music and a transformative garden. The show was formed as part of a collaborative project involving MA Performance Design and Practice students from Central Saint Martins and other creative artists. We believe it is important to provide a platform for talented individuals through our work.Classic British texts have always been an inspiration in our work. We believe it is important to revive these stories and introduce them to new audiences in an innovative way. After months of reflection and development the show is now ready to enter the rehearsal period and ultimately it will debut at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival.BUDGET:In order to make the show a success, your support is crucial. We are looking for funding to help with: accommodation, transport, marketing and production costs. We would be extremely grateful for any support you can offer us. Your generosity will not only be helping to establish our theatre company, but also showcase other artists, composers, writers and designers with whom we will be collaborating. We are looking to raise a total of £7000. BUT by breaking this down into 3 smaller amounts, we meet our targets and deadlines as they arrive. Phase 1 - £3000 Venue, Accommodation, TransportPhase 2 - £2000 Venue, Marketing & Production CostsPhase 3 - £2000 Venue, Production Costs THE TEAM: Artistic Director: Grace Lambert Grace spent 3 years studying Music and Drama at Bath Spa University graduating with a First Class (Hons) degree. She is now currently completing an MA in Performance Design and Practice at Central Saint Martins, University of the Arts London. Grace has previously worked with Brighton Theatre on 'Vlad the Impaler' and frequently collaborates with music video director Jackson Ducasse filming for a variety of artists: Icarus, Rob Bravery, Alex Maxwell. Artistic Director: Grace Strickland de Souza After studying Drama for 3 years at Bath Spa University, Grace went on to study screen acting at CAPA in Sheffield and advanced acting at the Merseyside Acadamy of Drama. Alongside directing, she has also acted in various stage and screen productions: 'Macbeth', Harlen Coban's 'The Five' and 'Billy Elliott: The Musical'. Grace is also a fashion blogger and experimental musician. Writer: Astara Cambata Astara graduated from Bath Spa University with a degree in Creative Writing and Drama Studies. She wrote and produced a play 'The Hive' for the Bath Fringe Festival '14. She now lives and works in London having recently worked alongside Shunt and Coney. Technical Director/Lighting Designer: Berta PibernatBerta has previously worked in San Francisco on several productions in community theatre such as 'The Learned Ladies', 'Tenderloin' and adaptations of Hemingway. She has also worked with dance companies such as Applegate, Joffrey, Ballet School/ Alonzo King Ballet School. She is now based in London studying an MA in Performance Design and Practice at Central Saint Martins. She is also an experienced programmer who has collaborated with several professionals including Tony Award Winning Lighting Designer Christopher Akerlind. Composer: Ruari Metcalfe Ruari studied Music at Bath Spa University where he was the inaugural winner of the Bath Spa Graduation Composition competition in 2013. As a composer and arranger Ruari has an adaptable style which lends itself to the world of film and theatre having previously worked on a variety of independent films.  Set & Costume Designer: Sha Lu  Sha (Sasha) studied as a Costume Designer and Maker at London College of Fashion graduating with a First Class degree. She has designed for numerous shows: DEJA BLUEZ X Central Saint Martins (Panarmonion Bar and Stage); The Macropulos Case (the Central Saint Martins Studio Theatre);  The Horrible Pet Store (China Joy 2014); Not Now, Bernard (Unicorn Theatre);  4.48 Psychosis (To be confirmed). Sha is currently a London based designer and is continuing her studies at Central Saint Martins: MA Performance Design and Practice.Illustrator: Ella Strickland de Souza Ella is a freelance illustrator and artist currently based in London. http://cargocollective.com/elladesouzaOTHER WAYS TO HELP: Keep spreading the word! Forward the details of our show to your friends and family and share this campaign. For more information follow us on social media. Twitter & Intagram: @eyehightheatre or like us on Facebook by searching Eye High Theatre.Thank you, From all of us at EYE HIGH THEATREThis show means a lot to us and we cannot wait for you to see it!

story:
"We Happy Few Productions makes a great case for revisiting the golden oldies. This theater troupe . . . makes the words from bygone eras feel fresh and urgent." -DCist names We Happy Few one of The Best Small Theater Companies in DC

We Happy Few is excited to produce CHALK this summer at Capitol Hill Arts Workshop Washington DC. 

We Happy Few Productions was founded by Hannah Todd and Raven Bonniwell in 2012. Our mission is to provide unique perspectives on classic texts by presenting
stripped down, small cast, ensemble productions with a group of talented artists. We have since had the good fortune to produce five well-received shows: Hamlet, The Tempest, Romeo & Juliet, The Duchess of Malfi, and The Winter's Tale.  For this exciting new production, we are excited to welcome Kerry McGee as director.

Kerry has been a part of We Happy Few since 2014 when she joined the company as Marketing Director.  Last year, Kerry showed her versatility by performing the roles of Perdita and Autolycus in The Winter's Tale.  She is no stranger to the directing world as has directed multiple shows in Richmond, Virginia.  Her production of The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity won the Richmond Theatre Critics Circle Award for Best Ensemble in 2014.

"Interesting and hyper-watchable" - Washington Post

WHF is drawn to the legend of The Chalk Circle because, like the Shakespeare texts that we frequently produce, the story is as relevant now as when it was written.  We are surrounded by a chaotic world: war, terrorism, inequality, refugees, uprisings, corruption, wall street, main street, corporations and politicians trying to buy our loyalty or appeal to our ideals.  And yet amidst all of this turmoil, we have to find a way to survive and love.  As WHF's first major adaptation project, we are excited to dig through the wealth of source material and find the ideas that continue to resonate, and to tell them in our distinct stripped-down, fast-paced style.

At its simplest, Chalk is a story of motherhood.  A wise judge draws a chalk circle on the ground to determine the true mother of a contested child.  However, it's also a story about about revolution and rebellion.  It's about the choices we are forced to make for ourselves, for our families and for the causes we believe in.  It's about the working class and the wealthy, justice and family, duty and survival.  In a ever-changing world where nothing is black and white, how can we judge what's right?

"... filled with fantastic actors breathing life and complexity into each line." - Washington City Paper

This summer, we have decided to increase our overall production budget in order to better compensate our artists.  We believe that it is critical to invest in our people, as they are some of the most talented and hard working artists in the industry.  For this reason, we're looking to raise just over $12,000 for this summer's production. 

How is the money spent? Great question.  Here is a breakdown of expenses for this particular production:
Performance Space Insurance: $350
Marketing: $1,000
Costumes: $300
Set: $300
Props: $100
Printing costs: $200
Director stipend: $600
Stage Management team: $900 (total)
Actor Stipends: $4,200 (total)
Designer Stipends: $1,850 (total)
Production team stipends: $2,500

As you can see, our goal for this indie-go-go campaign is just $5,000, but we could use a lot more than that!  $5,000 will pay for Actor & Director stipends and printing costs.  Any amount over that goes to the rest of the budget.

Thank you for your trust in our artistic vision, your continued support of our mission and for supporting this production of CHALK.


Special Thanks to Arnel Sancianco for our awesome graphic design!


We Happy Few Productions is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a nonprofit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of We Happy Few Productions must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
HOW WE CAME HOME is a bedtime story for a modern, cynical audience, inviting us to once again be children, to once again explore the world through a lens of bright colors and beautiful music and soaring love stories. It is a story of love against all odds, of real human connection, of fairy tale love, and of unconventional family.

It is a story for you.

About the story.

How We Came Home is written and directed by Jay Jacobson, a sophomore at Bard College. It is set to a brand new score composed by Bard senior Theo Lowrey, featuring a set designed by Bard senior Izzy Bump and a choreographed ballet number by Bard sophomore Lila Klaus. It is a collaborative effort between these amazing creative forces and its amazing ten-person cast.

It tells the story of Louisa, 12-year old daughter of Ellie and Clara, a small family living in NYC. When Louisa suddenly stops speaking to them, Ellie begins weaving together the story of how Ellie and Clara met into the fabric of fantastical bedtime stories: one night, they're battling a Trickster in an enchanted forest; another night, they're lost in an underworld that seems to go on forever.

As these stories progress, the underlying truth begins to shine through, and exploring the fractured relationship between Louisa  and her mothers becomes the focus of the play. It asks us to examine how storytelling can heal, how storytelling can bring us together, how storytelling can challenge and uplift. It asks us to leave our lives behind for a couple of hours and sit by the bed and listen.

About the campaign.

The good news is that one (possibly two!) student-run organizations on campus will be helping us fund this show. The bad news is that even this doesn't leave us with enough money to bring this incredibly gorgeous show to life. To give you a quick idea of the aesthetic we're aiming for, the set is comprised of a hyper-realistic bedroom complete with an actual bed, real furniture, three walls, and a functional door. This base set will be complemented by pink chiffon that will be hung, draped, flung, presented, coiled, and placed all over the theatre, and which will be lit from below by LED lights to change mood. If we reach our goal, we will even be able to suspend working bedroom lamps in exciting and interesting ways all throughout the space. AND, if we reach a stretch goal of $1500, we will send a download link for a recording of Theo Lowrey's score to each of our donors!

About your contributions.

Thank you so much for whatever contributions you can make! Donations, spreading the word (posting this link to FaceBook, whispering about the play into the void) all are invaluable and will help both the growth of an individual artist (me!) and the completion of a project that is bringing together a wonderful group of artists who are striving to create something beautiful and touching and important.

Frankie would like everyone to know that they were very nervous for the filming of this video, and are usually more charismatic and happy! I can verify this statement.

story:
Short Summary

The Wild At Heart is a Tennessee William triple bill made up of three of his short plays:

Perfect Analysis Given by a Parrot, Hello From Bertha and Portrait of a Madonna.

We are a collaboration of two theatre companies made up of young theatre professionals called StepbyStep Productions and Simple Life Productions. We have a strong ambition to create authentic theatre through asking bold questions about life, people and how the human being thinks and behaves and therefore Tennessee Williams’s work is of a great interest to us. 

We are going to create a Southern American evening, with a live band of six musicians playing blues and jazz. The band will be playing as people are entering and then go into a Tennessee Williams short play, then there will be an interval where the band plays and people can go to the bar and have a drink,followed by two more short plays with the band playing gently in between each play.

 There would be a bar in the theatre area serving themed drinks, cocktails and light snacks. The bar tenders and the band would all be dressed in the theme of the 40’s,  so that the audience never leave the impression of "the south" from entering the venue. Then the music and the plays will just gently flow into each other and it would all gather up into a totality of the world of Tennessee Williams.  

We are putting it on at the Hornsey Town Hall Arts Centre in Crouch End, London, doing eight performances between the 21st November - 4th December. They have a beautiful space called The Supper Room, which is a very '1940’s cabaret club' looking space with a stage and a bar.


What We Need & What You Get

- In total for the project we need 10.000. The 3500 we are seeking through Indiegogo are exclusively to pay our actors and musicians for their hard work! We believe that by creating a fair, professional working environment, everyone's experience of the project; actors' as well as audiences, will be so much better than it otherwise would be. Therefore we are not willing to put up a production where this factor is ignored and your help is absolutely vital!

- In return for your generous support we have listed a few different perks, ranging from a big thank you, to tickets and drinks and all the way to 'executive producer' credits! All donations, big and small, will go towards the goal of making the industry of entertainment a fair place for people to work in and enjoy. On top of that you will help bringing to life three pieces of incredible work by the one and only Tennessee Williams!



The Impact 

- We are a group of young and ambitious theatre makers with a strong drive to succeed. We have within the last year put on and contributed to four different theatre projects and two film projects, including sartre's No Way Out at the Canal Café Theatre in Little Venice and we are currently putting on a brand new Icelandic play at The Drayton Arms Theatre in South-Kensington to be premiered on the 22nd of October 2015. 

- With a little bit of help from our friends the future is bright and we believe we have a lot to contribute to the world of theatre and entertainment and are very excited about the coming year, which we see as an opportunity to prove that we can stand by that statement!

 


Risks & Challenges

- The main challenge in this world is finances (right?)! You can be the most talented, ambitious, intelligent person there is, but the truth is, without the cash it's hard work! Starting out is the trickiest bit, because people trust what they know and if they don't know you it's hard to gain their trust. Having secured the rights to stage these three diamonds of theatre we feel that we have the most amazing opportunity now to create the track record we need. All we need to do is to catch people's attention and get them to join  in on the joy! Any amounts we might receive above our set goal will go towards dressing up the venue and sourcing the best costumes possible, adding to the detail and magic, to make YOUR experience closer to perfection!



Other Ways You Can Help

- Having said this, you can help us in so many other ways then contributing money. Give us hand getting the word out by making noise about this campaign (please note the Indiegogo share tools - go social media crazy!), or by letting people know what's coming (the show itself) and simply by looking forward to come to see it yourself!

- Please be in touch if you have any ideas and/or questions. After all 'Life is partly what we make it, and partly what it is made by the friends we choose'!

story:
'Blood Wedding' will be the debut live performance of this young company. We need any support we can get to raise funds for its performance on 14th January at 'Resolutions' dance festival at  "The Place" 2016. 

"Two lovers destined for lives apart.Their yearning will distort their fate, awakening those hungry for death..."

Loosely inspired by Federico García Lorca's tragedy 'Blood Wedding', this work explores a sensual and dynamic synthesis of Contemporary and Latin American partnering to explore Lorca's dark poetry.

The company consists of dancers Carmine De Amicis, Harriet Waghorn and Nacho Garoz, and musician Sergio Jaraiz. Any money raised will go to funding the project.

We have some fantastic PERKS available in exchange for your donations. Including group and private Ballroom/Latin American or Contemporary lessons, 1hr massage sessions, 1hr PT sessions, the chance to come and take company class with Edifice or a printed image of Edifice's latest work... check them out!

story:
Short Summary

We're a not-for-profit theatre company whose main focus is to engage and educate through the arts. We focus on both the positive and negative impacts of historical figures and events in order to promote critical thought on history within our audiences, with a fun musical twist!

What We Need & What You Get

Your funding would go towards artist fees and production costs for any of our three major projects we're looking at doing for 2016: the eastern Ontario School Tour, our summer outdoor theatre show, or historical residencies in which we inhabit and re-animate a historic building! All of these projects promote and encourage community engagement through the arts. Our work has been given much acclaim, including positive reviews, testimonials, and feedback from past audiences. We hope to continue to bring our historical, musical-comedy style of performance to audiences once again in 2016, but can only do so with your support!

The Impact

This will be the 5th summer of our outdoor show, which was rated as the #1 tour/attraction for Kingston on TripAdvisor this past summer. Bringing the show back will continue to animate Kingston's downtown core, benefiting the summer tourist season and students in camps. We have also completed 3 highly successful cross-Canadian tours, and cannot wait to bring our performances to a local audience so local schools can experience professional productions that have been developed and presented across the country. The residencies will help highlight and restore importance to historic buildings in both Ontario and across Canada, helping communities engage with their past and bring it to life again. These projects will span across a great number of communities and will help bring learning through the arts to the forefront of 2016!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please feel free to share on your social media platforms, check out our website or Youtube channel, and use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out so we can bring a great year of programming to Kingston, Ontario and Canada!
story_txt:
Short Summary We're a not-for-profit theatre company whose main focus is to engage and educate through the arts. We focus on both the positive and negative impacts of historical figures and events in order to promote critical thought on history within our audiences, with a fun musical twist!   What We Need & What You Get Your funding would go towards artist fees and production costs for any of our three major projects we're looking at doing for 2016: the eastern Ontario School Tour, our summer outdoor theatre show, or historical residencies in which we inhabit and re-animate a historic building! All of these projects promote and encourage community engagement through the arts. Our work has been given much acclaim, including positive reviews, testimonials, and feedback from past audiences. We hope to continue to bring our historical, musical-comedy style of performance to audiences once again in 2016, but can only do so with your support!
    The Impact This will be the 5th summer of our outdoor show, which was rated as the #1 tour/attraction for Kingston on TripAdvisor this past summer. Bringing the show back will continue to animate Kingston's downtown core, benefiting the summer tourist season and students in camps. We have also completed 3 highly successful cross-Canadian tours, and cannot wait to bring our performances to a local audience so local schools can experience professional productions that have been developed and presented across the country. The residencies will help highlight and restore importance to historic buildings in both Ontario and across Canada, helping communities engage with their past and bring it to life again. These projects will span across a great number of communities and will help bring learning through the arts to the forefront of 2016!

    Other Ways You Can Help Please feel free to share on your social media platforms, check out our website or Youtube channel, and use the Indiegogo share tools to get the word out so we can bring a great year of programming to Kingston, Ontario and Canada!

story:
About the Project

Described by the Stage as a "human exclamation mark", Total Theatre as "really special" and Synonyms for Churlish as "the performer of our generation", Christopher Brett Bailey is a UK based writer, performer and maker of experimental theatre.

His debut show THIS IS HOW WE DIE won an OffWestEnd Award, the Arches Brick Award and was nominated for a Total Theatre Award and a Civilian Theatre Award. The show was called:

‘visceral, world-burning’ Total Theatre  | 'ingenious' ★★★★★ Exeunt |
'really shocks or transforms you' ★★★★ Guardian | 'blisteringly brilliant' ★★★★ The Scotsman | 'an annihilation of the senses' ★★★★ Time Out | 'a theatrical rite of passage' A Younger Theatre | ★★★★ The Times | 'totally fucking exhilarating' Catherine Love | 'ragingly brilliant' ★★★★ TV Bomb | 'utterly absorbing' ★★★★★ Literature Without Borders | 'A beautiful maniac' SNAP REVIEWS | 'You guys, I have a new hero.' Megan Vaughan | 'balls the size of coconuts' Plays To See | 'what a fucking genius' Smiths Magazine | 'sadistically funny' Culture Whisper

Now, in 2016 Chris and his team are starting work on a brand new show that might just be the weirdest and best thing you’ll see all year. Details are hush-hush at the moment, but they are striving to make "an ambitious follow-up, something vital and beautiful that'll put hairs on your chest whether you want 'em there or not…"

Venues are in place, commissioners are signed up and the band are ready to go. But without your generous support it will not be possible to bring this new beast to life.

What Will My Money Buy?

The money you donate will be going towards the absolutely essential elements of making and premiering the show (in four UK locations in autumn 2016), in particular:
  • Fees for the musicians, lighting designer, dramaturg, producer and production manager Chris is working with to make the show happen
  • Rehearsal space in London for Chris and the team to start working
  • Some special pieces of musical and lighting equipment that need to be bought or custom made
  • Money for Chris to eat and pay his rent while he’s writing
  • Train travel, van hire and accommodation to take the show to the three venues outside of London on tour

    Risks & Challenges

    The show is being co-commissioned by four major venues in different parts of the UK - Ovalhouse (London), Theatre in the Mill (Bradford), Cambridge Junction, Theatr Iolo (Cardiff) - who are all generously contributing alongside you. Producer Beckie Darlington has many years of experience making shows like this happen and you can trust that she knows how to wrangle a budget. Hopefully this makes you feel like your money is in safe hands. Should you ever have any doubts though, please do get in touch with Chris directly on 07900931114

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you’re broke but still want to help you can do so by spreading this link far and wide, preaching the gospel to all your friends.  The team are also on the lookout for cheap / free band rehearsal space in London, the guts of an old piano, scrap metal, drums, cymbals, unwanted amplifiers and PA speakers (the large + very loud variety only please)... if you know of any of these please do get in touch!

      With love and thanks from the bottom of our goddamned hearts,
      Christopher Brett Bailey and team
      Xx.

story:
Joan Jeanrenaud:
Musician, composer, cellist of the Kronos Quartet for 20 years.

Charlie Varon:
Award-winning playwright and performer, resident artist at The Marsh.

David Ford:
San Francisco’s leading director of solo theater.


Charlie and Joan, working under David's direction, are adapting Charlie’s new short story, "Second Time Around," into a fully-scored duet for cello and storyteller. This form is something new for all three of us. 

About the story:
A high school student brings a video camera to the retirement home where 92-year-old Ben Rosenau lives. He’s come to interview Ben about his service as a bomber pilot in World War II.

      Charlie says: “Much of the story occurs inside Ben’s mind – his memories, his regrets, his yearnings. My quest to put all this onstage led me to the cello – the instrument which, like no other, can express the interior life of human beings. And that led me to Joan.”



When will the show open?

We're doing our first public performance at The Marsh SF on Nov 18, 2015. The finished work will premiere at The Marsh in March 2016.



that will help give this work to the world! 

We've already raised over $10,000  -- including grants from the Fleishhacker and Zellerbach foundations. To get to opening we need another $30K.

Your donation funds artists to create new work. 
We're devoting hundreds of hours to writing, composing and rehearsing. That's where 70% of your donation will go. Another 20% goes to production, marketing, and publicity. 10% goes to The Marsh.

If we exceed our goal... 
Additional funds raised will be used to create a top-quality live audio recording of the work, so it can be downloaded or streamed by anyone with a computer, and to increase our budget for marketing and publicity.


Thanks to Indiegogo and The Marsh, you get a tax deduction for your contribution (less the value of any perks).

Joan, Charlie and David are all veteran artists with thousands of appreciative fans out there. You can help us reach those fans. Email your friends and encourage them to be part of this campaign, post it on Facebook, and talk it up!

story:
Domestic violence continues to be an issue affecting people of all backgrounds in our communities. January 14, 2016, is opening night of, Nobody Knows You as I Do,  a powerful play that addresses this subject.  This worldwide premiere was written by award winning and renowned Catalan playwrite/director Roger Peña Carulla.  To make it accessible for everyone, each performance will be presented in Spanish with English subtitles.

The author,  was inspired by the incredible amount of domestic violence depicted in the news. That was the catalyst that propelled him to write this powerful piece that dissects the mind  and brings to light the conflicts of both victim and perpetrator.

press/media interview in spanish

We are the producers and the cast of, Nobody Knows You as I Do: Alberto Mateo    ,web site, and Paulina Galvez ,  web site, owner of CUZ CUZ PRODUCTIONS, both actors from Spain currently living in South Florida and working on television, films and in the theater.  Our director is the talented, Lilo Vilaplana,web site, who has a huge experience in TV as a director of successful TV series in Colombia (El Capo, FOX) and Miami (Dueños del paraiso, Telemundo NBC), Films and theater. 

We have a terrific composer working in the original score, Luis Delgado,  check his web site here! Luis Delgado Web Site.


We also have the support of the  CCE, Cultural Center of Spain, in Miami, who is co-producing the play with us and providing the rehearsal space as well as the performance venue.


Our play, Nobody Knows You as I Do, will run from January 14th to January 23rd, 2016 at the Miami-Dade County On Stage Black Box Theater.  We will also film this production for educational purposes, use at universities and media requests. We think that not only will it be educational but entertaining as well. We would like to do a university tour in the state of Florida and the rest of the USA and we will bring it through the Spanish Cultural Center  to  Latin America where the domestic violence is an urgent issue that needs to be addressed.

5% of the profits from the performances in Miami will go to Safespace Foundation, web site, a nonprofit association who provides emergency support for women and children at risk of being victims of domestic violence in Florida.


What we need

We have already secured the venue.  The actors, directors, and the rest of the crew are giving our time and effort with no pay before we get paid through the tickets profit, but we need to raise $3,000 in order to bring the production, Nobody Knows You as I Do,  to the stage the way we dream it. Here is a breakdown of what we need to pay for:

100% - Will fund the materials for building the set, buy  the props, print the flyers, posters and playbills, promotional expenses in radio and newspapers,  and record the sound effects and original music. Here is a detailed breakdown of our expenses;

$350  stain steel medical bed with wheels. 

$440  pay bill (1,500 units).

$100  flyers (5,000 units).

$200 posters (50).

$250 newspaper advertising.

$600 radio advertising.

$230 background white curtain.

$60 medical instrumental.

$110 chair.

$40 white sheet.

$170 build panel.

$150 rent medical furniture.

$300 studio for sound recording.

Maybe you are asking, what happen to my money if they don´t reach the goal? If by any chance we don´t reach our entire goal, no worries! the show will go on anyway!

Other ways you can help

We understand that not everyone can contribute due to their financial situation.  The next best way to support us is to help get the word out! Or buy a ticket for the show and join us for, Nobody Knows You as I Do! at ticketmaster.

Please share our campaign with family and friends via Facebook and Twitter.


ESPAÑOL

La violencia doméstica sigue siendo un problema que afecta a personas de todos los orígenes y estratos sociales. EL 14 de enero del 2016, es el estreno mundial de Nadie te conoce como yo, una poderosa obra de teatro que aborda este tema. Escrita por el galardonado y reconocido dramaturgo catalán / director Roger Peña Carulla. Para que sea  accesible para todo el público, la obra se presentará en español con subtítulos en inglés.

entrevista en El nuevo Herald sobre el proyecto

El autor,  motivado por la increíble cantidad de violencia doméstica denunciada en las noticias,  escribió esta poderosa obra que indaga en la mente y  los conflictos de la víctima y el agresor.

Quienes somos


Somos los co productores y  elenco de Nadie te conoce como yo: Alberto Mateo web site y Paulina Gálvez  web site, de CUZ CUZ PRODUCTIONS, ambos actores de amplia trayectoria internacional.  Actualmente vivimos en el sur de la Florida y trabajamos regularmente en televisión, cine y  teatro. Nuestro director es el talentoso Lilo Vilaplana,  web site  que tiene una amplia experiencia en television, como director de series de gran éxito en Colombia ( El Capo de FOX) y Miami (Dueños del paraíso de Telemundo NBC) ademas de su trabajo en cine y teatro. 

Tenemos un compositor increíble trabajando en la música original, Luis Delgado, mira su pagina web! Luis Delgado Web Site.

Contamos con el apoyo de la CCEMIAMI, Centro Cultural de España, en Miami, web site, quienes son co productores de la obra  y nos proporcionan el espacio de ensayo, así como han facilitado el teatro donde actuaremos. Ellos son una institución sin animo de lucro que promueve la cultura hispana en el sur de la Florida.

Nuestra obra, Nadie te conoce como yo, va a presentarse en Miami a partir del 14 de  enero del 2016 en el  On Stage Black Box Theater del Miami-Dade County Auditorium. También vamos a filmar esta producción con fines educativos, para utilizarla en universidades y medios de comunicación. Pensamos que nuestro proyecto no sólo es educativo, y deja un mensaje muy positivo en el espectador sino que la puesta en escena será muy atractiva y arriesgada. Nos gustaría llevar la obra a las universidades en el estado de Florida y el resto de los EE.UU. La llevaremos a traves de los  Centros Culturales de España al resto de América Latina, donde la violencia doméstica es un hecho urgente de encarar.

El 5% de las ganancias de las actuaciones en Miami se destinará a la Fundación Safespace,  web site , una asociación sin fines de lucro que ofrece apoyo de emergencia para mujeres y niños en riesgo de ser víctimas de la violencia doméstica en Florida.

Lo que necesitamos

Ya tenemos asegurado el teatro donde nos presentaremos. Los actores, el director y el resto del equipo técnico y artístico estamos entregando nuestro trabajo sin recibir remuneración, y seremos pagados gracias a los ingresos en taquilla, pero necesitamos recaudar   $ 3.000 con el fin de llevar la producción, Nadie te conoce como yo, a los escenarios tal y como la soñamos. He aquí un desglose de lo que tenemos que pagar :

100% - se destinará a financiar los materiales para la construcción del set, imprimir los folletos, carteles y programas de mano, comprar  los elementos para la escena y grabar efectos de sonido y la música original.

$440  programa de mano (1,500 units).

$100  flyers (5,000 units).

$200 posters (50).

$250 anuncios en prensa.

$600 anuncios en radio.

$230 cortina blanca de fondo.

$60 instrumental medico.

$110 silla.

$40 sabana blanca.

$170 construir panel.

$150 alquilar mobiliario medico.

$300 estudio para grabar sonido.

Se preguntarán qué ocurre si no conseguimos la totalidad del dinero...Si no lo conseguimos, no se preocupen, el show debe continuar sea como sea!

Puedes ayudar de otras formas

Entendemos que no todo el mundo puede contribuir, debido a su situación financiera. Otra manera de apoyarnos es ayudar a correr la voz! O comprar una entrada para el espectáculo a través de ticketmaster y estar con nosotros en este viaje!

Por favor, comparte nuestra campaña con familiares y amigos a través de Facebook y Twitter.

story:
My name is Jason Maghanoy and you probably know me as a playwright, socialite, social butterfly and butterfly, all wrapped in a playwright. 

The Nails is my new play. It is a play about family. It is a play about faith. And it captures a world of freedom and extremism in all directions; love and cruelty exist within the same space here, sometimes they feel like the same thing. I wrote it while in-residence at fu-GEN and it’s going to have its premiere as part of the SummerWorks Performance Festival this coming August. The Nails is the most ambitious play that I've ever written, and I can’t express how proud I am to be sharing it with Toronto audiences this summer. My partner in all of this, director Tanya Rintoul, has put together an outstanding team of some of the most exciting emerging artists in the City of Toronto. And we'd love for you to join our Underwriters Network and help us build what we hope will be one of the best shows at the festival. 

The ask is simple: $20.

And every dollar from this campaign will go to supporting the young artists creating this work. It will go to rehearsal space, sets, costumes, marketing. And it will allow us to provide a box office share after the production that will compensate these great artists for the time, talent and amazing hard work. For your gift you’ll be listed in our program as part of our Underwriters Network AND invited to our closing night cast party, which will be, well, quite the party.  

Bottom line: working within the independent theatre scene is tough. But it’s rewarding. And in the end you kinda have to be a little bit crazy to do all of this. People ask me all the time: "Why do you write plays?” And to be honest there are so many answers: I write plays because I love creating and telling stories. I write plays because I love my city and I like the idea of my work contributing to its on-going cultural history. And I write plays because my art provides me with a sense of aliveness, that feeling that I can never live an ordinary life.

So let us know what you think. And do spread the word about our little campaign. 

In the end, you’ll be supporting some amazing people doing some amazing work. You'll be supporting us being a little bit crazy.

And honestly? It’ll be the best $20 bucks you’ll ever spend.
story_txt:
My name is Jason Maghanoy and you probably know me as a playwright, socialite, social butterfly and butterfly, all wrapped in a playwright. 
The Nails is my new play. It is a play about family. It is a play about faith. And it captures a world of freedom and extremism in all directions; love and cruelty exist within the same space here, sometimes they feel like the same thing. I wrote it while in-residence at fu-GEN and it’s going to have its premiere as part of the SummerWorks Performance Festival this coming August. The Nails is the most ambitious play that I've ever written, and I can’t express how proud I am to be sharing it with Toronto audiences this summer. My partner in all of this, director Tanya Rintoul, has put together an outstanding team of some of the most exciting emerging artists in the City of Toronto. story:
Short Summary

Keena: Unbranded was born from the experiences of its creator, Keena Ferguson Frasier now produced by Pamela Goodlow Green, this NAACP Theater Award winner for Best One-Person Show, Keena shares her truth in over ten characters she portrays on the stage. Each character rings true for those who see the show whether it is dealing with the responsibility of pro-choice, bullying, dating or finding the light at the end of a tunnel that seems endless.

Taking the show to North Carolina takes a team and to do that we need you!  Your donation helps our team get to the National Black Theater Festival and will pay for:

  • Transportation
  • Lodging and food
  • Launching a tour
  • Rehearsal space

What We Need

We need to raise $10,000 to cover all the costs to bring the team to North Carolina and make this opportunity a major success. No donation is too small.

What You Get

We have some amazing perks including a luxury car service for your next trip to and from the airport, associate producer credits, an in-home wine tasting experience and so much more. We will be announcing a couple of very cool special perks along the way. Additionally, you will be helping a show that deals with so many social issues get out into the world and inspire others.

The Impact

Sharing her experiences on stage has allowed others to be transparent and open in sharing their own journey and knowing that we are all in this together.  Unbranded holds a mirror to audiences and gives permission to step boldly into who you are truly meant to be.  Unbranded is about accepting all parts of your life journey and never allowing yourself to be put into a box or labeled, but to know that all parts of your story are important in shaping who you become.  For many who have seen the show, they have shared these sentiments.  A few quotes from past audiences are:

"I had the distinct honor to watch a TRUE ACTRESS turn and spin my whole world around. Keena Ferguson performed to the highest level!"

"The show was like pearls all strung together giving the audience bits and pieces of her life, from childhood and now mixed in Hollywood."

​

"Tonight I witnessed - experienced Keena Ferguson in her one woman show KEENA UNBRANDED The Solo Experience!!! APPLAUSE APPLAUSE APPLAUSE!!!"

"Keena is FAAAAANTASTIC!! So brave. So honest. So hilarious. So relatable. You should DEF be proud of yourself, Ms. Keena Ferguson!"

 

THANK YOU

Keena and the Unbranded team want to thank those who have donated to this campaign.  We honor ScentSational Soaps, A.M. Frasier, Alisa Banks Photography, Karim Saafir Photography, Zuri Wines, and D'Ondrae Landers for your generosity.  We could not have done this without you.

story:
My name is Hilary Chaplain, and I’m an actor, devisor, clown, physical comedian, puppeteer, and teacher. I’ve been doing mostly self-funded solo work over the past 12 years and am now embarking on a project with a gang! I’ve been granted a week long residency with Ko Fest in western Massachusetts to kick start the creation of a new show, “The Last Rat of Theresienstadt”. They'll provide us a place to stay and a rehearsal room as well as physical support. I’m excited about collaborating with a director, puppeteers, and a composer to tell a beautiful and humorous story about the relationship between a rat (played by a puppet) and a women (played by me) in the concentration camp in Terezin in Czechoslovakia where the arts were abundant and food was scarce. This story has so many parallels to what’s happening in the world today, and with the upsurge of anti-Semitism, this is a perfect story at a perfect time.

It’s kind of like a BARN RAISER! I’ve been very happy to help so many people raise their barns and now I’m RAISING MINE! Help me build my barn! Your contributions will help pay the artists, transportation, materials for props, and a few meals for this residency plus a little extra for music composition. That will get us started on a what I estimate to be a 6 month process.

We envision this project to expand into teaching opportunities in collaboration with survivors of the holocaust as well as other marginalized populations. We’re creating a story about an inter-species relationship where both sides learn to not only trust each other, but learn from, support, and love each other. And it’s a comedy!

With Artistic New Directions as my fiscal sponsor and long time supporter, your tax-deductible contributions,will go to the following (anything over our goal will go towards the ongoing project, so don't stop when it hits $8,000!):

Artist fees:           $6000

Transportation:     $300

Materials:              $1500

Meals:                       $200

Total:                      $8000

My amazing team includes these artists:

Director - Nancy Smithner is a performer, teacher and director. She has been teaching Physical Theatre, Acting, Mime and Directing for the Program in Educational Theatre since 1986. She has also taught at many other venues such as Tisch School of the Arts; Playwrights Horizons, Circle in the Square Theatre School, School for Movement Research, the New York Dance Intensive, the Berkshire Theatre Festival and Soongsil University in Seoul, Korea. Recent directing credits include The Eumenides by Aeschylus, Mad Forest by Caryl Churchill, (m)body: Provocative Acts, an original performance work on cultural interpretations of the body, A Midsummer Night's Dream, and Godspell. Her company, The Ensemble of Movement Theatre, performs original works, most recently "...suddenly there came a tapping...", a retelling of Poe's The Raven at the Storytelling Series at the Provincetown Playhouse.

Puppeteer - Jason Hicks, Trashville, is a self-taught puppeteer, trombone player, print maker, & agitator.   With fellow conspirators, for the last 15 years, he has been building & writing undocumented puppet shows of all sizes for all spaces and situations with the purpose of undermining the machines of destruction put on us by modern life.  Hicks co-founded the RPM Puppet conspiracy (2001-present), The Flying Donkey Theater (2009-present) the Semi-Upright Puppet Collective (2005-Present), the Boxcutter Cabaret and has worked for the Bread & Puppet Theater as a puppeteer and the band leader for the past decade, writing, building & touring puppet shows around the US and overseas.  He began working with Papel Machete in 2012 in NYC and Puerto Rico, collaborating on community street theater shows and the collective’s annual puppetry festival in San Juan, PR.  With the Flying Donkey Theater co-founder, Federica Colina, Hicks has run large scale art builds for marches, and demonstrations around climate justice in NYC (Climate March 2015), Taiwan (w/ Open Theater 2011-2015), Copenhagen (COP15 2010), Rome (Green Faith & 350.org 2015) and worked in numerous schools, universities and institutions around the Eastcoast, building puppet shows of all sizes with various communities. 

Puppeteer - Ariel Lauryn has performed with The Very Hungry Caterpillar Show  (Acorn Theater), The Talking Band, Columbia Stages, Stegosaurus Theater, LES Shakespeare and Co., The Ume Group, and Lady Fest at The Tank. She creates original works, ranging from slapstick shorts (Dixon Place, Bindlestiff Variety Show) to a webseries, Illuminutty, to a physical comedy one-act, Whether We Like It or Not.  That show has performed at Flint and Tinder (The Tank, NYC), Mad River Festival (Dell'Arte, CA), the New Orleans Fringe Festival '14, and CalArts.  Puppet-wise, she builds, performs, and teaches with The Puppet Kitchen, has created pieces and performed for Puppet Playlist (Sinkingship Productions, Triskelion Arts), puppeteered for the short film The Neverbell, and hand-acted in web commercials with VaynerMedia. 

Composer/Musician – Rob Schwimmer (Polygraph Lounge/ The NY Theremin Society) is a composer-pianist/keyboardist, thereminist, vocalist and Continuum player who has performed and recorded throughout the world. The New York Times praises Rob for his "Virtuosity, magic, and humor." He has worked with Simon and Garfunkel,Wayne Shorter, Antonio Carlos Jobim, Stevie Wonder, Bobby McFerrin, Willie Nelson, Paul Simon, Gotye, The Boston Pops, Chaka Khan, Laurie Anderson, Bette Midler, Queen Latifah, Arif Mardin, Adam Guettel,and Paul Bley, among many, many others. Working as a solo artist and as a founding member of the highly acclaimed Polygraph Lounge duo with  multi-instrumentalist Mark Stewart (Bang On A Can Allstars/Paul Simon) Rob's solo piano playing on his CD "Beyond The Sky" has been widely lauded in both classical and jazz publications: Hailed as "Extraordinary" in Gramophone and "Shaping up to be the finest solo piano CD of the year" in The NYC Jazz Record while The New York Times praised his "…machine-gun speed and clarity."

Lighting Designer – Sabrina Hamilton co-founded and is the Artistic Director of the Ko Festival of Performance in Amherst, MA. For many years she worked with the New York theatre company Mabou Mines as Lighting Designer, Production Manager, Stage Manager, Performer, and Assistant Director. Other credits include work at the New York Shakespeare Festival, the Goodman Theatre, the Mark Taper Forum and 6 years as Route Lighting Designer for New York’s Village Halloween Parade under the direction of Ralph Lee. International lighting credits include work in Berlin, Bologna, Florence, Milan, London, Grenada, Geneva, Paris, Rio de Janeiro, Amsterdam, Brussels, Cardiff, Edinburgh, Hong Kong, at the Bristol Old Vic, the Theatre Academy in Tampere, Finland, and at the International Theatre Festival in Havana, Cuba. She has spent much of the past several years touring with Sandglass Theater. as the lighting designer for their production of D-GENERATION: An Exaltation of Larks, the show that closed Ko’s season on “Age & Aging.”

Performer - Hilary Chaplain tours internationally with A LIFE IN HER DAY, directed by Avner Eisenberg, and in variety shows worldwide with her short comic numbers. Awards include Arlekin Solo Puppet Festival (Grand Prize), the XXI International Festival “Valise” (Acting Award) both in Poland, and in Havana, Cuba at Aquelarre 2006 (three Awards including the Grand Prize). Hilary was an original cast member in Bill Irwin's Largely/New York and appeared on Broadway in the Public Theatre production of The Tempest  directed by George C. Wolfe. She played a featured role in Forrest Gump, and a lawyer on Law and Order Criminal Intent. Hilary entertained children in NYC hospitals as "Nurse Nice" of the renowned Big Apple Circus Hospital Clown Program® (since 1987) and is a founding member of the New York Goofs, a clown ensemble.

story:
About us

Je Ne Sais Quoi Theatre is a new theatre hub/company currently based in Norwich, UK. We aim to put on compelling productions that question our outlook on today's world and the themes surrounding us. Our first production was 'Feeding Time', the UK premiere of a French play ('Le Repas des Fauves') and a sell-out show!

Our cast and crew are all students at the University of East Anglia studying a variety of subjects.

 

Context

On 7th January 2015 two gunmen entered the offices of the satirical newspaper Charlie Hebdo in Paris and opened fire, killing 12 and injuring 13. Al-Qaeda in Yemen took responsibility for the attack, which was a response to the newspaper publishing cartoons depicting the Prophet Muhammad.

The event was considered by many as an attack not only on Charlie but on free speech in general and sparked overwhelming reactions - including on social medias where the slogan 'Je Suis Charlie' (I am Charlie) was shared by millions. On 11th January millions of people - including 40 world leaders -led a unity rally in Paris and throughout the country.

A few days later the newspaper decided to resume publication with an issue depicting once again the Prophet. This led to many protests throughout the Islamic world, in some cases very violent ones: In Niger, such protests led to at least 10 deaths and injured 170.

 

About the show

The Charlie Question is an original piece by Jonathan Hendry based on the Charlie Hebdo shooting and exploring such themes as freedom of speech and the way we are now used to reacting to such terrorist attacks.

The play is semi-verbatim, mixing interviews (expressing different opinions) taken word-for-word with fictitious scenes giving a different perspective on the event. The interviews were carried out on the UEA campus and in Paris with students, teachers, a bookseller, a newsagent... 

We strive to create an engaging show that will make audiences think and especially talk about the topics explored. As a society, we believe it is our responsibility to keep the conversation and debate about free speech going, and we hope this play will contribute to this. To achieve this we will use many visual elements, mirroring the importance of images in the context of the attack. Live drawing will be included in the performance, whilst images and archives will be projected behind the actors.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We will be taking the show to two festivals, the Festival Off d'Avignon (South of France) in July and the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in August. This is a very exciting challenge but also an expensive one, which is why we need you to help us get there!

The money we raise will go towards paying for the Edinburgh venue, travel and accommodation for both festivals along with other costs such as promotional material (posters, flyers, etc).

We have a variety of perks in return for your generosity, do check them out! But most importantly and whatever you decide to put in, you will have contributed to the creation of a new, impactful and engaging  show.

 

Cast and Crew

Directed by Jonathan Hendry and Theo Smith

Prod manager: Katherine Edwards

Cast:

Felix Brown

Lizzie Brown

Shem Jacobs

Saskia May Kelly

Emily Westaway

Louis Raghunathan

Written by Jonathan Hendry

 

Please give whatever you can, every little helps!

Thank you!

 

'Why the Charlie Hebdo attack is still (very) relevant - and why we're putting on a play about it'

 

Find us on Facebook: 

https://www.facebook.com/thecharliequestion/?fr... (show page)

https://www.facebook.com/JeNeSaisQuoitheatre/?f... (company page)

Find us on Twitter: 

https://twitter.com/QuestionCharlie

https://twitter.com/QuestionCharlie

story:
Short Summary

LOUDER THAN WORDS is a concert of contemporary modern dance with original choreography by Karlovsky & Company Dance’s artistic director, Dawn Karlovsky. Joining Karlovsky & Company Dance for the LOUDER THAN WORDS concert is guest choreographer Sarah LaRose-Holland and her company, Kinetic Evolutions Dance, from Minneapolis, along with local visual artist Venus Slick, and musician Tory Z Starbuck.

LOUDER THAN WORDS explores the powerful subject of communication and non-verbal forms of personal, social, and cultural expression. This evening-length work exposes the use of non-verbal human interaction through direct and indirect articulations of gesture, touch, and body language. 
 

About Us

Karlovsky & Company Dance is a St. Louis based contemporary modern dance company dedicated to exploring and nurturing the art of dance with innovative choreography that illuminates the human experience. The company fosters collaborative relationships among musicians, visual artists, and choreographers reaching local, national, and international audiences through concert and informal performances, and dance education.  Karlovsky & Company Dance is the new resident dance company of the .Zack Performing Arts Incubator Program and the Grandel Theatre supported by the Kranzberg Arts Foundation.  Karlovsky & Company Dance is a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit organization.

The company is led by founder and artistic director, Dawn Karlovsky, recipient of a 2015 Artist Fellowship of the Regional Arts Commission of St. Louis, who teaches modern dance and The Alexander Technique at Washington University/University College, and in the Department of Dance at Webster University in St. Louis.

Karlovsky's choreographic work receives grant support by the Missouri Arts Council, a state agency, the Regional Arts Commission, and the Employees Community Fund of the Boeing Company St. Louis.  Support for this event is made possible by the Missouri Arts Council, the Regional Arts Commission, the Kranzberg Arts Foundation, and KDHX.

"Dawn Karlovsky is one of St. Louis' most intriguing choreographers,"
~ Alive Magazine

"Stunning, Stunning, Stunning!" ~ Margie L. of St. Louis
 

What We Need & What You Get

For this campaign, we are asking for help in raising $5,000 of the $10,000 needed for our concert.  We anticipate additional funding from tickets sales and other fundraising efforts. Any amount is greatly appreciated and will help us reach our goal!

Your contribution will help with these costs:

Artists’ salaries and per diem for travel for performance events = $4,000

Travel expenses for Minneapolis tour = $1,000 (partial amount)

 

What You Get

  • That good feeling of knowing that you have made a difference! All money raised will go toward the artists’ salaries, per diems, travel expenses, and theater rental.
  • The FIRST 20 PEOPLE to contribute $50 or more receive a company t-shirt! (Available for pick up at the May concert in St. Louis)
  • Our sincere THANK YOU and mention in our concert program.
  • Complimentary ticket(s) to our MAY 19 or 20, 2017 performance at The Sun Theatre for gifts of $75 or more.
  • A comfy Karlovsky & Company T-Shirt for gifts of $125 or more.
  • An official letter recognizing your tax-deductible contribution.

The Impact

Our company is growing! The opportunity to perform in other cities helps strengthen our company visibility, deepen our artistic connections, and build audiences. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Use social media to share this campaign - Facebook, Email, Tweet, Instagram, text, tell friends about it! 
  • LIKE Karlovsky & Company Dance on Facebook to see what we’re up to!
  • Make you contribution double!  Find out if your employer takes part in Matching Gifts programs!
  • Come see us perform! 

MAY 19 & 20, 2017 - 7:30pm

LOUDER THAN WORDS

The Sun Theater

3625 Grandel Square

St. Louis 63103

TICKETS: METROTIX - 314-534-1111

http://www.metrotix.com/events/detail/karlovsky-and-company-dance-louder-than-words

314-534-1111

 

JUNE 2 & 3, 2017

JSB TEKBOX 

The Cowles Center

528 Hennepin Avenue

Minneapolis, MN 55403

To see more about us, visit our website: www.karlovskydance.org

Contact us at: karlovskyandcompanydance@gmail.com

 

WE ARE MOST GRATEFUL FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
Who we are

Elle NYTT was established in Trinidad and Tobago in 2007 and the New York branch was subsequently established in 2010. Elle NYTT is structured both as a school and performing company.  The Trinidad location offers dance classes at three locations in Modern, Ballet, Soca, Caribbean Fusion, Hip Hop, Dancehall, Femme Funk and also facilitates studio rentals. At the New York branch, Elle NYTT currently offers a Soca Class at the Mark Morris Dance Center, Brooklyn.  

Elle NYTT’s mission is to support, promote, and showcase distinct dance styles and to develop the dance industry in Trinidad and Tobago, as well as promote Caribbean culture abroad. The company continues to explore and build relationships domestically and internationally encouraging everyone to experience different styles of dance.


What We Need & What You Get

We believe in providing performance opportunities for all the students in our classes.  Our first school show started in the studio in Cascade, and every year we continue to grow, moving to MovieTowne, which had its own challenges when it rained, being an outdoor space, to Jean Pierre Complex which had other challenges with the birds in the venue, and we have also explored Bishops/ Trinity East.  This year we are moving the show back to Port of Spain to Queens Hall.  This is the first time we would have the school production there and the students will get the opportunity to perform in a space specifically designed for theatre.  Of course, this now means that our production costs have increased as well.  So we're coming to you for assistance to make this happen.  It would mean the world to these kids and their families who eagerly look forward to that special moment being on stage.

We have also been longing to do some refurbishments to our studio space in Curepe.  The flooring needs to be redone and we would also like to make some adjustments to the registration and waiting area. Lastly, the studio is unbearably hot especially on a Saturday during the day when we have the majority of our kids classes.  We would love to be able to install air conditioning to make it just a bit more comfortable, not only for the kids, but also for the parents who sit patiently and wait in the sweltering heat.  These costs have proven to be a bit more than we can manage on our own and so we're coming to you for your assistance in this regard.

The US$30,000 has been calculated based on the quotations we received for the flooring, air conditioning, refurbishment as well as the budget for our production.  Please note that this budget does not include full payment to Elle NYTT choreographers, teachers and company members, the way we would normally do when we have a company production, as the members will all be contributing this as part of our fund raising efforts.

Whether or not we meet this goal, any amounts donated will go towards meeting these costs.  Check out the various perks offered as as a small token of our appreciation for your generous contributions.  The perks range from special thank you notes on our social media, free classes at any of the studio locations, free DVDs of our previous productions, private classes, to photo opportunities with our Elle Team.


The Impact

The services we offer at Elle NYTT go beyond just dance classes and performances. Dancing as an extracurricular activity can greatly assist in one’s social development and eventually lead to less unproductive hours spent by young adults, not to mention its fitness benefits.

We feel that we have the skills necessary to continue to enrich people’s lives through dance, to inspire and motivate, but we do need your help.

For companies selecting the Platinum perk and greater donations, your sponsorship will qualify for a tax allowance of 100% of the amount contributed as our company is registered with the National Registry of Artists with the Ministry of Arts and Multiculturalism. We will also include your company as one of the sponsors both in our program (target audience of 1,400 over the 2 night run of the show), as well as in our online promotion. Our Facebook page now has over 9,800 likes and our profile page has 5,000 friends, in addition to the network of our 30+ company members - a great opportunity to be promoted.   It should also be noted that Elle NYTT has managed to attract a diversified target audience as our students and performing members come from various ethnicities and social backgrounds.  As such, we are sure that viewership would also come from various socio-economic backgrounds.


Other Ways You Can Help

You can also help us achieve our goals by sharing the campaign link on your social media (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram), or by forwarding by email, or even whats app, bbm and text messages to your friends and anyone you think may be interested.

Share as many times as you like!!!

Lastly, did we say thank you?

… Thank you! Thank you! Thank you!

We truly appreciate your support and look forward to seeing you at the show on 4th & 5th June!

story:
Help London Theatre Workshop upgrade its theatre space as it moves into its new City home.

London Theatre Workshop is a hub for theatrical innovation. It is a not-for-profit, producing theatre company dedicated to finding, developing and showcasing work of the highest quality; and importantly, celebrating the fusion between music and drama. 

London Theatre Workshop is entirely self-funded, receiving no public funding or subsidy. It exists because of its extraordinary body of work. Headed by founder and original Artistic Director Ray Rackham, London Theatre Workshop is a collaborative working theatre lab; re-imagining existing plays and musicals, and developing new work with music at its heart. It is committed to nurturing budding industry talent and offering a platform that provides an opportunity to develop practical skills in all areas of theatrical production. London Theatre Workshop is a creative incubator for work that is commercially viable, whilst maintaining artistic integrity.

In January 2016, London Theatre Workshop refreshed its key personnel and reappointed Rackham as the Artistic Director who would lead its most ambitious project to date; the move to the heart of the City of London and the historic, world famous Leadenhall Market. The move sees the company opening the first professional studio theatre in the Square Mile, alongside a creative Arts Centre that will cultivate and encourage  talent across all theatrical disciplines. 

To do so, London Theatre Workshop needs your help to raise essential funds for upgrading the existing infrastructure at the new venue to accommodate a full lighting rig, sound capability and essential building works. Your support will make such an exciting and creative enterprise possible.

Become part of the #LTWFamily by helping us build our new home.

story:
Short Summary

/kor/ productions is a grassroots level opera company with the focus of bringing opera to a wider audience.  We perform mainly in public spaces like coffeehouses and bars to appeal to a modern audience.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $20,000 to fund our current season, which includes Mozart's Le Nozze di FIGARO, a double bill of GIANNI SCHICCHI and Old MAID and a THEIF, BOHEME IN A BAR (in Seattle), and SONG!, a series of staged song concerts.  Our funding would go to artists, singers, staff, instrumentalists, public relations, space rental, and in some cases housing and travel expenses.

The Impact

We believe opera has an important place in performance art, that it encompasses all aspects of theater in the best way possible.  By funding our project, not only are you helping to further the genre, but also the careers of the young artists we hire to perform.

Risks & Challenges

60 days is not a lot of time to raise $20,000.  But, believe us, any contribution will help!  Imagine yourself paying for one of our rehearsal spaces, or for a costume, or even for coffee to help the singers get through a Saturday morning rehearsal!  If you break it down that way, no amount is too large or small.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our indiegogo page, and like us on Facebook!  www.facebook.com/korproductions.  Also, check out our webpage for upcoming events:  www.korproductions.org
