story:
MESSAGE FROM THE PLAYWRIGHT

Dear Friends!

Your contribution will go a long way. Every dollar counts. This is a play with a relevant and important message and needs to be shared with the world.

A one of its kind story - "A Muslim in the midst" is probably the only play that deals with the immediate aftermath of 9/11 as seen through the eyes of ordinary people outside the United States. The story is set in a city I was born and raised; Bangalore, India. A city that has close connections to the US through its IT industry, and the large expatriate population that calls the city home. The premise to this intense drama is inspired by real events. For your convenience, I have broken down the different donation amounts under various categories but feel free to donate any amount outside of the preset categories (You can click on the amounts listed on the right side-bar to donate). My entire cast and crew will be thankful for your generosity. 
- Anand Rao, Playwright

The Background:

Islamaphobia is neither new nor exclusive to New York City, the United States or for that matter, the world.

  • With almost 1.8 billion Muslims around the globe (that's about 24% of the world's population), the perception of Muslims and what the attack on September 11th did to help change that view is as much a topic of discussion today as it was in the days following the September 11th attacks. This is a story inspired by true events that takes place half way around the world, and gives life to a moment in history from a perspective never before seen on a New York stage, until now.

  • Given the climate of todays presidential election, a rise in fear of terrorism following attacks in recent weeks around the world, this play is long overdue and ready to take the New York stage by storm. We want you to be a part of this great debate, this unique tale of what happens when two couples from two very opposing sides of the issue come together as simple human beings, in a moment of kindness and civility, a moment that provides an honest look at being a Muslim stranger, and getting to know one up close.

  • "A Muslim in the midst" raises important questions as the characters grapple with their limitations to find answers. A reflection of the times we live in, and the increasing need for discovering a  common fellowship based on humanity and empathy. It's an ongoing debate that transcends cultures and borders.

Synopsis:

  • September 14th, 2001: On the third day after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, on the streets of Bangalore, India; a poor Muslim family is stranded. Desperate to reach a relative’s home in a distant suburb, the new immigrants to the city are struggling to find a ride late in the night. Watching them closely is a modern Hindu couple, both well-traveled and highly educated executives of American companies. The liberal and westernized executive couple offers to take the traditional and rural Muslim couple along. The conversation quickly takes an unexpected turn as the two world’s collide. Fueled by an intermittent radio broadcast spewing pro and anti-Islamic rhetoric and warnings about potential terror threats, the characters fight within their self-imposed confines of prejudice and fear, in their attempts to look beyond the obvious ideological differences, and unravel a common fellowship based on humanity. 

IN THE NEWS

We were recently featured in the Huffington Post and The Times of India. You can read the articles here: 

  • To read Playwright Anand Rao's interview in the Times of India, please go to the gallery, and look for the digital image of the print version.

  • Click here to read Huffington Post: "Muslim Debate Makes Theatrical Debut

Why we need your help?
"A Muslim in the midst" thus far has been solely funded by its playwright - Anand Rao. Now, we need your help to take the play to the next level. The confirmed shows in September 2016 are at 'Thespis' - a competition and festival that does not share ticket revenues with the performing group. Your donations are not just a much-needed relief but they will be the essential lifeblood that keeps the vital parts of this production running.
Our amazing team of talented cast and crew has already invested a lot of energy and time on the play. We have a line-up of highly talented and trained actors, carefully handpicked to portray the complex characters. They are all eagerly awaiting to demonstrate their craft, and bring the characters to life on stage. 

Upcoming Shows

Thespis 2016 Theatre Festival, Hudson Guild Theater, 441 W, 26th St., NYC.

  • Monday, September 12 at 6:15 PM
  • Friday, September 16 at 9:00 PM
  • Sunday, September 18 at 3:30 PM
Now begins the real work, as we start looking at building sets, stage properties, lighting, costume, marketing, and a whole lot of other expensive activities including renting rehearsal space in New York. 
It's our aim to produce a play that stands out not just for its relevance of topic but also for its quality of production. Your donation will go a long way in realizing all our dreams of making sure that "A Muslim in the midst" will make a strong world premiere at Thespis 2016, be remembered for a long time, and gets invited for performances at other venues. 

We Win, You Win

What do YOU get by donating to this play? There is no downside to it at all.

  • You are singlehandedly helping bring a new multicultural, multi-ethnic theatre piece to an Off-Broadway stage. And you're doing it for an amount far less than if you were an investor in a professional production with a normal run. 
  • Your contribution is NOT for one play. It affects the larger theatre industry, and the entire community of minority artists in this country. All the powerful and important plays that you see today were developed in Off-Broadway venues with shoe string budgets, often beginning as festival productions and growing from there.
  • You are more than just a donor. Your donation however small it may be will show future Broadway producers, that we can attract investors. And, that we have a large community of people willing to support us. And the more people who show their support by donating, the better the show looks as an investment vehicle. 

Our budget:

  • Rehearsal Space: $1,200
  • Advertising/Marketing: $2,000
  • Props/Sets/Costumes: $1750
  • Sound and Light: $1600
  • Technicians: $1250
  • Transportation and logistics: $1000
  • Stipends and fees: $1200

Watching them closely is a modern Hindu couple, both well-traveled and highly educated executives of American companies. The liberal and westernized executive couple offers to take the traditional and rural Muslim couple along. The conversation quickly takes an unexpected turn as the two world’s collide. Fueled by an intermittent radio broadcast spewing pro and anti-Islamic rhetoric and warnings about potential terror threats, the characters fight within their self-imposed confines of prejudice and fear, in their attempts to look beyond the obvious ideological differences, and unravel a common fellowship based on humanity. 

IN THE NEWS

We were recently featured in the Huffington Post and The Times of India. You can read the articles here: 


To read Playwright Anand Rao's interview in the Times of India, please go to the gallery, and look for the digital image of the print version.

Click here to read Huffington Post: "Muslim Debate Makes Theatrical Debut




Why we need your help?


"A Muslim in the midst" thus far has been solely funded by its playwright - Anand Rao. Now, we need your help to take the play to the next level. The confirmed shows in September 2016 are at 'Thespis' - a competition and festival that does not share ticket revenues with the performing group. Your donations are not just a much-needed relief but they will be the essential lifeblood that keeps the vital parts of this production running.
Our amazing team of talented cast and crew has already invested a lot of energy and time on the play. We have a line-up of highly talented and trained actors, carefully handpicked to portray the complex characters. They are all eagerly awaiting to demonstrate their craft, and bring the characters to life on stage. 


Upcoming Shows
Thespis 2016 Theatre Festival, Hudson Guild Theater, 441 W, 26th St., NYC.


Monday, September 12 at 6:15 PM
Friday, September 16 at 9:00 PMSunday, September 18 at 3:30 PM


Now begins the real work, as we start looking at building sets, stage properties, lighting, costume, marketing, and a whole lot of other expensive activities including renting rehearsal space in New York. 

It's our aim to produce a play that stands out not just for its relevance of topic but also for its quality of production. Your donation will go a long way in realizing all our dreams of making sure that "A Muslim in the midst" will make a strong world premiere at Thespis 2016, be remembered for a long time, and gets invited for performances at other venues. 

    
We Win, You Win



What do YOU get by donating to this play? There is no downside to it at all.


You are singlehandedly helping bring a new multicultural, multi-ethnic theatre piece to an Off-Broadway stage. And you're doing it for an amount far less than if you were an investor in a professional production with a normal run. 

Your contribution is NOT for one play. It affects the larger theatre industry, and the entire community of minority artists in this country. All the powerful and important plays that you see today were developed in Off-Broadway venues with shoe string budgets, often beginning as festival productions and growing from there.

You are more than just a donor. Your donation however small it may be will show future Broadway producers, that we can attract investors. And, that we have a large community of people willing to support us. And the more people who show their support by donating, the better the show looks as an investment vehicle. 

Our budget:


Rehearsal Space: $1,200
Advertising/Marketing: $2,000
Props/Sets/Costumes: $1750
Sound and Light: $1600
Technicians: $1250
Transportation and logistics: $1000
Stipends and fees: $1200

story:
For the 3rd year, SALSA MADRAS is hosting the Latin Festival Madras! 
Through the festival we aim to connect Chennai, the Growing Social Dancing destination in India to the world and giving the best dance and holiday experience for everyone, bringing the best of the talents from all over the world to Chennai. 
We at SALSA MADRAS, proudly present you the India's Most awaited Afro-Latin Festival this September filled with more than 20 dance workshops by International artists, 2 choreography bootcamps, stunning shows by National and international artists and teams, Theme parties all night, Crazy pool party, surfing and beach parties and more, with participants from more than 30 different nationalities coming to Chennai!

Come and join us for a memorable dance holiday in the wonderful city of Chennai!

We are expecting about 150-200 dancers from various cities within India, viz. Chennai, Pondicherry, Hyderabad, Kochi, Bangalore, Mumbai, Pune, Delhi, etc. and from countries Viz. France, Spain, Colombia, US, England, Scotland, Austria, Romania, Hungary, Canada, Australia, Vietnam, Thailand, Poland, Russia, Ukraine, Singapore, Malaysia, Sri Lanka, Dubai, Philippines, Nepal, Japan, and more, making it a multi cultural dance event with everyone sharing the same passion for dancing. 


LATIN Festival Madras & KIZOMBA Conference 2016

23 Sept: Surfing and dancing by the sea

24 Sept: Workshops, Championships, Shows, theme party

25 Sept: Workshops, pool party, Shows, Theme party

(complimentary lunch and Dinner on 24 & 25 Sept)

Getaway to Pondicherry

(26-27 Sept 2016)

Do what you like during the day and we get together in the night for dancing! Pondicherry is a beautiful old French Colony, not to be missed!

CHAMPIONSHIPS!

* 3rd Chennai salsa solo Open

* 2nd Asia Kizomba Championship

Registration closes 15 Aug 2016.

SPECIAL CHOREOGRAPHY BOOTCAMPS

* Bachata by Gupson Pierre

* Kizomba by Azlan & Mabel

watch out more details!

For info on passes, stay, agenda, competitions, artists, partner festivals and more, check www.latinfestivalmadras.in

SALSA MADRAS

  • Arun Srinivasan, the Director and founder of SALSA Madras has more than 7 years of experience in Teaching and currently one of the promoters of salsa, bachata and Kizomba in India and Asia. 
  • Salsa Madras, founded in March 2014, takes the opportunity to host the festival thereby bringing in talents from Different ends of the world in different genres of music and dance to Chennai to help grow the standard of the Latin and Afro Dances in the city
  • We have been making every effort possible to bring the best exposure and knowledge in the field of Afro Latin to keep Chennai alive with dancing socially! 

What We Need & What You Get 

  • The funding will be directed towards the expenses catering to the flights, stay, food and fee of the Artists from different countries; Logistics involved in the festival including lights, sounds, floor, stage, backdrops, etc.; Marketing and promotion expenses in Media, papers, Radio across Chennai, and through other promoters in other cities and countries; 
  • Your contribution little or more can make a difference and we will be thankful and offer you perks in return. 

CHENNAI - a dance destination 

  • Chennai, considered a very conservative city, is now slowly getting on the Salsa and Kizomba Map of the world. A successful festival also means it is making a difference in the City's quality, standard and exposure to Afro and Latin World
  • This is the 3rd year of the festival and we have hosted kizomba bootcamps by Nelson Campos, Katia Verreault, salsa & Bachata workshops by Leading international artists viz. Salsa Twins (Rahul & Deepak Stephen), Umesh Lakshman(Montuno dance US), Julia Pauer (Aerialist from Austria) and more. 
  • Salsa Madras also helps in promoting Afro & Latin dance across India and Asia but being leading promoters for various Asian salsa and Kizomba festivals. Your contribution can help us bring more awesomeness to the festival and so to the city.

story:
The Goal:

Help us produce the new musical MCCREADY for the 2016 Hollywood Fringe Festival in Los Angeles this June!

Created and written by Jon Bernstein and Jennifer Blake, MCCREADY had a successful run in Los Angeles, CA in May/June 2015, and the ongoing interest in MCCREADY has been overwhelming! After the Fringe Festival run, we are looking to run in Nashville, and beyond!

The full amount needed for this run is $6,000. 

Your support here means that you are supporting local theatre as well as new musicals!!

What We Need 

Producing theatre ain't cheap, so to give you an idea of exactly what this Fringe Festival run of MCCREADY costs, the following are required:

  • Cost of Venue
  • Liability Insurance
  • Registration fees
  • Cast
  • Crew: Lighting tech/Stage Manager, etc
  • Marketing

What You Get

As a thank you for your support, we have some fun perks that include TICKETS to our show, POSTERS signed by the cast, and even a spaghetti DINNER with the cast!

Other Ways Y'all Can Help

Sharing our campaign means the world to us too!!

Tweet, Facebook, Instagram, Holler, Telegram #MCCREADYMUSICAL #HFF2016

THANK YOU SO VERY MUCH!!

story:
Short Summary

  • My name is Joshua Manculich and I am dancer, choreographer, and artist. This campaign seeks to support my creative projects over the next year and half. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • The majority of my budget takes into account my wish to pay dancers that I workshop with!  

The Impact

  • When I started making work in Chicago, little did I know that this would lead to more extensive creativity and research as a student of life! I feel excited to present a work that emphasizes how contemporary dance captures, comments, and frames life experiences.

I feel excited to present a work that emphasizes how contemporary dance captures, comments, and frames life experiences.

story:
The Queen, written by Aditya Rawal and directed by Gwynn MacDonald, will have a run of 12 shows from the 2nd of June to the 19th of June at the iconic Off-Off-Broadway venue, Theater for the New City, in the East Village in New York.

THE PLAY:
Set in 16th century India, at the peak of the Mughal era, The Queen is the story of Durga, who is consigned to the west wing of the palace after her husband, the Rajput king, marries a younger woman. She battles against the loss of her beauty and relevance as she resolves to burn the palace down and avenge her husband’s betrayal. 

The play draws inspiration from Macbeth, Medea and the works of Rabindranath Tagore. It explores themes of power and the position of women in society, an issue that in four centuries has not lost its importance.

WHERE YOU CAN HELP:
Artists from minority communities create some of the most provocative art. Despite that, we are provided with fewer opportunities to showcase our work on the established stage. In the times we live in, we believe it is even more important to support work made by artists of colour because the stories we tell today, will become the moral institutions of society tomorrow. Therefore,  storytelling must be diverse. By contributing to our production, you don't just support the creation of art, you also ensure a thriving, diverse culture.

Most of our collaborators have agreed to work for no fee, or a subsidised fee. Every dollar we save allows us to maximise the quality of our production. Some of our members have even contributed personal funds towards this project, such is the belief we share in each others talents and the play.

We are looking to raise funds for the following:
Rehearsal space
Period costumes 
Set and light elements
Publicity and press packets
Salaries for cast and crew 

TOTAL: 4000$

If, due to the generosity of our benefactors, we make more than 4000$ dollars, we will pay our cast, crew and designers the salary that they would normally command. As is widely known, surviving as an artist, especially in New York City, is very challenging and as producers we would like to ensure that our artists and collaborators receive the financial compensation that they deserve.

THE HISTORICAL BACKGROUND OF THE PLAY:
The 16th century brought about a perplexing situation for the Rajput kings of Rajasthan, who bore a proud legacy of nobility and bravery. To prevent the destruction of their kingdoms at the hands of the almighty Mughals, they were forced to accept Emperor Akbar’s suzerainty, thereby betraying the same legacy that they were trying to protect.

The king, Pratap, finds himself in this position when Akbar demands that he send his army to fight alongside the Mughals, in a battle that has little to do with the Rajputs. Pratap must use all the resources at his disposal, including his first wife, Durga, to prevent this.

THE THEATER: 
Founded in 1971, Theater for the New City (TNC) is one of New York City's leading Off-Off-Broadway theaters, known for radical political plays and community commitment. Productions at TNC have won 43 Obie Awards and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama for Sam Shepard’s Buried Child. Theatre for the New City has served as the home for theatre pioneers such as Richard Foreman, Charles Ludlam, Miguel Piñero, Ralph Lee, María Irene Fornés, Romulus Linney, Harvey Fierstein, and Heiner Muller. A musical adaptation of Antoine de Saint Exupéry’s The Little Prince in 1973 featured Tim Robbins in the title role. The 1976 play Dinosaur Door by Barbara Garson featured a young Vin Diesel.

DIRECTOR:
Gwynn MacDonald has directed and produced for the theater, television, film and radio. Her work in television (MTV networks, Showtime, CBS, etc.) has received both Cable Ace and Emmy Nominations. 

Gwynn majored in theater and studied film production at Princeton University. After graduation she focused on theater, studying script analysis with Jose Quintero. As Artistic Director for the Juilliard alumni-founded Juggernaut Theatre Company, she has – among other projects – produced an all African-American Othello, directed the world premier of Joe Pintauro's Rosen's Son. She has also produced Caplan's Lapis Blue Blood Red about Baroque painter Artemisia Gentileschi in collaboration with the Metropolitan Museum and their retrospective of her work.

She is a Drama League Directors’ Project alum, co-editor of Women in Theatre Online journal, on the advisory board of the Immigrants’ Theatre Project, as well as a member of the  Society of Stage Directors & Choreographers, The Shakespeare Society, and the Lincoln Center Theatre Directors Lab. 

PLAYWRIGHT:
Aditya Rawal is a playwright/screenwriter, actor and director from Mumbai, India. He is currently developing the screenplay of Faceless with acclaimed Bollywood director, Ketan Mehta. His plays have been performed at many festivals, including the Short + Sweet Theatre Festival in Chennai, India. He has co-authored two story books on Child Rights, and has also produced and directed a documentary titled, Drama-in-Education: Taking Gandhi Out of the Textbook.

Aditya acted in Kishan Kanhaiya, a play which was adapted in to the blockbuster Bollywood film, OMG (Oh My God), for which Aditya was the assistant director. He appeared in the film, Ferrari ki Sawaari, which was produced by Vinod Chopra Films (producers of iconic Bollywood films, 3 Idiots and PK).

M.F.A.: Dramatic Writing Program at Tisch School of the Arts, NYU
Initiation Course in Devising Theatre at the London International School of Performing Arts.

MUSICIANS:
With this play, we hope to transport the audience to a specific time and place in Indian history. Part of the theatrical experience will include a live acoustic band playing an original score and some traditional songs. The music will be composed and performed by Rhythm Tolee, an award winning New York City based Punjabi band with members from Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx and Jersey City area.

Rhythm Tolee is an award winning New York City based Punjabi band with members from Brooklyn, Queens, Bronx and Jersey City area. "Tolee" means "A free spirited group of people" in Punjabi language. This is exactly what Rhythm Tolee is, a group of free spirited artists with Rhythm.

Rhythm Tolee performs a wide variety of songs by mixing Punjabi Folk and Sufi music with western tunes. The band was recently awardedwith the Audience Award at the first South Asian International Performing Arts Festival held in Tribeca in Aug 2015 and was covered by major media outlets like The Huffington Post, The Express Tribune etc.

For more information please visit: www.facebook.com/RhythmTolee

COSTUMES:
Originally from St. Louis, Missouri, Joseph Blaha migrated to New York City in 2010. Past design credits include Like Money in the Bank (Theatre Row), Separati (Vim Vigor Dance Company), Sex of the Baby (Access Theatre), SONS+DAUGHTERS (NYU Tisch 2nd Ave Dance Company), Blood on the Tracks (Bailout Theatre), Cloven Tongues (The Wild Project) Swing State and A Letter to Harvey Milk (New York Musical Theatre Festival), Un Plugged In (Theatre Row), Heathens (Theatre for a New City). Regional credits include The Mystery of Edwin Drood, Altar Boyz, The 25th Annual Putnam County Spelling Bee (Papermill Theatre), The Cradle Will Rock, I Love You Because, and The Girlhood of Shakespeare's Heroines (Missouri Stare University).
B.F.A. Missouri State University, M.F.A. NYU- Tisch School of the Arts. www.josephsblaha.com

PRODUCTION MANAGER:
Aman Soni is an actor from New Delhi, India and is currently based in New York. His recent theatre credits include -- "Invasion" by Jonas Hassen Khemiri, "Shape of Love" by Bina Sharif at the Theater for the New City; "Virtual Realty" by Alan Arkin at the Workshop Theater.

Aman is an undergraduate of SUNY Purchase College, Conservatory of Theatre Arts, he will continue his graduate studies at Brown University / Trinity Repertory MFA Acting program starting this fall.

story:
A Sci-Fi Manifesto to save the planet

Opera for the Unknown Woman tells the story of how women think together, and how powerful and world-defining they can be when loosed upon the hard problem of climate stability and human change. Using science fiction as a frame, our opera brings together a group of women from present day Earth, who are drawn to one another by a mysterious power to forge a future for their planet.  As the story unfolds, we witness their mission to divert the extinction of human life.

It is important to us that this work reaches as many people as possible, and we need your help to make sure it does just that.

The money raised from this fundraiser will go towards the additional performances of the show including the costs of a new cast member, and hire costs for sound and lighting equipment and in particular projection costs to realise  Will Duke’s  fantastic designs. The award-winning cast and team are working hard to bring this work to fruition, and we hope you will donate to help us make these extra dates a success. Thank you.

Melanie Wilson is a London based theatre maker whose work combines sound and language to create powerful, poetic performances. Her work employs theatre, sound art and contemporary forms of composition, and she has collaborated with artists and companies across forms of theatre, film, music, installation, fine art and photography.


About the Show 

300 years from now. World economies have failed. The human vestiges of earth are scattered and defenceless, pursued by flood and famine. Aphra, the last hope for life has two weeks to live. 

In 2016 a group of women from around the world are drawn together by an unearthly power, to forge a future for their planet. Can their mission alter Earth’s course and save Aphra?

Read more about 'Opera for the Unknown Woman' here. You can also follow updates from the cast and creative team on the journey of making this unique show on our blog.


Perks

General perks

£5 – a great big thank you (a personalised thank you email)

£10 – an "affinity & resistance" badge    

£25 – a limited edition Opera for the Unknown Woman tote bag and an "affinity & resistance" badge  

£50 – a badge, a tote bag, and a signed, framed cast photo

£100 – 2 tickets to the show, a badge and a bag 

£500 – 2 tickets to the show, a badge, a bag and a backstage pass plus a limited edition copy of the libretto signed by creative team    


We'll be announcing some limited edition perks as the campaign progresses, so keep an eye out.

Also, follow us on social media to access the secret perks we'll be sharing.


Other Ways You Can Help

 Here are some ways you can help us spread the word to your networks:

-  Like us on Facebook

-  Follow us on Twitter and using the hashtag #operationopera

-  Share our IndieGoGo campaign page 

-  Bookmark our website and our blog, where we will be posting updates and highlights throughout the month

Thank you for being part of our growing community. We’re excited to share this campaign with you, and to bring you what we hope is an important new work by Melanie Wilson.


Thank You For Your Support

story:
About us:

The Dead Arts Society (DAS) is a UC Davis student-run theater club where students write, direct, and perform original scenes, one-acts, and full length plays. We pride ourselves in being open to anyone and everyone wanting to join - all majors and experience levels are welcome! Each quarter we have a new showcase and, this is the best part, admission is FREE. However, in order to keep it that way, we do need a little help from our friends (that's you!!!!).

Our Spring Showcase:
WHERE: Wright Hall - Lab A

WHEN:    May 19 - 7-10pm

                  May 20 - 7-10pm

                  May 31 - 1-4pm and 7-10pm

WHAT:    This quarter's showcase features THREE unique one-acts, including:
  • Soul Mates, by Lexi Scherr // Directed by Lexi Scherr & Lena El-Gabalawy
       Two souls sharing one body. Having a hard time understanding that concept? So is everyone else in Daniel and Danny's life, which can make things rather complicated and difficult to navigate. Watch them deal with all of the joys and hardships that come with their duel identities.

  • PSYCHOBASH!, by Ben Sipes // Directed by Kendall Larsen & Ben Sipes
         What at happens when our favorite psychological concepts throw a party? Love, competition, and conspiracy! Is Happiness on ecstasy? Probably. Sadness a raging alcoholic? Absolutely. Will Id, the master of unrestricted desire, release their sexual urges on everyone? You'll just have to come and see. PSC 1 gets fun with PSYCHOBASH!, the most kick ass party to hit the stage!

  • HANA DOOL SET, by Rose Kim // Directed by Delevan Tam & Natalie Hovsepian
         One and two, Hana and Dool, a play written by Rose Kim and directed by Delevan Tam and Natalie Hovespian. Good gr8 swell! What does a play mean? :3 What am I thinking? Who are you? Cogito Ergo Sum. How do you right a play? Mmmmmmmmmmmmh yes I feel the universe flowing inside me. :) You don't need to find the truth because you are it. Watch as chaos of writing unravel itself into order.

Your Impact:

All donations will go towards purchasing props, costumes, and all the other theatrical elements needed to help make our showcase the best it can be. Your support helps keep the showcase a free event for all students, faculty, friends, and family wishing to attend and support the cast members! In return, we'll hook you up with reserved seats and signed programs!

Want To Know More?

For more information about Dead Arts Society, our spring showcase, or any questions you may have, feel free to...

  • Check out our showcase event page!
  • Email us at deadartssociety@gmail.com!
  • Follow our Dead Arts Society Facebook page!

story:
Hey! My name is Caitlin Looney and I am the director/producer of the Chicago-based sketch group MAGIC CITY. I could tell you about my junior high student government experience or about the time I played an Irish-lady-pirate in a play about lady-pirates or how my extensive theatre and comedy background has helped me in my role as director/producer of the best—in my humble opinion—sketch group in Chicago, but that's boring. Let's talk about the coolest people I know and what they're up to.

MAGIC CITY is coming off a fantastic run of their inaugural show BABIES IN BUSINESS SUITS at The Second City's Donny Skybox. But the group is ready for the next big thing—a brutal skewering of the reality TV show that brought real love to the people of America: The Bachelor.

You’ve seen countless clean cut, seamlessly edited episodes of The Bachelor, but what aren’t you seeing and what do you really want to be seeing? MAGIC CITY will dive head first into the sordid insanity that ensues on-set AND off-camera when love and reality TV go head to head in LOVE, BLOOD & ROSES. MAGIC CITY has the realest ladies, the lamest bachelor, the robotic-est host and the skeeziest producer that have yet to be seen in a Bachelor parody.

With the help of your contributions, we will be able to produce LOVE, BLOOD & ROSES in the only way it truly should be: with too much spectacle, too much white wine (jk it's grape juice. right, ladies?) and the perfect amount of quality.

But before you dive into all the nitty-gritty-details of this campaign, check out our crazy beautiful cast! 

Top L to R: Tess Lennon-Dorn, Danielle Durbin, Bridget O'Connor & Courtney Tesh.
Bottom L to R: Willie Griswold, Chase Ingrande & Marc Ranucci.

Top L to R: Tatsue Sera, Laura Mulcahy, Jordan Lee Cohen & Shelby Quinn.
Bottom L to R: Aria Machinski, Annie Sullivan & Squeek Rangel. 

LET US ENTERTAIN YOU! LET US MAKE YOU SMILE!

We created and produced MAGIC CITY's very first sketch show, BABIES IN BUSINESS SUITS, entirely on our own. This included creating and rehearsing the show, pitching the concept to our friends at Donny's Skybox, and spending out-of-our-pocket money on advertising and marketing. For LOVE, BLOOD & ROSES, we want to go above and beyond what we already know we're capable of. MAGIC CITY will still bring you top quality entertainment that only MAGIC CITY can provide, but we need your help to financially support this endeavor. 

This show has the ability to reach a much wider and larger audience than BABIES IN BUSINESS SUITS did, but we can only do so much within our means. With your financial support, we will be able to market the show more effectively, reaching out to the people we know want to see LOVE, BLOOD & ROSES, but are people we may not be able to access in our current networks. With your help, we'd also be able to have a consistent (and large enough) rehearsal space for our weekly rehearsals, as well as the ability to pay taxes on any of the money we make off of this show. 

If you check out our perks, you'll see there are a ton of fun things you can receive, should you choose to you help us reach our goal. This includes custom stickers, MAGIC CITY t-shirts, signed cast pictures and cast member portraits, and going all the way up to us treating you to dinner, the show AND DRINKS! We want to make sure you have the best experience when you come to our shows, and the perks will help us AND you!

A BREAKDOWN OF WHERE THE FUNDS ARE HEADED

Marketing/Advertising: $1000 budget
Facebook Ads, printed posters, flyers, postcards, photos and stickers that will be distributed across the city of Chicago.

Rehearsal Space: $1000 budget
Two rehearsals every week for the month of June in a rented studio that can fit the needs of our extra large cast.

Props/Make-Up/Costumes: $400 budget
Our show is going to require a little more props, make-up and costumes than a typical sketch show because of our subject matter. These funds will go toward reimbursing our cast members for any expenses they may have in their thrift-store clothing and drug-store make-up endeavors.

The Rest of the Money: $600 budget
The rest of the money we raise will go toward any unforeseen costs we may have in the production and run of the show, but also in making sure MAGIC CITY is able to pay off taxes for any of the money it makes off of its show. Extra money will go into a slush fund that will cover taxes, festival applications and online digital content projects. And if we are able, shelling out funds to our cast because we believe in paying artists for their valuable time, energy and efforts.

We understand that money is not always an easy thing to give away. That's why in the event we don't reach our goal, we'll still do everything we can to go above and beyond to bring you the best sketch show ever. 

BUT WHAT MAKES US SPECIAL!??!

OK, OK. We've asked for your moneys, but why should you bother helping us? 

Aside from giving MAGIC CITY the ability to pay for more effective advertisement, rehearsal spaces and reimbursements for make-up/props/costuming—as well as helping us cover our tax butts—contributing to this campaign offers MAGIC CITY not only the chance to endure, but to grow and flourish. 

At the heart of MAGIC CITY is the love of play and giving people the opportunity to work and perform with joy. MAGIC CITY is about being able to walk into the room and CREATE art that is funny, relevant and honest to who we are not only as performers, actors, directors, writers, but as humans. It's about creating work you believe in with people you love working with. 

For LOVE, BLOOD & ROSES, we are bringing in 9 incredibly talented guest artists to help bring this project to life. This brings our cast to a total of 16, but in a totally cheesy-corn-puff-way, this is us growing our family. 

Should we meet our goal, we will be able to build the foundation needed for MAGIC CITY to truly succeed. Funds that are not used specifically for this show will go to other MAGIC CITY endeavors which include building a website for online digital content, applying and performing for festivals, future shows and so much more.

You won't just be helping us produce this one show, you'll be helping us thrive.

IN THE EVENT OF AN EMERGENCY
(what happens if we don't get the funds)

WE'LL BE OK! We've done this before and we did it pretty damn well. It stung a little bit, but we've got the ability to bounce back from any obstacles we may encounter because we've got a strong team. 

We may not be able to have the audiences we're hoping to have and we may not be able to reimburse ourselves for out-of-pocket costs, but we're scrappy. If it doesn't happen this time, it may set us back a bit in all we hope to do. However, we'll be able to get to where we're going eventually. 

WANNA DO OTHER STUFF TO HELP US?

We totally understand if you're unable to contribute to this campaign! Money is hard to come by—hence the campaign—but don't fret! If you believe in our cause, you're welcome to SHARE, SHARE, SHARE this campaign with all your friends and family or any very cool patrons of the arts you may know!

Thanks for everything! And if anything else, come check out our show! 

SATURDAYS JULY 2 - 23 @ 10PM IN DONNY'S SKYBOX

story:
Thespis, Here We Come!

Gaybraham Lincoln is back! We are very proud to announce that Gaybraham Lincoln: The Musical  has been accepted into the 2016 Thespis Theatre Festival in New York City. We are raising money to fund this festival production of our musical satire, which will perform in New York City on July 28th, 29th, and 31st.

The Gaybraham Creative Team

  • Jared Corwin - Creator, Bookwriter, Co-Lyricist
  • Jacob Minter - Composer, Co-Lyricist, Orchestrator
  • Gabriella Carr - Dramaturg, Original Director, Additional Materials

About Gaybraham Lincoln

Gaybraham Lincoln is a satirical musical detailing the state affairs and affairs of state surrounding the American civil war. Frustrated by Abraham's lack of sexual interest, Mary Todd Lincoln begins an affair with General Ulysses S. Grant, unaware that president Lincoln has begun his own affair with eccentric and unstable actor John Wilkes Booth. With music satirizing and honoring the songs of the civil war, Gaybraham Lincoln is an irreverent historical farce that poses fundamental questions about sexuality, identity, and equality.

Expanded from an original script by Jared Corwin and songs by Jacob Minter, Gaybraham Lincoln: The Musical  was developed under dramaturg and director Gabriella Carr, culminating in a student-run production at Ithaca College in December of 2013. Following the success of the premiere performance, an expanded cast album was developed and recorded with a 15-piece orchestra directed by composer Jacob Minter.

This Campaign

The Gaybraham team is thrilled to be involved in the 2016 Thespis Festival! We are seeking funding for the many resources required to mount a festival production, including wardrobe, equipment, travel, and the salaries of our actors and crew. Our Thepis performance will employ at least 14 actors and a 5-piece band, as well as a small production crew.

Donor rewards from this campaign include tickets to our festival performances, various audio and video materials, and Gaybraham Lincoln merchandise.

Everything Helps!

Word of mouth is everything! Gaybraham Lincoln is still a young show, and we are grateful for any help people can give. If you are interested in being involved in the production, know of anyone who would be interested in the show, or would like to help spread the word, don't be afraid to reach out to us!

story: We are a group of students at UK drama school Rose Bruford College and have just set up a group called Here be Dragons Theatre. Our first production 'Knots' will be playing at this years Camden Fringe Festival at The Lion and Unicorn theatre and we need your help getting there! The money that we raise will go towards the hiring of the theatre, the festival registration fee and anything after that will go towards props, set and costume. 'Knots' is a play that explores the issue of mental health and in particular, the effects of loneliness; the stigma behind it, the way it is portrayed in media and exploring if a younger generation is more open and aware of mental health issues, or are we just as dumbfounded as the generation before? We will be working with the local community and talking to people who have suffered, or who are suffering with a mental illness and exploring why a sickness of the mind is not often considered a sickness at all. We will be using their experience to question how we can raise awareness to the subject matter and how we can help in the future. Every little donation helps and we would be so so grateful to those who can help us contribute in putting on Here be Dragon's exciting premiere production!
story_txt: We are a group of students at UK drama school Rose Bruford College and have just set up a group called Here be Dragons Theatre. Our first production 'Knots' will be playing at this years Camden Fringe Festival at The Lion and Unicorn theatre and we need your help getting there! The money that we raise will go towards the hiring of the theatre, the festival registration fee and anything after that will go towards props, set and costume. 'Knots' is a play that explores the issue of mental health and in particular, the effects of loneliness; the stigma behind it, the way it is portrayed in media and exploring if a younger generation is more open and aware of mental health issues, or are we just as dumbfounded as the generation before? We will be working with the local community and talking to people who have suffered, or who are suffering with a mental illness and exploring why a sickness of the mind is not often considered a sickness at all. We will be using their experience to question how we can raise awareness to the subject matter and how we can help in the future. Every little donation helps and we would be so so grateful to those who can help us contribute in putting on Here be Dragon's exciting premiere production!

story:
Short Summary

We are currently in our last few months of attending Talent Unlimited High School as dance majors. Looking back at the four years we've been at TUHS, we have collected many great memories and close relationships in our school community and as a dance department. Because we've been able to do what we love and create art in addition to our academic studies on a day to day basis, our high school experience has been deeply meaningful. 

We are working so hard to make our final performances at TUHS the best they can be —  from the dancing to the costumes to all of the behind the scenes work that goes into producing a concert. We've been studying and refining our understanding of the repertory and technique of George Balanchine™. We will be performing Martha Graham technique at the company's historic Westbeth studio theater. Not least of all, we are preparing intensively for our final concerts on May 12th & 13th. 

George Balanchine™  is a Trademark of the The George Balanchine Trust©. All rights reserved. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are launching this campaign to fund the purchase of new costumes for our Spring Concert. Your donation will go a long way towards bringing our vision of a professional looking concert to life. 

  • We are looking to raise $1500 that will go towards the purchase of new costumes. Any funds raised in excess of $1500 will be paid forward to the following classes of dancers at TUHS.
  • No donation is too small. Give what you can. Any amount helps. 
  • Check out our perks! For the $150 and $200 levels, you can receive tickets to see Miami City Ballet or NYC Ballet at Lincoln Center. 
  • Your donations are tax deductible. We have partnered with Pentacle Dance's Behind the Scenes program, which is providing 501(c)(3) fiscal sponsorship. 

The Impact

The connections we have made with each other are unlike anything else. We have danced together, struggled together, laughed together and this will be the last time we will be able to perform together on the TUHS stage. We would love for you to come and support the Talent Unlimited dance department and experience our love of the arts.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our campaign with your friends! We appreciate any support you can offer in spreading the word about the campaign and the upcoming performance.

story:
DeRose Art Company coming to New York City

The goal is to support this incredibly talented group of artists to travel to New York and help "pull out all the stops" to professionally produce an incredible show.

The Company was founded in late 2007, creating and producing innovative works every year that explore choreographic language and technique, physical dexterity, and movements that explore the senses and defy gravity.

What We Need

The break down of our expected expenses:

  • Theater rental (*including sound technicians & lighting): $3500
  • Film & video editing: $800
  • Assistence with travel expenses (food and lodging): $2000

Other Ways You Can Help

Help us get the word out and make some noise!

Please share our campaign in your social networks like Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, and never underestimate a good old fashion phone call or face-to-face recommendation to family and friends. 

You would recommend a good restaurant to all your friends and family, so if you like art, dance, and movement culture. Why not recommend our work too!?

The Impact

You contribution is making it possible for these artists to share their innovative work and art that tells the story of incredible gravity defying physical feats blended with beautiful and primitive body language.

The DeRose Art Company has built an incredible story of grassroots success, starting in Buenos Aires Padma was staged in 2008, a captivating work by the beauty and quality of its movements, with 10 artists on stage, images, narration and music define the atmosphere of this show. In 2009 this show was staged in Teatro do Sul, Buenos Aires, and invited to take part in the presentation of the new collection of OSX clothes. The DeRose Art Company was invited to participate in the festivals of Buenos Aires and Florianópolis. Later that year, the company debuted its second work, Shaktí, at the Globe Theatre, Buenos Aires. In 2010 the company performed at the Theatre of the Armenian Cultural Association, and again at the Globe Theater. In February 2011, it held another show at the City Hall, São Paulo and during May and June made several presentations at the Teatro do Sul, Buenos Aires. In September of that year, its new work Nexus was presented at Teatro Margarita Xirgu. During 2012 the company makes seven presentations at Teatro do Sul, Buenos Aires, and in September Padama was again staged at the Globe Theatre. During 2013 the company made a series of presentations at the Teatro Garrick and at the Globe Theatre, presenting that year the works Shaktí and Nexus. In April and May 2014 it presents a cycle of performances at the Teatro El Cubo with Shaktí and Nexus.

We will make sure to honor their success and add New York City to the list of cities worldwide that have hosted this art company.

Risks & Challenges

We don't take unmanageable risks, so rest assure that regardless of whether we meet all or only a few of our funding goals, we will use your support to feature choreographies within the context of the event DeRose Culture New York.

We may not reach our goal to pay for complex lighting features and effects, the show time may be shorter to reduce rental costs, and we may not be able to make the show available to the general public, but the show must and will go on!!!

story:
Conviction is a new play written by Rebecca Morgan and will be the premier production by Playful Moon Theatre, directed by Ria Samartzi.

 Set in Prague, two years after the Communist coup d'etat, Milada Horakova, activist, politician and mother is under surveillance by the secret police. First year law student Ludmila Brozova is being seduced into the Party's inner circle. As the nation begins a modern day witch hunt, their lives intertwine and converge towards zero. In a world where ideas can kill and the game is rigged, who will emerge victorious? 

A tale of belonging, surviving and divided loyalties.

What We Need

Producing theatre in London is a pricey game and we are looking to raise £5000 to help cover production costs such as rehearsal space, tech and design costs and to be able to pay our artists a fair wage for the hard work they put in.

This is our first production as a new company and the more we are able to raise the higher quality the production and the more we are able to compensate our talented and generous team.  We feel it is of the upmost importance to support our artists through any means possible and would love to guarantee them the best financial support we can offer whilst working with us.

What You Get

We hope you enjoy our perks and rewards on the right hand side but we really want to let you know that any support you are able to offer means the world to us and we really are eternally grateful. 

We’d also like to give a shout out to the incredibly talented artist Jennifer Vida Male who is kindly donating her time and skills to this campaign by donating unique portraits as one of our many perks! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! 

Tickets for the show can be purchased here.

story:
Short Summary

Set in a mystical and violent 16th century Prague, Broken City uses a percussive and eclectic score to tell the story of a young woman named Noa, who impersonates a legendary mud creature in an attempt to inspire her people to fight back against the oppression they've been facing. When things do not go as planned, she and her brother Daniel end up on opposite sides of a war and must choose between loyalty to their cause and loyalty to each other, until one is forced to make the ultimate sacrifice to fix their beloved city.

We (Dylan and Melissa) originally wrote Broken City as our thesis musical at NYU Tisch's prestigious Graduate Musical Theatre Writing Program, and we're very excited to continue working on it alongside our wonderful director, Gina Rattan, and our friends at Monday Theatre Company. If you ask us, musical theatre could use a few more feminist superhero stories, and we can't wait to introduce ours to the world. 

These demos and this reading, which will take place on December 2nd, are the best way for us to get our work out there, but we can't do it without your help.

What We Need & What You Get

Our funding is going to two places: the demos and the reading. For the demos, we were able to find time in a recording studio that we didn't need to pay for, but we still need to compensate the incredible singers, instrumentalists, and audio engineers who contributed their time. For the reading, we need money for the following:

  • Compensation for the Director, Stage Manager, Music Director, and Actors
  • Printing of scripts and scores
  • Rental of rehearsal and performance space
  • Other miscellaneous rehearsal costs

In exchange for your contribution, we are prepared to offer:

  • A special shout out on our website and Facebook page ($5 contribution)
  • A shout out and an MP3 of one of our demo tracks of your choice ($10 contribution)
  • A shout out and MP3s of three of our demo tracks of your choice ($25 contribution)
  • A shout out and MP3s of all six of our demo tracks ($50 contribution)
  • All of the above and dinner with the creative team ($100)
  • All of the above and a song written by Melissa and Dylan just for you ($500 contribution)
  • All of the above and a co-producer credit ($1000 contribution)

If we are unable to reach our goal, the funds will either be used to fund as much of the reading as possible or be saved for a future reading once we've been able to raise enough money through other channels.

The Impact

We believe this show has a lot to contribute to the world. First of all, it was written by two women, it's directed by a woman, and the producers of this reading are women... which is still pretty rare in the musical theatre world. On top of that, the hero of our story is a woman, and, *spoiler alert* she spends the vast majority of the show talking about things other than men, including when she's talking to other women (which is a lot of the time, seeing as two of the other three principle characters are also women).

It's also the story of an oppressed cultural minority's journey to empowerment, and what with the year/decade/240 years we've been having in this country, that's something we could all use a little more of. Our hope is that our story will remind people that there is always something that can be done to effect change, while still being joyful and exciting to watch.

We received a lot of positive feedback on the show back at NYU, and we've done so much work on it since then, so we're sure audiences would get even more out of it now.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you don't have the capacity to contribute yourself, please, share our campaign on social media! Every dollar counts, and  money from friends-of-friends helps just as much as money from friends.

For more information, see our website (brokencitymusical.com) and Facebook (facebook.com/brokencitymusical).

story:
Bref résumé du projet

  • Je m'appelle Amaryllis Tremblay et je suis passionnée par le théâtre. Je suis en secondaire 5 dans la seule école au Québec à offrir un cours de théâtre intensif de 5h/semaine en plus des cours obligatoires.
  •  Ce projet est important pour moi parce que le métier de comédienne et les autres métiers de ce domaine m'intéressent, alors cet expérience unique ne pourra être qu'enrichissante.

 Et comment le budget sera géré?

 Ce voyage en France me coûtera environ 1500$, ce qui est abordable, considérant la destination. Le montant inclue tout (nourriture, avion, participation au festival, logement, etc.)

  • Le plus gros morceau de l'argent ira pour le billet d'avion. Sinon, nous seront logés chez des gens de la place pendant quelques jours et dormirons dans des dortoirs étudiants ensuite.
  •  Ma campagne Indigogo n'indique que 800$ parce que je vais essayer de trouver l'autre moitié de l'argent en travaillant et faisant des collectes de fonds à l'école et dans mon quartier.

 D'autres façons d'aider

 Certains d'entre vous n'auront peut-être pas les moyens monétaires de m'aider dans mon projet, et c'est compréhensible! Si vous voulez quand même faire votre part, voici comment:

  •  Si vous avez des contacts dans Montréal et pouvez me référer pour un travail à temps partiel, je serais très reconnaissante.
  •  Passez le mot, partagez mon projet!

Merci infiniment.

 Ce projet est important pour moi parce que le métier de comédienne et les autres métiers de ce domaine m'intéressent, alors cet expérience unique ne pourra être qu'enrichissante.


 Et comment le budget sera géré?

Le plus gros morceau de l'argent ira pour le billet d'avion. Sinon, nous seront logés chez des gens de la place pendant quelques jours et dormirons dans des dortoirs étudiants ensuite.
 Ma campagne Indigogo n'indique que 800$ parce que je vais essayer de trouver l'autre moitié de l'argent en travaillant et faisant des collectes de fonds à l'école et dans mon quartier.

 Si vous avez des contacts dans Montréal et pouvez me référer pour un travail à temps partiel, je serais très reconnaissante.
 Passez le mot, partagez mon projet!

Merci infiniment.

story:
Kids CAN..

  • Dream! And Dream BIG!
  • Learn! With mentors and adults who listen and care!
  • Achieve! Whatever they want, whatever they dream, with loving acceptance and reverent guidance.
  • Realize.. their worth! Through friendships, leadership, healthy influences, and accomplishing goals. (And applause! We LOVE the applause!!)
  • Lead! All of our futures depend on the children of today.

What and Why we need it..

We need prop, set material and costuming funds. Tuition does not even begin to cover the enormous production cost (minimum of 15k) which includes:

  • Theater Rental (We use one of Ft Worth's most prestigious stages!)
  • Microphones (We want every parent, grandparent and guest to hear every well rehearsed, well deserved word.)
  • Licensing (Unlike some of our local competition, we fully license each and every play we do, we respect, and teach respect for the theatre and the arts.)
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Advertising and ticketing expenses

Last but not least, what we need help with now is:

  • Costuming
  • Props
  • Materials for sets

Where we are and where we want to go

We go above and beyond for this program. Our kids experience everything about Musical Theatre, from set and stage design, costuming, acting, and direction. We strive for the best theatre experience that these kids can possibly get.  Our children's productions are not "extras" to help help fund our major productions. Our children's classes ARE our major productions! Our ONLY Productions. With your help, we can give each child a more amazing experience than the last. This is our 4th year and we have grown, and will continue to grow with your help! We have preformed Wizard Of Oz, The Little Mermaid, Annie and in production now for Into The Woods. Next season we would love to grow even more and offer more scholarships and more programs for many more kids and teens who need a fresh diverse outlet.

Why is this so important?

We offer the exception to the norm. Diversity, culture and acceptance, so that these children can see their worth and become the amazing young people and adults they deserve to have the chance to be. These are the kids that will change the world for the better. Help me give them that future.

Some important words from some important people:
http://www.performingartsconvention.org/advocacy/id=28
 
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some just can't monetarily contribute, we get it! But that doesn't mean you can't help:

You can share this campaign with friends and social media.

You can send a "Break a Leg" message to the kids for opening night in April by visiting and giving our Facebook page a "like" @ facebook.com/mtddc

    Thank you for your consideration and your support!

story:
I am on the board of IVEY-award winning Gremlin Theatre (founded in part by my husband Dan's childhood friend Peter Hansen), raising funds for our new permanent performance facility in St. Paul where we can stage meaningful & affordable work. I am excited to be affiliated with this talented and dedicated group of artists as they build out their new home in a great, accessible location at the Vandalia exit off of 94, walking distance from the Green Line Light Rail.

Gremlin is signing a lease to build out a space at VANDALIA TOWER, the old King Koil mattress factory, renovated by First & First, now a vibrant home to businesses, artists & creatives, Lake Monster Brewing & *plenty* of parking (a must for a performance space)!

The new theatre will be an upgrade in quality when it comes to its size, lobby, backstage & tech capabilities. It will also be an exciting set-up: up close and personal, with seating for around 120 arranged in the thrust with audience on three sides. In fact, nobody will be more than four rows from the stage. So you’ll be nice and close to the action with great sight-lines. Both patrons and actors will love it.

Also, Gremlin serves the greater arts community as a space that other smaller organizations without their own permanent homes can rent - a much-needed resource in the Twin Cities. But we need to raise this early money to build out our space.

Your gift will have a huge impact on this new gathering space for theatre-lovers and the community. Your gift is tax-deductible, as Gremlin is a registered non-profit charity.

Please join me in my personal goal of raising $5,000 towards their campaign.

Past Gremlin Theatre production photos of AFTER MISS JULIE, H2O, OUTSIDE PADUCAH and THE EFFECT OF GAMMA RAYS ON MAN-IN-THE MOON MARIGOLDS (c) Peter Hansen / Gremlin Theatre. Photos of Vandalia Tower (c) First and First, 2016
story_txt: I am on the board of IVEY-award winning Gremlin Theatre (founded in part by my husband Dan's childhood friend Peter Hansen), raising funds for our new permanent performance facility in St. Paul where we can stage meaningful & affordable work. I am excited to be affiliated with this talented and dedicated group of artists as they build out their new home in a great, accessible location at the Vandalia exit off of 94, walking distance from the Green Line Light Rail.Gremlin is signing a lease to build out a space at VANDALIA TOWER, the old King Koil mattress factory, renovated by First & First, now a vibrant home to businesses, artists & creatives, Lake Monster Brewing & *plenty* of parking (a must for a performance space)!The new theatre will be an upgrade in quality when it comes to its size, lobby, backstage & tech capabilities. It will also be an exciting set-up: up close and personal, with seating for around 120 arranged in the thrust with audience on three sides. In fact, nobody will be more than four rows from the stage. So you’ll be nice and close to the action with great sight-lines. Both patrons and actors will love it.Also, Gremlin serves the greater arts community as a space that other smaller organizations without their own permanent homes can rent - a much-needed resource in the Twin Cities. But we need to raise this early money to build out our space.Your gift will have a huge impact on this new gathering space for theatre-lovers and the community. Your gift is tax-deductible, as Gremlin is a registered non-profit charity.Please join me in my personal goal of raising $5,000 towards their campaign.Past Gremlin Theatre production photos of AFTER MISS JULIE, H2O, OUTSIDE PADUCAH and THE EFFECT OF GAMMA RAYS ON MAN-IN-THE MOON MARIGOLDS (c) Peter Hansen / Gremlin Theatre. Photos of Vandalia Tower (c) First and First, 2016

story:
Person[ing]

Text & ideas from the book "Architectural Body" by Gins & Arkawa

"The organism we are speaking of persons the world; other types of organisms dog, giraffe, or cockroach the world. While members of lower species routinely produce behavior that is true to type, the organism that persons, not always able to summon up all it must to produce a person, has a higher probability of failure."
- Architectural Body

A short dance film exploring the dynamics that allow us organisms to person. Our minds, bodies, environments, and perceptions create the worlds within which we live; we'll dive into the conflicting signals that create our realities. Based on study of performance, movement, and teaching / learning procedures & relationships. 

A non-narrative, highly-stylized film with elements of story will. We will utilize dance / physical acting / clown work / devised movement to create the piece.  Shooting TBD in July on Dauphin Island, AL / August in New York City.

This film aims to serve as a launching point for further explorations into organisms and the processes by which their 'persons' are created & sustained. Footage to be used for the short film itself as well as for live interdisciplinary performances. 

Please see our other videos in the Gallery linked above! 


What the funds will help with:

> rehearsal space
> filming space / equipment 
> costume / make-up 
> editing & post-production needs
> film festival entry fees
> cast treats / compensation / bribes 

But also... 

*Contribute to a conversation about humanity that is desperately needed in our current political and social climate!
*An amazing creative experience to share with my middle school Drama & Dance students next year!
*Launching a larger body of work based on these topics that is more actively socially and politically engaged!

Cast / Creative:

Director / Choreographer / Creator: 
Chris Rehmann
Filming:
Jake Nathanson

Dancers / Artists / Collaborators: 

Chris Albrigo

Shani Bekt

Andrew Chung

Wednesday Sue Derrico

Holly Gillian 

Gabriel Eugene Milligan-Green 

Kingsley Nwaogu

Chris Rehmann

Trevor F. Salter

Lindsay Wolff

story:
Our Lear

Eleusis Collective’s production of William Shakespeare’s King Lear is a site-specific and promenade production where audience and actors travel together through a rural Iowa farm just after the 1980s farming crisis. Installed in an industrial Chicago farm and fueled by an original singer songwriter score, this political rendering of Lear looks at the play through the eyes of the daughters and asks: how can we free ourselves of our societal coding and simply connect?

Who Are We? 

Eleusis Collective is dedicated to creating "a space for the female imaginary." Eleusis is a Chicago-based company that explores issues of gender, identity, and representation through performance, literary, and multimedia arts. In summer 2012, we launched our first project in the community of Rutland, VT, implementing a theatre arts workshop for local high school girls. In fall 2012, we produced an original play called The Last Sleepover at the Chicago Fringe Festival. In spring 2013, we tackled the Chicago premiere of Sam Holcroft's Vanya, exploring Chekhov's characters (especially female) through a contemporary lens in a unique site-specific production in Logan Square.

What We Need and What You Get:

We are asking for a collaborative effort to raise $11,000. These funds go directly into the production and are critical to making King Lear happen.

We have a Production team of 10 people. Each of these individuals work collaboratively (and tirelessly) to promote the experience of the show and build its community. We need funds to pay our collaborators, support our community partners and spaces, and reach our potential audience members.

The funds allocated to the Design team (5 people) are crucial for the environment of the production, and will serve to create and maintain a fully immersive and electrifying experience including live music and an installed world on an urban farm. 

The cast of King Lear is a group of 12 talented actors that will bring the timeless words of Shakespeare to the stage. Already in rehearsals, these actors are dedicated to the rigorous technique required by Shakespeare's language while asking the big character questions to build a seamless world. 

The Impact

With your help, we can make our dreams of King Lear a reality, and provide a truly unique theatrical experience that challenges the traditional paradigm, and infuses a classic text with an exciting contemporary sensibility.  A big part of this production is engaging with community and we are tackling four community conversations to increase awareness and visibility of local organizations, especially urban farmers. 

Our Partners

A contribution to this project not only supports Eleusis Collective and feminist Shakespeare, but also the local urban farm Patchwork Farms. Read/Write Library is also one of our partners -- their mission is to collect, preserve, and provide access to community media in order to encourage inquiry into and ownership of the historical record. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are asking you, our friends, family, and peers, to join our community and contribute in any way possible. A wide variety of materials and labor will go into making King Lear a reality, and we would be thrilled to accept in kind donations in many forms. Please contact alexandra.garfinkle@gmail.com if you are interested in volunteering/assisting or would like to support the show in any way.

story:
Summary:

We are excited to share this new venture with you as we take you along a madcap, farcical journey through Victorian England. This has been 2 years in the making and we are very happy to present this reading to a live audience. 

Cast:

Joe Harkins (Ragtime on Ellis Island)

Raul Hernandez

Melissa Rose Hirsch (The Bad Years)

Andrew Holder

Robin Cameron Lounsbury*

Evan Mayer (Annie National Tour)

Angelo McDonough

Christopher Michaels

Chris Collins-Pisano

Daniel Plimpton* (The Book Of Mormon First National Tour)

Adrian Rifat

Jordan Silver

Morgan Smith (The Sound of Music on Broadway)

Kasey Yeargain

Frank Vlastnik* (Broadway's Sweet Smell of Success, Big, and A Year with Frog and Toad)

Written by composer/lyricist Kit Goldstein Grant

Directed by Christopher Hlinka

Musical directed by Matthew Bennis

Stage managed by Joshua Quinn*

Produced by Sahar Helmy and Melissa Nally

*Member of Actors' Equity Association. Equity approved showcase.

What We Need:

Cast and Crew

Rehearsal Space

Venue Space

Musicians 

Publicity/Press

What You Get:

What you get are some amazing perks, our unending gratitude, and the joy of supporting new musicals! 

Risks & Challenges:

Any musical faces challenges. Your support will help us take The Wrong Box to the next level! 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Please share on Facebook, Twitter, and other social media sites. Spread the word. Indiegogo also has some nifty tools to help you help us. Sharing is caring!

story: I'm trying to do something I've never really seen before. I hope that Closed Eyes and Parted Lips is an honest, moving play that allows people to connect using the universal language of laughter. PTSD is often talked about regarding war, but PTSD as realated to sexual trauma isn't as prevalent.

story:
Catherine

     Hi, my name is Mackenzie Jennings and I am a sophomore at a school of the arts located in Raleigh.  Recently, I finished writing my pride and joy, Catherine. And that is the reason why I have made this campaign. My goal for this campaign is to gain money for my production, so that I may perform it at a nearby theatre. As a high school student, I do not have enough money to rent the theatre, create costumes and to be able to buy props. With your help, I can raise this money. If I reach my goal, I would be thrilled! I thank you for your time, and please, consider donating for our cause.

What We Need & What You Will Get

     If we are to be able to perform this play, we will need $6,500 overall. I have budgeted everything with this in mind, and it would be the perfect number. If you can donate a specific amount to our cause, preferably a large amount, but I understand that money is tight, you can receive a perk.  At the moment, there are only three perks. If you donate $50, then you will receive a signed playbill. If you donate $100, you will receive a free disc, with the recording of one our performance. If you donate $200, you can get a free ticket to our matinee showing. At this time, however, I am not sure if I will reach my goal, so where will all the donated money to if I do not reach my goal? The donated money will still be used. I put this campaign in a flexible budget, because every single dollar that goes into this campaign is extremely precious to me.

The Impact

     This play is important to me, as it hits close to home. Everyone sees these people, these historical figures, as perfect people, but in actuality, they aren't. This play tells the important story of Catherine the Great as Sophie, a German noble, way before her rule in Russia. And that's important. To see someone you look up to like this, in their adolescence, still trying to find their way, opens up doors for you. It tells you that it's okay to not be perfect.

Risks & Challenges

     Even though I am just a high school girl, there are things I can do to change things, and this is a step towards that, so please, donate money to my cause. Catherine can change people's lives, and it has already changed my own. Though it is risky, and we could end up under budget, I have faith within the people who are scrolling through my campaign, so my job is to promote this campaign until the end. 

Other Ways You Can Help

     Please don't forget that you can share this campaign! Even if you may not be able to donate any money, there are other people who are willing, so spread the word. I thank you for your time, and I hope to reach our goal.

story:
We have pulled out all the stops to make the world theatrical premiere of "One Way Trip to Mars" an exciting and memorable event, starting with an amazing cast of rising stars from the New York theatrical world.  From more than 200 qualified applicants we selected 12 exceptional actors whose singing was so emotionally potent it brought tears to our eyes.  
 
We will follow up later with bios and video excerpts so you can see for yourself, but here's a brief overview:  Pepe Nufrio (pepenufrioart.com) will be Paolo "Cruze," the first astronaut to travel to Mars on a one-way mission.  Fantine Pritoula (fantinemusic.com) will star as Cassandra, Paolo's life partner and fellow astronaut who is sent to join him when conditions on earth deteriorate. Nacole Palmer (nacolepalmer.com) stars as Madeleine, Cassandra's best friend and confidant; and Cory Gibson (onewaytriptomars.us/cory_gibson/) stars as Hector, heroic head of the space agency. Rennie Weingart stars in the dancing role she has developed as the embodiment of "Mars," while Marta Rymer, Evan Michael Smith, Maigan Kennedy, David Curtis, Renee Gagner, Jackson Mattek, and Elora Von Rosch perform in a variety of roles in the Ensemble.  With Dennis St. Pierre as Director,  musical direction by Raymond Bailey (assisted by Courtney Babbidge) and an orchestra of fabulous musicians that includes Parker Kenyon, Joe Beninati, Marc Chillemi, Kate Campbell-Strauss, Jeff Buchsbaum, and several others, we are gearing up to raise the roof.
 

It's not just the fantastic cast and great music that make "One Way Trip to Mars" such a powerful theatrical experience. We have also tapped into the talents of Chad Lefebvre (chadlefebvre.com) to manifest our shared creative vision of a cinematic backdrop that will transport you with our lead characters into outer space and to the surface of Mars. It is a cross between musical theater and virtual reality. It's no wonder that we have caught the attention of NASA and the space exploration community.  Even Buzz Aldrin is talking about it.

Here's how this all came about.  Three years ago, after hearing about the Mars-One Program, Johannah sat down at the piano on a cold winter night and wrote “It Catches Up to You,” the first song in what would then inspire an entire rock opera. Both Johannah and Peter found themselves intrigued about the psychology that would compel over 200,000 people to volunteer to be the first humans to make a one-way trip to the Red Planet, with no hope of ever returning to Earth. 

While Peter began writing songs from the perspective of a solo astronaut setting off on a spectacular adventure, Johannah tapped into the emotional depth and complexity of those who would be left behind. Soon after that first song (which is the final song in the opera) more material began to present itself with a cohesive narrative about Paolo “Cruze” and Cassandra, two lovers on intersecting developmental trajectories. Paolo, like a character from Greek mythology, starts with considerable hubris but becomes heroic in his growing humility, while Cassandra, as her name implies, goes from being a warning voice without agency to an empowered heroine.

After working together for more than two years to write songs around their developing narrative, Johannah and Peter—with their Hollowbody Electric Band and an 18-voice chorus—staged a series of multi-media concerts to standing ovations in Bath, Maine. Those performances caught the attention of Dennis St. Pierre, whose decades of experience in musical theater and production qualified him to help re-work the concert version of the show into a piece fully-developed for musical theater.  Now with 28 original songs and a cast and crew of professionals from New York, One Way Trip to Mars premieres August 24 – 27 at the historic Waterville Opera House in Maine.  

Combined with the show we are planning an Art & Science Fair in which local students will explore through the arts the many areas of science involved in space exploration and the future human settlement of Mars. Our dream is that Waterville will be the first stop on the show’s way to Broadway and beyond, and that the art & science fair will be a template for a new way of including the arts in STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, ART & Math) Education.  Further, from every ticket sold we are donating $1.00 to the Shriners' Children's Hospital.

Putting on a show and educational program like this is not cheap--especially when bringing in the kind of exceptional talent we have recruited for cast and crew. The normal funding streams (ticket sales, advertising, sponsorship, grants) may not be enough, so we are asking our friends to join us in supporting this work. We have great rewards in store for you for being part of our team, ranging from music files and DVDs to premium tickets, invitations to backstage events, meetings with cast and crew, and more.  Please take a few minutes to review which level of support feels right for you. Even if you can give only a few dollars now you can still help us by spreading the word and encouraging your friends to join the campaign or purchase tickets to the show.

We are super excited about “One Way Trip to Mars,” and are pleased that so many people are expressing their interest and support. WBLM (radio 102.9) has signed on as our Media Sponsor, and the Explore Mars organization (supported by NASA, Boeing, Lockheed Martin and other major organizations involved in space exploration) is partnering with us to help ensure access to technical and financial support from the space exploration community.  Check out the wonderful article by famed music critic Bob Keyes in this week’s Maine Sunday Telegram (http://www.pressherald.com/2017/06/18/one-way-t...). We hope you will join us, too, with your financial support and attendance. 

With your help “One Way Trip to Mars” will have an amazing future. 

Please repost on social media and tell friends and family about the campaign and about the show (and for out-of-state folks, consider this: there’s no better time than the end of August to spend a few days in Maine).

We look forward to hearing from you…and seeing you in Waterville! Now, please meet our cast:

Fantine as Cassandra

Pepe Nufrio as Paolo "Cruze"

Cory Gibson as Hector

Nacole Palmer as Madeleine

Maigan Kennedy (Ensemble)

Marta Rymer as "Mars"

Elora Von Rosch (Ensemble)

Evan Michael Smith (Ensemble)

David Curtis (Ensemble)

Renee Gagner (Ensemble)

Jackson Mattek
